paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO, SALARINO, and SOLANIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO, SALARINO, and SOLANIO enter.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$In sooth, I know not why I am so sad.$NEWLINE$It wearies me; you say it wearies you.$NEWLINE$But how I caught it, found it, or came by it,$NEWLINE$What stuff ’tis made of, whereof it is born,$NEWLINE$I am to learn.$NEWLINE$And such a want-wit sadness makes of me,$NEWLINE$That I have much ado to know myself.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$To be honest, I don’t know why I’m so sad. I’m tired of it, and you say you’re tired of it too. But I have no idea how I got so depressed. And if I can’t figure out what’s making me depressed, I must not understand myself very well.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Your mind is tossing on the ocean,$NEWLINE$There, where your argosies with portly sail,$NEWLINE$Like signors and rich burghers on the flood—$NEWLINE$Or, as it were, the pageants of the sea—$NEWLINE$Do overpeer the petty traffickers$NEWLINE$That curtsy to them, do them reverence$NEWLINE$As they fly by them with their woven wings.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$You’re worried about your ships. Your mind is out there getting tossed around on the ocean with them. But they’re fine. They’re like huge parade floats on the sea. They’re so big they look down on the smaller ships, which all have to bow and then get out of the way. Your ships fly like birds past those little boats.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth,$NEWLINE$The better part of my affections would$NEWLINE$Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still$NEWLINE$Plucking the grass to know where sits the wind,$NEWLINE$Peering in maps for ports and piers and roads.$NEWLINE$And every object that might make me fear$NEWLINE$Misfortune to my ventures out of doubt$NEWLINE$Would make me sad.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Yes, believe me, if I had such risky business ventures in other countries, I’d be sad too. I’d worry about it every second. I’d constantly be tossing blades of grass into the air to find out which way the wind was blowing. I’d be peering over maps to figure out the best ports, piers, and waterways. Everything that made me worry about my ships would make me sad.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$My wind cooling my broth$NEWLINE$Would blow me to an ague when I thought$NEWLINE$What harm a wind too great at sea might do.$NEWLINE$I should not see the sandy hourglass run,$NEWLINE$But I should think of shallows and of flats$NEWLINE$And see my wealthy Andrew docked in sand,$NEWLINE$Vailing her high top lower than her ribs$NEWLINE$To kiss her burial. Should I go to church$NEWLINE$And see the holy edifice of stone$NEWLINE$And not bethink me straight of dangerous rocks,$NEWLINE$Which, touching but my gentle vessel’s side,$NEWLINE$Would scatter all her spices on the stream,$NEWLINE$Enrobe the roaring waters with my silks,$NEWLINE$And, in a word, but even now worth this,$NEWLINE$And now worth nothing? Shall I have the thought$NEWLINE$To think on this, and shall I lack the thought$NEWLINE$That such a thing bechanced would make me sad?$NEWLINE$But tell not me. I know Antonio$NEWLINE$Is sad to think upon his merchandise.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I’d get scared every time I blew on my soup to cool it, thinking of how a strong wind could wipe out my ships. Every time I glanced at the sand in an hourglass I’d imagine my ships wrecked on sandbars. I’d think of dangerous rocks every time I went to church and saw the stones it was made of. If my ship brushed up against rocks like that, its whole cargo of spices would be dumped into the sea. All of its silk shipments would be sent flying into the roaring waters. In one moment I’d go bankrupt. Who wouldn’t get sad thinking about things like that? It’s obvious. Antonio is sad because he’s so worried about his cargo.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Believe me, no. I thank my fortune for it—$NEWLINE$My ventures are not in one bottom trusted,$NEWLINE$Nor to one place, nor is my whole estate$NEWLINE$Upon the fortune of this present year.$NEWLINE$Therefore my merchandise makes me not sad.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No, that’s not it, trust me. Thankfully my financial situation is healthy. I don’t have all of my money invested in one ship, or one part of the world. If I don’t do well this year, I’ll still be okay. So it’s not my business that’s making me sad.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Why then, you are in love.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Well then, you must be in love.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Fie, fie!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Oh, give me a break.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Not in love neither? Then let us say you are sad$NEWLINE$Because you are not merry—and ’twere as easy$NEWLINE$For you to laugh and leap and say you are merry$NEWLINE$Because you are not sad. Now, by two-headed Janus,$NEWLINE$Nature hath framed strange fellows in her time.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$You’re not in love either? Fine, let’s just say you’re sad because you’re not in a good mood. You know, it’d be just as easy for you to laugh and dance around and say you’re in a good mood. You could just say you’re not sad. Humans are so different.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Some that will evermore peep through their eyes$NEWLINE$And laugh like parrots at a bagpiper,$NEWLINE$And other of such vinegar aspect$NEWLINE$That they’ll not show their teeth in way of smile$NEWLINE$Though Nestor swear the jest be laughable.
paragraphs.translated: Some people will laugh at anything, and others are so grouchy they won’t even crack a smile when they hear something hysterically funny.

paragraphs.original: Enter BASSANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO enter.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO

paragraphs.original: Here comes Bassanio, your most noble kinsman,$NEWLINE$Gratiano, and Lorenzo. Fare ye well.$NEWLINE$We leave you now with better company.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes your cousin Bassanio. And Gratiano and Lorenzo too. Goodbye, then. We’ll leave you to talk to them. They’re better company.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I would have stayed till I had made you merry$NEWLINE$If worthier friends had not prevented me.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I would’ve stayed to cheer you up, if your nobler friends hadn’t shown up.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Your worth is very dear in my regard.$NEWLINE$I take it your own business calls on you$NEWLINE$And you embrace th' occasion to depart.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You’re both very precious to me. But I understand. You need to leave to take care of your own business.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO, LORENZO, GRATIANO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Good morrow, my good lords.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO, LORENZO, and GRATIANO) Good morning, gentlemen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$,$NEWLINE$, and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SALARINO and SOLANIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Good signors both, when shall we laugh? Say, when?$NEWLINE$You grow exceeding strange. Must it be so?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SALARINO and SOLANIO) Hello, friends. When are we going to have fun together again? Just name the time. We never see you anymore. Does it have to be that way?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$We’ll make our leisures to attend on yours.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Let us know when you want to get together. We’re available.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SALARINO and SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO and SOLANIO exit.$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio,$NEWLINE$We two will leave you. But at dinnertime$NEWLINE$I pray you have in mind where we must meet.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Bassanio, we’ll say goodbye for now, since you’ve found Antonio. But don’t forget, we’re meeting for dinner tonight.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I will not fail you.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, I’ll be there.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$You look not well, Signor Antonio.$NEWLINE$You have too much respect upon the world.$NEWLINE$They lose it that do buy it with much care.$NEWLINE$Believe me, you are marvelously changed.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$You don’t look well, Antonio. You’re taking things too seriously. People with too much invested in the world always get hurt. I’m telling you, you don’t look like yourself.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I hold the world but as the world, Gratiano—$NEWLINE$A stage where every man must play a part,$NEWLINE$And mine a sad one.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$For me the world is just the world, Gratiano—a stage where every person has a part to play. I play a sad one.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Let me play the fool.$NEWLINE$With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come.$NEWLINE$And let my liver rather heat with wine$NEWLINE$Than my heart cool with mortifying groans.$NEWLINE$Why should a man whose blood is warm within$NEWLINE$Sit like his grandsire cut in alabaster,$NEWLINE$Sleep when he wakes, and creep into the jaundice$NEWLINE$By being peevish? I tell thee what, Antonio—$NEWLINE$I love thee, and ’tis my love that speaks—$NEWLINE$There are a sort of men whose visages$NEWLINE$Do cream and mantle like a standing pond,$NEWLINE$And do a willful stillness entertain$NEWLINE$With purpose to be dressed in an opinion$NEWLINE$Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit,$NEWLINE$As who should say, “I am Sir Oracle,$NEWLINE$And when I ope my lips, let no dog bark!”$NEWLINE$O my Antonio, I do know of these$NEWLINE$That therefore only are reputed wise$NEWLINE$For saying nothing, when I am very sure$NEWLINE$If they should speak, would almost damn those ears$NEWLINE$Which, hearing them, would call their brothers fools.$NEWLINE$I’ll tell thee more of this another time.$NEWLINE$But fish not with this melancholy bait$NEWLINE$For this fool gudgeon, this opinion.—$NEWLINE$Come, good Lorenzo.—Fare ye well awhile.$NEWLINE$I’ll end my exhortation after dinner.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Then I’ll play the happy fool and get laugh lines on my face. I’d rather overload my liver with wine than starve my heart by denying myself fun. Why should any living man sit still like a statue? Why should he sleep when he’s awake? Why should he get ulcers from being crabby all the time? I love you, and I’m telling you this because I care about you, Antonio—there are men who always look serious. Their faces never move or show any expression, like stagnant ponds covered with scum. They’re silent and stern, and they think they’re wise and deep, important and respectable. When they talk, they think everybody else should keep quiet, and that even dogs should stop barking. I know a lot of men like that, Antonio. The only reason they’re considered wise is because they don’t say anything. I’m sure if they ever opened their mouths, everyone would see what fools they are. I’ll talk to you more about this some other time. In the meantime, cheer up. Don’t go around looking so glum. That’s my opinion, but what do I know? I’m a fool.—Let’s go, Lorenzo.—Goodbye for now. I’ll finish my lecture after dinner.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Well, we will leave you then till dinnertime.$NEWLINE$I must be one of these same dumb wise men,$NEWLINE$For Gratiano never lets me speak.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$All right, we’ll see you at dinnertime. I must be one of these silent so-called wise men Gratiano’s talking about, because he never lets me get a word in.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Well, keep me company but two years more,$NEWLINE$Thou shalt not know the sound of thine own tongue.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$If you hang around me for two more years, you’ll forget the sound of your own voice. I won’t ever let you speak.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Farewell. I’ll grow a talker for this gear.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Goodbye. After that lecture of yours, I’ll start talking a lot.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Thanks, i' faith, for silence is only commendable$NEWLINE$In a neat’s tongue dried and a maid not vendible.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Thank you. The only tongues that should be silent are ox-tongues on a dinner plate and those that belong to old maids.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GRATIANO and LORENZO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$LORENZO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO and LORENZO exit.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$LORENZO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Is that any thing now?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Is he right?

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice. His reasons are as two grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff—you shall seek all day ere you find them, and when you have them they are not worth the search.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Gratiano talks more nonsense than any other man in Venice. His point is always like a needle in a haystack—you look for it all day, and when you find it you realize it wasn’t worth the trouble.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, tell me now what lady is the same$NEWLINE$To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage,$NEWLINE$That you today promised to tell me of?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$So, who’s this girl, the one you said you were going to take a special trip for? You promised to tell me.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$'Tis not unknown to you, Antonio,$NEWLINE$How much I have disabled mine estate,$NEWLINE$By something showing a more swelling port$NEWLINE$Than my faint means would grant continuance.$NEWLINE$Nor do I now make moan to be abridged$NEWLINE$From such a noble rate. But my chief care
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Antonio, you know how bad my finances have been lately. I’ve been living way beyond my means. Don’t get me wrong, I’m not complaining about having to cut back.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Is to come fairly off from the great debts$NEWLINE$Wherein my time something too prodigal$NEWLINE$Hath left me gaged. To you, Antonio,$NEWLINE$I owe the most in money and in love,$NEWLINE$And from your love I have a warranty$NEWLINE$To unburden all my plots and purposes$NEWLINE$How to get clear of all the debts I owe.
paragraphs.translated: I just want to be honorable and pay off the big debts that piled up when I was living the high life. I’m in debt to many people, and I owe most to you, Antonio—both money and gratitude. And because you care about me, I know you’ll let me tell you my plan to clear all my debts.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it.$NEWLINE$And if it stand, as you yourself still do,$NEWLINE$Within the eye of honor, be assured$NEWLINE$My purse, my person, my extremest means$NEWLINE$Lie all unlocked to your occasions.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Please let me know your plan, Bassanio. As long as it’s honorable, you can be sure that I’ll let you use all my money and do everything I can to help you.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$In my school days, when I had lost one shaft,$NEWLINE$I shot his fellow of the selfsame flight$NEWLINE$The selfsame way with more advisèd watch$NEWLINE$To find the other forth—and by adventuring both,$NEWLINE$I oft found both. I urge this childhood proof$NEWLINE$Because what follows is pure innocence.$NEWLINE$I owe you much, and, like a willful youth,$NEWLINE$That which I owe is lost. But if you please$NEWLINE$To shoot another arrow that self way$NEWLINE$Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt,$NEWLINE$As I will watch the aim, or to find both$NEWLINE$Or bring your latter hazard back again$NEWLINE$And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Back when I was a schoolboy, if I lost an arrow I would try to find it by shooting another arrow in the same direction, watching the second arrow more carefully than I had the first. By risking the second arrow, I’d often get both of them back. I’m telling you this story for a reason. I owe you a lot, and like a spoiled kid I’ve lost what I owe you. But if you’d be willing to shoot another arrow the same way you shot the first, I’ll watch your arrow more carefully this time. Either we’ll get back all the money I owe you, or else we’ll get back what you lend me this time, and I’ll just owe you what I already owe you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You know me well, and herein spend but time$NEWLINE$To wind about my love with circumstance.$NEWLINE$And out of doubt you do me now more wrong$NEWLINE$In making question of my uttermost$NEWLINE$Than if you had made waste of all I have.$NEWLINE$Then do but say to me what I should do$NEWLINE$That in your knowledge may by me be done,$NEWLINE$And I am pressed unto it. Therefore speak.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You know me better than that. You’re wasting your breath. All of this talk means you have doubts about my friendship. That’s worse than if you bankrupted me. Just tell me what to do, and I’ll do it. Tell me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$In Belmont is a lady richly left,$NEWLINE$And she is fair and—fairer than that word—$NEWLINE$Of wondrous virtues. Sometimes from her eyes$NEWLINE$I did receive fair speechless messages.$NEWLINE$Her name is Portia, nothing undervalued$NEWLINE$To Cato’s daughter, Brutus' Portia.$NEWLINE$Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,$NEWLINE$For the four winds blow in from every coast$NEWLINE$Renownèd suitors, and her sunny locks$NEWLINE$Hang on her temples like a golden fleece,$NEWLINE$Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchos' strand,$NEWLINE$And many Jasons come in quest of her.$NEWLINE$O my Antonio, had I but the means$NEWLINE$To hold a rival place with one of them,$NEWLINE$I have a mind presages me such thrift$NEWLINE$That I should questionless be fortunate!
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$There’s a girl in Belmont who’s inherited a huge amount of money, and she’s beautiful and—even better—she’s a good person. I think she likes me. Sometimes the expression on her face tells me she likes me. Her name is Portia. She’s as rich as that famous Roman heroine Portia, the daughter of Cato and wife of Brutus. Her wealth is world-famous. Famous and important men have come in from all over the world to try to marry her. The hair that hangs down on her forehead is like gold, calling every adventurer to Belmont like a gold rush. Antonio, if I only had enough money to hold my own against those suitors, I know I could win her!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Thou know’st that all my fortunes are at sea.$NEWLINE$Neither have I money nor commodity$NEWLINE$To raise a present sum. Therefore go forth,$NEWLINE$Try what my credit can in Venice do—$NEWLINE$That shall be racked even to the uttermost$NEWLINE$To furnish thee to Belmont, to fair Portia.$NEWLINE$Go presently inquire, and so will I,$NEWLINE$Where money is, and I no question make$NEWLINE$To have it of my trust or for my sake.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$You know right now all my money’s tied up in that cargo that’s still at sea. I can’t give you the cash you need because I don’t have it. But go ahead and charge things to me on credit, as much credit as I can get in Venice. I’ll use all my lines of credit to help you get to Belmont, to Portia. Go see who will lend money, and I’ll do the same. I’m sure I can get something either as a business loan, or as a personal favor.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA and NERISSA$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA and NERISSA enter.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is aweary of this great world.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Oh Nerissa, my poor little body is tired of this great big world.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You would be, sweet madam, if your miseries were in the same abundance as your good fortunes are. And yet for aught I see, they are as sick that surfeit with too much as they that starve with nothing. It is no mean happiness, therefore, to be seated in the mean. Superfluity comes sooner by white hairs, but competency lives longer.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You’d be tired, madam, if you had bad luck rather than wealth and good luck. But as far as I can tell, people with too much suffer as much as people with nothing. The best way to be happy is to be in between. When you have too much you get old sooner, but having just enough helps you live longer.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Good sentences, and well pronounced.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Good point, and well said.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$They would be better if well followed.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$It would be better if you actually applied it to your life.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If to do were as easy as to know what were good to do, chapels had been churches and poor men’s cottages princes' palaces. It is a good divine that follows his own instructions. I can easier teach twenty what were good to be done than be one of the twenty to follow mine own teaching. The brain may devise laws for the blood, but a hot temper leaps o'er a cold decree. Such a hare is madness the youth—to skip o'er the meshes of good counsel the cripple. But this reasoning is not in the fashion to choose me a husband. O me, the word “choose!” I may neither choose whom I would nor refuse whom I dislike—so is the will of a living daughter curbed by the will of a dead father. Is it not hard, Nerissa, that I cannot choose one nor refuse none?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You think it’s that easy? If doing good deeds were as easy as knowing how to do them, then everyone would be better off. Small chapels would be big churches, and poor men’s cottages would be princes' palaces. It takes a good priest to practice what he preaches. For me, it’s easier to lecture twenty people on how to be good than to be the one person out of twenty who actually does good things. The brain can tell the heart what to do, but what does it matter? Cold rules don’t matter when you’ve got a hot temper. Young people are like frisky young rabbits, and good advice is like a crippled old man trying to catch them. But thinking like this won’t help me choose a husband. Oh, the word “choose” is strange! I can’t choose who I like, or refuse who I dislike. I’m a living daughter still controlled by the wishes of her dead father. Isn’t it a pain that I can’t choose or refuse anyone, Nerissa?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Your father was ever virtuous, and holy men at their death have good inspirations. Therefore the lottery that he hath devised in these three chests of gold, silver, and lead, whereof who chooses his meaning chooses you, will no doubt never be chosen by any rightly but one who shall rightly love. But what warmth is there in your affection towards any of these princely suitors that are already come?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Your father was an extremely moral man, and religious people get odd ideas on their deathbeds. Your father’s idea was to have a game with three boxes. The suitor who can figure out whether to pick the gold, silver, or lead box will solve your father’s riddle—and that suitor’s the man for you. No one will ever choose the right box who doesn’t deserve your love. But tell me. Do you like any of the princely suitors who’ve come?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I pray thee, overname them. And as thou namest them, I will describe them. And according to my description, level at my affection.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Run through the list. As you name them I’ll describe them for you, and from my descriptions you can guess how I feel toward them.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$First, there is the Neapolitan prince.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Well, first there was the prince from Naples.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Ay, that’s a colt indeed, for he doth nothing but talk of his horse, and he makes it a great appropriation to his own good parts that he can shoe him himself. I am much afeard my lady his mother played false with a smith.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Ah, yes, that stallion. All he talks about is his horse. He thinks it’s a great credit to his character that he can shoe a horse all by himself. I’m afraid his mother may have had an affair with a blacksmith.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Then there is the County Palatine.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Then there’s the Count Palatine.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He doth nothing but frown, as who should say, “An you will not have me, choose.” He hears merry tales and smiles not. I fear he will prove the weeping philosopher when he grows old, being so full of unmannerly sadness in his youth. I had rather be married to a death’s-head with a bone in his mouth than to either of these. God defend me from these two!
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He does nothing but frown, as if he wants to say, “If you don’t want me, I don’t care.” He doesn’t even smile when he hears funny stories. If he’s so sad and solemn when he’s young, I can only imagine how much he’ll cry as an old man. No, I’d rather be married to a skull with a bone in its mouth than to either of those men. God protect me from these two!

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$How say you by the French lord, Monsieur le Bon?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What did you think about that French lord, Monsieur le Bon?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$God made him and therefore let him pass for a man. In truth, I know it is a sin to be a mocker, but he!—why, he hath a horse better than the Neapolitan’s, a better bad habit of frowning than the Count Palatine. He is every man in no man. If a throstle sing, he falls straight a- capering. He will fence with his own shadow. If I should marry him, I should marry twenty husbands. If he would despise me I would forgive him, for if he love me to madness I shall never requite him.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$We might as well call him a man, since God created him. No, I know it’s bad to make fun of people, but still! His horse is better than the Neapolitan’s and he frowns more than the Count Palatine. He was trying to outdo everyone so much that you couldn’t tell who he was. He started dancing every time a bird sang, and he was so eager to show off his fencing that he’d fight with his own shadow. If I married him, I might as well as marry twenty husbands, because he’s like twenty men all rolled into one! I’d understand it if he hated me, since even if he loved me desperately, I’d never be able to love him back.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What say you then to Falconbridge, the young baron of$NEWLINE$England?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What about Falconbridge, that young English baron?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You know I say nothing to him, for he understands not me, nor I him. He hath neither Latin, French, nor Italian, and you will come into the court and swear that I have a poor pennyworth in the English. He is a proper man’s picture, but alas, who can converse with a dumb show? How oddly he is suited! I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I have no opinion about him. We don’t talk because we don’t understand each other. He doesn’t speak Latin, French, or Italian, and you know how little English I speak. He’s great-looking, but how can you talk to someone who doesn’t speak your language? He was dressed so oddly too! I think he got his jacket in Italy, his tights in France, his hat in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What think you of the Scottish lord, his neighbor?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What do you think of his neighbor, the Scottish lord?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That he hath a neighborly charity in him, for he borrowed a box of the ear of the Englishman and swore he would pay him again when he was able. I think the Frenchman became his surety and sealed under for another.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I think he’s very forgiving, since he let the Englishman slap him on the ear without hitting him back. Rather than defend himself, he just threatened to pay the Englishman back later. Then the Frenchman promised to help the Scot pay the Englishman back, and added a slap of his own.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$How like you the young German, the Duke of Saxony’s nephew?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$How did you like the young German, the duke of Saxony’s nephew?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober, and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk. When he is best he is a little worse than a man, and when he is worst he is little better than a beast. And the worst fall that ever fell, I hope I shall make shift to go without him.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He’s pretty awful in the morning when he’s sobering up, and even worse in the afternoon when he’s drunk. At his best he’s a little less than a man, and at his worst he’s little more than an animal. If we got married and he tragically met his demise, I’m sure I could find a way to go on without him.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$If he should offer to choose and choose the right casket, you should refuse to perform your father’s will if you should refuse to accept him.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$If he offers to play the game and chooses the right box, but then you reject him, you’ll be disobeying your father’s last wishes.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Therefore, for fear of the worst, I pray thee, set a deep glass of rhenish wine on the contrary casket, for if the devil be within and that temptation without, I know he will choose it. I will do any thing, Nerissa, ere I’ll be married to a sponge.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I know. So please put a nice big glass of white wine on the wrong box. I know he’ll get tempted and choose that one. I’ll do anything rather than marry a drunk, Nerissa.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You need not fear, lady, the having any of these lords. They have acquainted me with their determinations, which is indeed to return to their home and to trouble you with no more suit unless you may be won by some other sort than your father’s imposition depending on the caskets.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You don’t have to worry about any of these lords, my lady. They’ve all told me what they want, which is to go back home and give up on you—unless there was some other way to win you than your father’s pick-the-box test.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If I live to be as old as Sibylla, I will die as chaste as Diana unless I be obtained by the manner of my father’s will. I am glad this parcel of wooers are so reasonable, for there is not one among them but I dote on his very absence. And I pray God grant them a fair departure.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I’ll die an old maid unless I can be won according to the rules set by my father’s will. I’m glad these suitors are sensible enough to stay away. The only thing I like about them is that they’re not there. I wish them all safe trips home.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Do you not remember, lady, in your father’s time a Venetian, a scholar and a soldier, that came hither in company of the Marquess of Montferrat?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Do you remember a Venetian scholar and soldier who accompanied the marquess of Montferrat here once when your father was still alive?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, it was Bassanio—as I think he was so called.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, yes, that was Bassanio. I think that was his name.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$True, madam. He, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, that’s the one. He deserves a beautiful wife more than all the other men I’ve ever seen.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of thy praise.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I remember him well, and my memory tells me that he deserves your praise.

paragraphs.original: Enter a SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$SERVINGMAN
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: How now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: Hello, do you have any news?

paragraphs.original: SERVINGMAN$NEWLINE$The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave. And there is a forerunner come from a fifth, the Prince of Morocco, who brings word the prince his master will be here tonight.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$The four suitors are looking for you so they can say goodbye, madam. And there’s a messenger representing a fifth one, the prince of Morocco, who says the prince will be here tonight.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If I could bid the fifth welcome with so good a heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach. If he have the condition of a saint and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me. Come, Nerissa.—(to SERVANT) Sirrah, go before. Whiles we shut the gates upon one wooer Another knocks at the door.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If I could say hello to the fifth one as happily as I’ll say goodbye to the first four, I’d be very happy he’s coming. If he’s as good as a saint but is black like a devil, I’d rather he hear my confession than marry me. Let’s go, Nerissa.—(to the SERVANT) Go ahead. As soon as we shut the door on one suitor, another one starts knocking.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BASSANIO and SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO and SHYLOCK enter.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats, well.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats, hmmm.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, for three months.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Yes, for three months.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$For three months, well.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$For three months, hmmm.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$For the which, as I told you, Antonio shall be bound.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$As I said before, Antonio will guarantee the loan. If I default, he’ll pay you.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Antonio shall become bound, well.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Antonio will guarantee it, hmmm.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$May you stead me? Will you pleasure me? Shall I know your answer?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Can you help me? What’s your answer?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio bound.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats for three months, and Antonio will guarantee it.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Your answer to that?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Your answer?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Antonio is a good man.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Antonio’s a good man.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Have you heard any imputation to the contrary?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Have you heard anything to the contrary?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Ho, no, no, no, no. My meaning in saying he is a good man is to have you understand me that he is sufficient. Yet his means are in supposition. He hath an argosy bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies. I understand moreover, upon the Rialto, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures he hath squandered abroad.
paragraphs.translated:
SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What? No, no, no, no. What I meant in saying he’s a good man is that he has enough money to guarantee the loan. But his investments are uncertain right now. He has one ship bound for Tripoli, another heading for the Indies. What’s more, people at the
Rialto tell me he has a third ship in Mexico, and a fourth in England, as well as other business ventures throughout the world.$NEWLINE$Rialto$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But ships are but boards, sailors but men. There be land rats and water rats, water thieves and land thieves—I mean pirates—and then there is the peril of waters, winds, and rocks. The man is notwithstanding sufficient.
paragraphs.translated: But ships are just fragile boards, and sailors are just men. There are rats and thieves and pirates—not to mention storms, winds, and rocks. Anything could happen. But in spite of all this, the man is still wealthy enough. Three thousand ducats—I think I can let him guarantee your loan.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Be assured you may.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I assure you he can.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I will be assured I may, and that I may be assured,$NEWLINE$I will bethink me. May I speak with Antonio?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I will be sure he can, before I make the loan. And I’ll think of a way to be sure. Can I speak with Antonio?$NEWLINE$will

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$If it please you to dine with us.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$If you like, you can dine with us.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Yes—to smell pork, to eat of the habitation which your prophet the Nazarite conjured the devil into. I will buy with you, sell with you, talk with you, walk with you, and so following, but I will not eat with you, drink with you, nor pray with you. What news on the Rialto? Who is he comes here?
paragraphs.translated:
Oh yes—to smell
pork ? I don’t think so!. Your prophet Jesus sent the devil into a herd of pigs. I’m not going to eat that. I’ll buy with you, sell with you, talk with you, walk with you, and so on, but I won’t eat with you, drink with you, or pray with you. Any news on the Rialto? Who’s that?$NEWLINE$pork$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This is Signor Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This is Signor Antonio.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$(aside) How like a fawning publican he looks!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I hate him for he is a Christian,$NEWLINE$But more for that in low simplicity$NEWLINE$He lends out money gratis and brings down$NEWLINE$The rate of usance here with us in Venice.$NEWLINE$If I can catch him once upon the hip,$NEWLINE$I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him.$NEWLINE$He hates our sacred nation, and he rails,$NEWLINE$Even there where merchants most do congregate,$NEWLINE$On me, my bargains and my well-won thrift,
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$(to himself) He looks just like a guy who’s robbed me but now comes to beg me for a favor! I hate him because he’s a Christian. But more than that, I hate him because he stupidly lends money without interest, which lowers the interest rates here in Venice. If I can just get the upper hand of him once, I’ll satisfy my old grudge against him. He hates Jews. Even at the Rialto he’s always complaining about me and my negotiating and my hard-earned profits, which he calls “interest.”$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Which he calls “interest.” Cursèd be my tribe$NEWLINE$If I forgive him!
paragraphs.translated: It would an insult to Jews everywhere to forgive that man!

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Shylock, do you hear?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Shylock, are you listening?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I am debating of my present store,$NEWLINE$And by the near guess of my memory$NEWLINE$I cannot instantly raise up the gross$NEWLINE$Of full three thousand ducats. What of that?$NEWLINE$Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe,$NEWLINE$Will furnish me. But soft! How many months$NEWLINE$Do you desire?$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Rest you fair, good signor.$NEWLINE$Your worship was the last man in our mouths.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’m thinking about how much cash I have on hand. If I remember correctly, I can’t raise the entire three thousand ducats immediately. But so what? Tubal, a wealthy Jew I know, will supply me with the cash. But wait a minute! How many months do you want? (to ANTONIO) Oh, hello, how are you, signor? We were just talking about you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Shylock, albeit I neither lend nor borrow$NEWLINE$By taking nor by giving of excess,$NEWLINE$Yet to supply the ripe wants of my friend,$NEWLINE$I’ll break a custom.$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Is he yet possessed$NEWLINE$How much ye would?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Shylock, although I never lend or borrow with interest, I’m willing to break that habit to help a friend in need. (to BASSANIO) Does he know how much you need?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Oh yes, three thousand ducats.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And for three months.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$For three months.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I had forgot—three months.$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You told me so.$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Well then, your bond, and let me see—But hear you,$NEWLINE$Methought you said you neither lend nor borrow$NEWLINE$Upon advantage.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Yes, I forgot—three months. (to BASSANIO) You told me that. (to ANTONIO) Now then, about your guarantee. Let me see—but listen, Antonio, I thought you said you don’t lend or borrow with interest.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I do never use it.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$That’s right. That’s not how I do business.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$When Jacob grazed his uncle Laban’s sheep—$NEWLINE$This Jacob from our holy Abram was,$NEWLINE$As his wise mother wrought in his behalf,$NEWLINE$The third possessor, ay, he was the third—
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$When Jacob took care of his uncle Laban’s sheep—Jacob was the heir to his grandfather Abraham’s birthright, because his mother cleverly arranged for her husband Isaac to make Jacob his heir—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And what of him? Did he take interest?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$What’s your point? Did he charge interest?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$No, not take interest—not as you would say$NEWLINE$Directly interest. Mark what Jacob did:$NEWLINE$When Laban and himself were compromised$NEWLINE$That all the eanlings which were streaked and pied$NEWLINE$Should fall as Jacob’s hire, the ewes, being rank,$NEWLINE$In the end of autumn turnèd to the rams.$NEWLINE$And when the work of generation was$NEWLINE$Between these woolly breeders in the act,$NEWLINE$The skillful shepherd peeled me certain wands.$NEWLINE$And in the doing of the deed of kind$NEWLINE$He stuck them up before the fulsome ewes,$NEWLINE$Who then conceiving did in eaning time$NEWLINE$Fall parti-colored lambs—and those were Jacob’s.$NEWLINE$This was a way to thrive, and he was blessed.$NEWLINE$And thrift is blessing, if men steal it not.
paragraphs.translated:
SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$No, he didn’t
charge interest—not in your sense of the word. But listen to what Jacob did. When he and Laban agreed that all the spotted lambs would be Jacob’s pay, it was the end of autumn, when the sheep were starting to mate. Because newborns look like whatever their mother sees during mating, he stuck some spotted branches into the ground right in front of the sheep, who saw them while they mated. The mothers later gave birth to spotted lambs, all of which went to Jacob. That was his way of expanding his business, and it worked. My point is that profit is a blessing, as long as you don’t steal to get it.$NEWLINE$charge interest$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$This was a venture, sir, that Jacob served for—$NEWLINE$A thing not in his power to bring to pass$NEWLINE$But swayed and fashioned by the hand of heaven.$NEWLINE$Was this inserted to make interest good?$NEWLINE$Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$That business venture you’re referring to happened because God made it happen like that. Jacob didn’t have any control over what happened. Are you saying this story proves that charging interest makes sense? That your interest payments are like Jacob’s sheep?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I cannot tell: I make it breed as fast.$NEWLINE$But note me, signor—
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I can hardly tell the difference; I make my money multiply as fast as those sheep. But listen to me, signor—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Mark you this, Bassanio,$NEWLINE$The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose.$NEWLINE$An evil soul producing holy witness$NEWLINE$Is like a villain with a smiling cheek,$NEWLINE$A goodly apple rotten at the heart.$NEWLINE$Oh, what a goodly outside falsehood hath!
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Watch out, Bassanio. The devil can quote Scripture for his own use. An evil soul using a holy story is like a criminal who smiles at you. He looks like a good apple but he’s rotten at the core. Oh, liars can look so honest!

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats—’tis a good round sum.$NEWLINE$Three months from twelve, then. Let me see. The rate—
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats. That’s a nice even sum. Three months from twelve months of the year. Let me see. The interest rate will be—

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, Shylock, shall we be beholding to you?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Well, Shylock? Are you going to loan us the money?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Signor Antonio, many a time and oft$NEWLINE$In the Rialto you have rated me$NEWLINE$About my moneys and my usances.$NEWLINE$Still have I borne it with a patient shrug,$NEWLINE$For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe.$NEWLINE$You call me misbeliever, cutthroat dog,$NEWLINE$And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine—$NEWLINE$And all for use of that which is mine own.$NEWLINE$Well then, it now appears you need my help.$NEWLINE$Go to, then! You come to me and you say,$NEWLINE$“Shylock, we would have moneys.” You say so!—$NEWLINE$You, that did void your rheum upon my beard$NEWLINE$And foot me as you spurn a stranger cur$NEWLINE$Over your threshold! Moneys is your suit.$NEWLINE$What should I say to you? Should I not say,$NEWLINE$“Hath a dog money? Is it possible$NEWLINE$A cur can lend three thousand ducats?” Or$NEWLINE$Shall I bend low and in a bondman’s key$NEWLINE$With bated breath and whispering humbleness$NEWLINE$Say this:
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Signor Antonio, you’ve often insulted my money and my business practices in the Rialto. I have always just shrugged and put up with it because Jews are good at suffering. You called me a heathen, a dirty dog, and you spit on my Jewish clothes. And all because I use my own money to make a profit. And now it looks like you need my help. All right then. You come to me saying, “Shylock, we need money.” You say that!—even though you spat on my beard and kicked me like you’d kick a stray mutt out your front door. And now you’re asking for money. What can I tell you? Shouldn’t I say, “Does a dog have money? Is it possible for a mutt to lend three thousand ducats?” Or should I bend down low, and in a humble and submissive voice say:

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “Fair sir, you spet on me on Wednesday last;$NEWLINE$You spurned me such a day; another time$NEWLINE$You called me ’dog'—and for these courtesies$NEWLINE$I’ll lend you thus much moneys?”
paragraphs.translated: “Sir, last Wednesday you spit on me. You insulted me on this day, and another time you called me a dog. And out of gratitude for these favors, I’ll be happy to lend you the money?”

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I am as like to call thee so again,$NEWLINE$To spet on thee again, to spurn thee too.$NEWLINE$If thou wilt lend this money, lend it not$NEWLINE$As to thy friends, for when did friendship take$NEWLINE$A breed for barren metal of his friend?$NEWLINE$But lend it rather to thine enemy,$NEWLINE$Who, if he break, thou mayst with better face$NEWLINE$Exact the penalty.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’ll probably call you those names again and spit on you, and reject you again too. If you’re going to lend us this money, don’t lend it to us as if we were your friends. When did friends charge interest? Instead, lend it to me as your enemy. If your enemy goes bankrupt, it’s easier for you to take your penalty from him.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Why, look you how you storm!$NEWLINE$I would be friends with you and have your love,$NEWLINE$Forget the shames that you have stained me with,$NEWLINE$Supply your present wants and take no doit$NEWLINE$Of usance for my moneys—and you’ll not hear me!$NEWLINE$This is kind I offer.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Look at you getting all riled up! I want to be friends with you, and forget all the times you’ve embarrassed and humiliated me. I want to give you what you need, and not charge a penny of interest—but you won’t listen to me! I’m making a kind offer—zero percent financing.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This were kindness.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$That really would be kind.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$This kindness will I show.$NEWLINE$Go with me to a notary, seal me there$NEWLINE$Your single bond, and—in a merry sport—$NEWLINE$If you repay me not on such a day,$NEWLINE$In such a place, such sum or sums as are$NEWLINE$Expressed in the condition, let the forfeit$NEWLINE$Be nominated for an equal pound$NEWLINE$Of your fair flesh, to be cut off and taken$NEWLINE$In what part of your body pleaseth me.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ll show you how kind I am. Come with me to a notary and we’ll make it official. And let’s add a little clause just for a joke. If you don’t repay me on the day we agree on, in the place we name, for the sum of money fixed in our contract, your penalty will be a pound of your pretty flesh, to be cut off and taken out of whatever part of your body I like.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Content, in faith. I’ll seal to such a bond,$NEWLINE$And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$It’s a deal. I’ll agree to those terms and even say that Jews are nice.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$You shall not seal to such a bond for me!$NEWLINE$I’ll rather dwell in my necessity.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, you can’t sign a contract like that for me! I’d rather go without the money.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Why, fear not, man. I will not forfeit it.$NEWLINE$Within these two months—that’s a month before$NEWLINE$This bond expires—I do expect return$NEWLINE$Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about it, man, I won’t have to pay any penalty. In two months—a month before this loan is due—I expect to earn more than three times that much from my investments.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$O Father Abram, what these Christians are,$NEWLINE$Whose own hard dealings teaches them suspect$NEWLINE$The thoughts of others!—Pray you, tell me this:$NEWLINE$If he should break his day, what should I gain$NEWLINE$By the exaction of the forfeiture?$NEWLINE$A pound of man’s flesh taken from a man$NEWLINE$Is not so estimable, profitable neither,$NEWLINE$As flesh of muttons, beefs, or goats. I say,$NEWLINE$To buy his favor I extend this friendship.$NEWLINE$If he will take it, so. If not, adieu.$NEWLINE$And for my love I pray you wrong me not.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Oh father Abraham, what kind of people are these Christians? Their own meanness teaches them to suspect other people!—Please tell me this. If he fails to repay me by the deadline, what would I get out of such a penalty? A pound of human flesh taken isn’t even as valuable as a pound of mutton or beef. I’m just offering this as a favor to a friend. If he agrees, great. If not, goodbye. And I hope you won’t think badly of me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, Shylock, I will seal unto this bond.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, Shylock, I’ll sign the contract and agree to its terms.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Then meet me forthwith at the notary’s.$NEWLINE$Give him direction for this merry bond,$NEWLINE$And I will go and purse the ducats straight,$NEWLINE$See to my house left in the fearful guard$NEWLINE$Of an unthrifty knave, and presently$NEWLINE$I will be with you.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Then meet me right away at the notary’s. Give him the instructions for our amusing little contract, and I’ll go get the money for you right away. I need to check in at home first, because one of my careless servants is in charge right now. I’ll see you soon.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hie thee, gentle Jew.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hurry up, my Jewish friend.

paragraphs.original: Exit SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK exits.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: The Hebrew will turn Christian. He grows kind.
paragraphs.translated: He’s so kind you’d think the Jew is turning Christian.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I like not fair terms and a villain’s mind.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I don’t like it when a villain acts nice.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Come on. In this there can be no dismay.$NEWLINE$My ships come home a month before the day.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Come on, there’s no reason to worry. My ships will come home a month before the money is due.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish cornets Enter the Prince of MOROCCO, a tawny Moor all in white, and three or four followers accordingly, with PORTIA, NERISSA, and their train$NEWLINE$MOROCCO$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated:
Trumpets play. The prince of
MOROCCO , a brown-skinned man dressed in all white, enters, followed by three or four servants dressed in costumes like his. PORTIA, NERISSA, and their ATTENDANTS enter.$NEWLINE$MOROCCO$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA$NEWLINE$ATTENDANTS

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Mislike me not for my complexion,$NEWLINE$The shadowed livery of the burnished sun,$NEWLINE$To whom I am a neighbor and near bred.$NEWLINE$Bring me the fairest creature northward born,$NEWLINE$Where Phoebus' fire scarce thaws the icicles,$NEWLINE$And let us make incision for your love$NEWLINE$To prove whose blood is reddest, his or mine.$NEWLINE$I tell thee, lady, this aspect of mine$NEWLINE$Hath feared the valiant. By my love I swear$NEWLINE$The best-regarded virgins of our clime$NEWLINE$Have loved it too. I would not change this hue$NEWLINE$Except to steal your thoughts, my gentle queen.
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Don’t hold my skin color against me. I was born and raised in the sun, which is why I’m dark-skinned. But I’m as red-blooded as any man. Show me the best-looking person born in the freezing north, where the sun barely thaws the icicles. I’ll win your love by cutting myself to prove to you I have redder blood than he does. I’m telling you, madam, my skin color has made brave men fear me and Moroccan girls love me. I wouldn’t change it except to make you think of me, my darling queen.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$In terms of choice I am not solely led$NEWLINE$By nice direction of a maiden’s eyes.$NEWLINE$Besides, the lottery of my destiny$NEWLINE$Bars me the right of voluntary choosing.$NEWLINE$But if my father had not scanted me$NEWLINE$And hedged me by his wit to yield myself$NEWLINE$His wife who wins me by that means I told you,$NEWLINE$Yourself, renownèd Prince, then stood as fair$NEWLINE$As any comer I have looked on yet$NEWLINE$For my affection.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Being good-looking isn’t the only way to my heart, you know. I have other criteria for choosing a husband. Not that it matters, because the box test takes away my free choice anyway. But if my father hadn’t restricted me like this—forcing me to marry whoever wins his test—then you’d have had as good a chance to marry me as any of the suitors I’ve met so far, prince.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Even for that I thank you.$NEWLINE$Therefore I pray you lead me to the caskets$NEWLINE$To try my fortune. By this scimitar$NEWLINE$That slew the Sophy and a Persian prince$NEWLINE$That won three fields of Sultan Solyman,$NEWLINE$I would o'erstare the sternest eyes that look,$NEWLINE$Outbrave the heart most daring on the earth,$NEWLINE$Pluck the young sucking cubs from the she-bear,$NEWLINE$Yea, mock the lion when he roars for prey,$NEWLINE$To win the lady. But, alas the while!$NEWLINE$If Hercules and Lychas play at dice$NEWLINE$Which is the better man, the greater throw$NEWLINE$May turn by fortune from the weaker hand.$NEWLINE$So is Alcides beaten by his page,$NEWLINE$And so may I, blind fortune leading me,$NEWLINE$Miss that which one unworthier may attain$NEWLINE$And die with grieving.
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Thank you for saying that. Show me the caskets and let me try my luck. I swear by my sword, which killed the Shah of Persia and a Persian prince and defeated the Sultan Suleiman three times, that I would face the meanest-looking warriors on earth. I would act braver than the bravest man on earth. I would grab bear cubs from a ferocious mother bear, or tease a hungry lion—all of this in order to win your love, lady. But this is bad! If the hero Hercules and his servant Lychas rolled the dice, which would win? Not the greater hero. Just the one who happened to be luckier that time. And just as Hercules could be beaten by his servant, blind luck could make me lose this test and make someone worse than me win. If that happened, I’d die of sadness.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You must take your chance,$NEWLINE$And either not attempt to choose at all$NEWLINE$Or swear before you choose, if you choose wrong$NEWLINE$Never to speak to lady afterward$NEWLINE$In way of marriage. Therefore be advised.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You have to take your chances. Either don’t choose at all, or swear beforehand that if you choose incorrectly you’ll never talk about marriage to any woman again. Think about it carefully.

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Nor will not. Come, bring me unto my chance.
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Fine, I swear I won’t ever get married if I choose incorrectly. Let me take my chances.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$First, forward to the temple. After dinner$NEWLINE$Your hazard shall be made.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Let’s go to the temple first. You can take your chances after dinner.

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Good fortune then!—$NEWLINE$To make me blessed or cursed’st among men.
paragraphs.translated: I’ll try my luck then. I’ll either be the luckiest or the unluckiest man alive.

paragraphs.original: Cornets
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LAUNCELOT the clown, alone$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT enters alone.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Certainly my conscience will serve me to run from this Jew, my master. The fiend is at mine elbow and tempts me, saying to me, “Gobbo,” “Launcelot Gobbo,” “Good Launcelot,” or “Good Gobbo,” or “Good Launcelot Gobbo” —“use your legs, take the start, run away.” My conscience says, “No. Take heed, honest Launcelot. Take heed, honest Gobbo,” or as aforesaid, “Honest Launcelot Gobbo, do not run. Scorn running with thy heels.” Well, the most courageous fiend bids me pack. “Fia!” says the fiend. “Away!” says the fiend. “For the heavens, rouse up a brave mind,” says the fiend, “and run.” Well, my conscience, hanging about the neck of my heart, says very wisely to me, “My honest friend Launcelot, being an honest man’s son”—or rather an honest woman’s son, for indeed my father did something smack, something grow to. He had a kind of taste.—Well, my conscience says, “Launcelot, budge not.” “Budge!” says the fiend. “Budge not,” says my conscience. “Conscience,” say I, “you counsel well.” “Fiend,” say I, “you counsel well.” To be ruled by my conscience I should stay with the Jew my master, who, God bless the mark, is a kind of devil. And to run away from the Jew I should be ruled by the fiend, who, saving your reverence, is the devil himself. Certainly the Jew is the very devil incarnation. And in my conscience, my conscience is but a kind of hard conscience, to offer to counsel me to stay with the Jew. The fiend gives the more friendly counsel. I will run, fiend. My heels are at your command. I will run.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I’m sure I’ll feel guilty if I run away from this Jew, my master. The devil’s on my shoulder, tempting me. He’s saying, “Gobbo,” “Launcelot Gobbo,” “Good Launcelot,” or “Good Gobbo,” or “Good Launcelot Gobbo”—“use your legs and run away.” But my conscience says, “No, Launcelot, calm down, don’t run away.” The devil’s urging me to leave. “Go away!” he says. “Run away! Be tough,” says the devil, “and run!” But then my conscience, hanging around my heart, says very wisely to me, “My good friend Launcelot, you’re a good boy, the son of an honest man,” really, that should be the son of an honest woman, since my father cheated on my mother. Anyway, my conscience says, “Stay put.” “Go,” the devil says. “Don’t go,” says my conscience. “Conscience,” I say, “you give good advice.” “Devil,” I say, “you give good advice.” If I listened to my conscience, I’d stay with the Jew my master, who’s a devil. But if I ran away from the Jew, I’d be following the advice of the devil, who’s the very devil himself. Certainly the Jew is the devil incarnate, and my conscience is giving me a hard time by telling me to stay with the Jew. The devil’s advice is nicer. I’ll run, devil. Tell me to run, and I’ll run.

paragraphs.original: Enter Old GOBBO with a basket
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO enters with a basket.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to$NEWLINE$Master Jew’s?
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Excuse me, young man, how do I get to the Jew’s residence?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(aside) O heavens, this is my true-begotten father, who, being more than sand-blind—high-gravel blind—knows me not. I will try confusions with him.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(to himself) Good heavens, it’s my father. He doesn’t recognize me because he’s half-blind—or more than half-blind, somewhere between half-blind and totally blind. I’ll play a little game with him.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to$NEWLINE$Master Jew’s?
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Young man, excuse me, how do I get to the Jew’s?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all on your left. Marry, at the very next turning turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Turn right at the next turn, but at the following turn, turn left. Oh, and then at the very next turn, don’t turn left or right, but turn down and around to the Jew’s house.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$By God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell me whether one Launcelot that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Good heavens, those are difficult directions. Can you tell me if a man named Launcelot, who lives with him, is still there?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Talk you of young Master Launcelot? (aside) Mark me now. Now will I raise the waters.—Talk you of young Master Launcelot?$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Are you talking about young Master Launcelot? (speaking so no one else can hear) Watch out, I’m going to pull a good prank here.—Is that who you’re talking about?$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$No “master,” sir, but a poor man’s son. His father, though I say ’t, is an honest exceeding poor man and, God be thanked, well to live.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$He’s not a “master,” sir, he’s just a poor man’s son. His father, if I do say so myself, is an honest but very poor man, and, thank God, likely to live a long time.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Well, let his father be what he will, we talk of young$NEWLINE$Master Launcelot.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Well, his father can be whatever he wants to be. We’re talking about young Master Launcelot.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Your worship’s friend and Launcelot, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Please don’t call him that, sir. He’s just Launcelot.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$But I pray you, ergo, old man, ergo, I beseech you, talk you of young Master Launcelot?
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$But excuse me, ergo, old man, ergo, I’m asking you if you’re talking about young Master Launcelot.$NEWLINE$ergo$NEWLINE$ergo

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Of Launcelot, an ’t please your mastership.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Yes, I’m talking about Launcelot, sir.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Ergo, Master Launcelot. Talk not of Master Launcelot, Father, for the young gentleman, according to Fates and Destinies and such odd sayings, the Sisters Three and such branches of learning, is indeed deceased, or as you would say in plain terms, gone to heaven.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Ergo , Master Launcelot. But please don’t talk about Master Launcelot, old man. The young gentleman, submitting to the fates, the three sisters who control destiny, and other branches of learning like that, is deceased. Or, to put it in plain language, he’s gone to heaven.$NEWLINE$Ergo$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Marry, God forbid! The boy was the very staff of my age, my very prop.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Oh, no. God forbid! The boy was going to support me in my old age!

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff or a prop?$NEWLINE$Do you know me, Father?
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$What am I, a cane? How could I support anyone? Don’t you recognize me, father?

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman. But I pray you, tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Heaven help me, I don’t know you, sir. But please tell me, is my boy—God rest his soul—alive or dead?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Do you not know me, Father?
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$You really don’t recognize me, father?

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Alack, sir, I am sand-blind. I know you not.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Sir, I’m half-blind. I don’t know you.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Nay, indeed if you had your eyes, you might fail of the knowing me. It is a wise father that knows his own child. Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son. Give me your blessing. Truth will come to light. Murder cannot be hid long—a man’s son may, but in the end truth will out.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Even if you had your eyes, you still might not recognize me. It takes a wise father to know his own child. Well, old man, I’ll tell you news of your son. Give me your blessing. The truth will come to light, and murder can’t be hidden long—a man’s son may hide, but truth will always come out.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Pray you, sir, stand up. I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Please stand up! I’m sure you aren’t Launcelot, my boy.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Pray you, let’s have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing. I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Come on, quit fooling around. Give me your blessing. I’m Launcelot, who was your boy, is your son, and will be your child.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$I cannot think you are my son.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$I can’t believe you’re my son.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I know not what I shall think of that. But I am Launcelot, the Jew’s man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I don’t know what to say to that, but the fact is I’m Launcelot, the Jew’s servant, and Margery, your wife, is my mother.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Her name is Margery, indeed. I’ll be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood. (feels the back of LAUNCELOT’s head) Lord worshipped might he be, what a beard hast thou got! Thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.$NEWLINE$(feels the$NEWLINE$back of$NEWLINE$’s head)
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Yes, you’re right, her name is Margery. If you’re Launcelot, then you’re my own flesh and blood. (feels the back of LAUNCELOT’s head) My Lord, what a bushy beard you have! You’ve got more hair on your chin than Dobbin my horse has in his tail.$NEWLINE$(feels the back of$NEWLINE$’s head)

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward. I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Then Dobbin’s tail must be growing backward. I’m sure he had more hair on his tail than I have on my face when I last saw him.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Lord, how art thou changed! How dost thou and thy master agree? I have brought him a present. How 'gree you now?
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Lord, how you’ve changed! How are you and your master getting along? I’ve brought him a present. How are you?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Well, well, but for mine own part, as I have set up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have run some ground. My master’s a very Jew. Give him a present. Give him a halter. I am famished in his service. You may tell every finger I have with my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come. Give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I’m all right. But I’ve decided to run away, and I can’t wait to get going. My master’s a total Jew. You’re giving him a present? Give him a noose to hang himself. He’s starving me to death. You can see my ribs so well you can count them. I’m glad you’ve come, father. Give me your present to give to Master Bassanio. He gives his servants beautiful new uniforms.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If I serve not him, I will run as far as God has any ground.—O rare fortune! Here comes the man.—To him, Father, for I am a Jew if I serve the Jew any longer.
paragraphs.translated:
If I can’t get a job with him, I’ll run away to the ends of the earth.—Oh look, this is lucky, here comes Master Bassanio now.—Let’s go talk to him, Father. If I work for the
Jew any longer, you can just call me a Jew.$NEWLINE$Jew$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter BASSANIO with LEONARDO and another follower or two$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$LEONARDO
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO enters with LEONARDO and an attendant or two.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$LEONARDO

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to a follower) You may do so, but let it be so hasted that supper be ready at the farthest by five of the clock. See these letters delivered, put the liveries to making, and desire Gratiano to come anon to my lodging.$NEWLINE$(to a follower)
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to an attendant) All right, go ahead. But do everything quickly. Supper must be ready at five at the latest. Make sure these letters get delivered, get the uniforms made, and tell Gratiano to come visit me soon.$NEWLINE$(to an attendant)

paragraphs.original: Exit follower
paragraphs.translated: The attendant exits.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To him, Father.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Go talk to him, father.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) God bless your worship!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) God bless you, sir!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Gramercy! Wouldst thou aught with me?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Thank you. What do you want with me?

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$Here’s my son, sir, a poor boy—
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$This is my son, sir. He’s a poor boy—

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew’s man that would, sir, as my father shall specify—
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Not a poor boy, but the rich Jew’s servant, who wants, as my father will explain—

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve—
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$He wants very much, sir, as one might say, to work for—

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew and have a desire, as my father shall specify—
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To put it briefly, I work for the Jew, and I want, as my father will tell you—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$His master and he, saving your worship’s reverence, are scarce cater-cousins—
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$He and his master aren’t exactly friends—

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being, I hope, an old man, shall frutify unto you—
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To be brief, the truth is that the Jew has done me wrong, and that forces me to—as my father, an old man, will inform you—

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon your worship, and my suit is—
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$I have a present I’d like to give you, sir. And I want to request that—

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your worship shall know by this honest old man—and though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father—
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To make a long story short, the request is about me, as this good old man will tell you. Even though I’m his son and I’m the one saying it, this old man is a poor man—

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$One speak for both. What would you?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$One of you do the talking. What do you want?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Serve you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To work for you, sir.

paragraphs.original: GOBBO$NEWLINE$That is the very defect of the matter, sir.
paragraphs.translated: GOBBO$NEWLINE$That’s what we’re trying to say, sir.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I know thee well. Thou hast obtained thy suit.$NEWLINE$Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,$NEWLINE$And hath preferred thee, if it be preferment$NEWLINE$To leave a rich Jew’s service, to become$NEWLINE$The follower of so poor a gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I know who you are. You can have what you want. I spoke with your master Shylock today, and he recommended you to me. If you want to leave a rich Jew to work for a poor gentleman, you’re welcome to.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir—you have “the grace of God,” sir, and he hath “enough.”
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Do you know the old proverb “The grace of God is enough,” sir? It could be divided between you and my boss Shylock—you have “the grace of God,” and he has “enough.”

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Thou speak’st it well.—Go, father, with thy son.—$NEWLINE$Take leave of thy old master and inquire$NEWLINE$My lodging out.—$NEWLINE$(to followers)$NEWLINE$(to followers)$NEWLINE$Give him a livery$NEWLINE$More guarded than his fellows'. See it done.
