paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Nicely put.—Go with your son, old man.—Say goodbye to your old master and find your way to my house. (to attendants) Give him a uniform that’s a little nicer than the others. Make sure it gets done.$NEWLINE$(to attendants)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Father, in. I cannot get a service, no. I have ne'er a tongue in my head. (reading his own palm) Well, if any man in Italy have a fairer table which doth offer to swear upon a book, I shall have good fortune. Go to, here’s a simple line of life. Here’s a small trifle of wives. Alas, fifteen wives is nothing! Eleven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man. And then to ’scape drowning thrice and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a feather-bed—here are simple ’scapes. Well, if Fortune be a woman, she’s a good wench for this gear.—Father, come. I’ll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling.$NEWLINE$(reading his own palm)
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Father, go ahead. I can’t get a job, can I? I can’t talk well, no. (reading his own palm) If any man in Italy has a palm good enough to swear on a Bible with, it’s me. I’ve got very good luck! Here’s my life line. It shows a few wives—fifteen wives is nothing. Eleven widows and nine maids is a humble beginning for one man. It seems I’ll almost drown three times, and my life will be in danger when I’m caught in bed with another man’s wife! But these little lines are the escape routes I can take to get out of that one. If luck’s a lady, she’s good at this business. Father, let’s go. I’ll leave the Jew behind in the blink of an eye.$NEWLINE$(reading his own palm)

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT the clown with Old GOBBO$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$GOBBO
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT and GOBBO exit.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$GOBBO

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, good Leonardo, think on this.$NEWLINE$These things being bought and orderly bestowed,$NEWLINE$Return in haste, for I do feast tonight$NEWLINE$My best esteemed acquaintance. Hie thee, go.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Please, Leonardo, think about this (he hands him a piece of paper). These things have been bought and are ready. Hurry back here. I’m having dinner tonight with someone I greatly respect. Go now.$NEWLINE$(he hands him a piece of paper).

paragraphs.original: LEONARDO$NEWLINE$My best endeavours shall be done herein.
paragraphs.translated: LEONARDO$NEWLINE$I’ll do my best.

paragraphs.original: Enter GRATIANO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO enters.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to LEONARDO) Where is your master?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to LEONARDO) Where’s your master?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LEONARDO$NEWLINE$Yonder, sir, he walks.
paragraphs.translated: LEONARDO$NEWLINE$He’s walking over there, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit LEONARDO$NEWLINE$LEONARDO
paragraphs.translated: LEONARDO exits.$NEWLINE$LEONARDO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Signor Bassanio!
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Signor Bassanio!

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Gratiano!
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Gratiano!

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I have a suit to you.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I have a favor to ask.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$You have obtained it.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Anything.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$You must not deny me. I must go with you to Belmont.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Don’t say no. Let me go with you to Belmont.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Why, then you must. But hear thee, Gratiano.$NEWLINE$Thou art too wild, too rude and bold of voice—$NEWLINE$Parts that become thee happily enough$NEWLINE$And in such eyes as ours appear not faults.$NEWLINE$But where thou art not known, why, there they show$NEWLINE$Something too liberal. Pray thee, take pain$NEWLINE$To allay with some cold drops of modesty$NEWLINE$Thy skipping spirit, lest through thy wild behavior$NEWLINE$I be misconst’red in the place I go to,$NEWLINE$And lose my hopes.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Well, if you have to go, you have to go. But listen to me, Gratiano. Sometimes you get a bit too wild, and you let your voice get a bit loud and rude. These things look good on you, of course, and to people like you and me there’s nothing wrong with it. But in places where people don’t know you, your behavior might seem too wild. Please, try to act a little more serious, or the people in Belmont will get the wrong impression about me, and your wildness will make me blow my chance with Portia.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Signor Bassanio, hear me.$NEWLINE$If I do not put on a sober habit,$NEWLINE$Talk with respect and swear but now and then,$NEWLINE$Wear prayer books in my pocket, look demurely—$NEWLINE$Nay more. While grace is saying, hood mine eyes$NEWLINE$Thus with my hat, and sigh and say, “Amen”—$NEWLINE$Use all the observance of civility$NEWLINE$Like one well studied in a sad ostent$NEWLINE$To please his grandam, never trust me more.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Listen, Signor Bassanio, there’s nothing to worry about. I’ll be solemn-looking, I’ll talk with respect, and I’ll only swear once in a while. I’ll carry prayer books in my pocket and look sweet—even more. While grace is being said, I’ll be modest and say “amen”—I’ll watch my manners as if I’m trying to please my grandma. If I don’t do all this, never trust me again.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Well, we shall see your bearing.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Well, we’ll see how you act.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Nay, but I bar tonight. You shall not gauge me$NEWLINE$By what we do tonight.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Okay, but tonight doesn’t count. You can’t judge me based on what I do tonight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, that were pity.$NEWLINE$I would entreat you rather to put on$NEWLINE$Your boldest suit of mirth, for we have friends$NEWLINE$That purpose merriment. But fare you well.$NEWLINE$I have some business.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, it’d be a shame for you to act serious tonight. I’d rather see you having fun, because we have friends coming who want to have fun. Anyway, I have to say goodbye to you now. I’ve got some business to take care of.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$And I must to Lorenzo and the rest.$NEWLINE$But we will visit you at supper time.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I have to join Lorenzo and the others, but we’ll visit you at supper time.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter JESSICA and LAUNCELOT the clown$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA and LAUNCELOT enter.$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.$NEWLINE$Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil,$NEWLINE$Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.$NEWLINE$But fare thee well, there is a ducat for thee.$NEWLINE$And Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see$NEWLINE$Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.$NEWLINE$Give him this letter.$NEWLINE$(gives LAUNCELOT a letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a letter)$NEWLINE$Do it secretly.$NEWLINE$And so farewell. I would not have my father$NEWLINE$See me in talk with thee.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’m sorry you’re leaving my father like this. It’s hell in our house, and you helped cheer it up, like a funny devil. But goodbye. Here’s a ducat for you. You’ll soon be meeting Lorenzo at supper; he’ll be a guest of your new master. Give him this letter. (gives LAUNCELOT a letter) Do it secretly. Goodbye. I don’t want my father to see me talking to you.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Adieu! Tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful pagan, most sweet Jew! If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceived. But adieu. These foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Goodbye. My tears show you my feelings, my beautiful pagan, my sweet Jew! I’m sure some Christian will resort to trickery to get you. But goodbye. It’s not manly to cry. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Farewell, good Launcelot.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Goodbye, Launcelot.

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT exits.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: Alack, what heinous sin is it in me$NEWLINE$To be ashamed to be my father’s child!$NEWLINE$But though I am a daughter to his blood,$NEWLINE$I am not to his manners. O Lorenzo,$NEWLINE$If thou keep promise, I shall end this strife,$NEWLINE$Become a Christian and thy loving wife.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, what a heinous sinner I am, being ashamed to be my father’s child! But I need to remember I’m related to him by blood, not behavior. Oh Lorenzo, if you keep your promise to me, I’ll end this agony by becoming a Christian and marrying you.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GRATIANO, LORENZO, SALARINO, and SOLANIO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO, LORENZO, SALARINO, and SOLANIO enter.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Nay, we will slink away in supper time,$NEWLINE$Disguise us at my lodging, and return,$NEWLINE$All in an hour.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$No, we’ll sneak away at supper time, disguise ourselves with masks at my house, and come back in an hour.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$We have not made good preparation.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$But we haven’t made any preparations.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$We have not spoke us yet of torchbearers.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$We haven’t even talked about who’ll be our torchbearers.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$'Tis vile, unless it may be quaintly ordered,$NEWLINE$And better in my mind not undertook.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$The masquerade party might turn out terribly if we don’t manage things carefully. I think it’s better to call it off.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$'Tis now but four o'clock. We have two hours$NEWLINE$To furnish us.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$It’s only four o'clock now. We have two hours to get ready.

paragraphs.original: Enter LAUNCELOT with a letter$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT enters with a letter.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?
paragraphs.translated: Launcelot, what’s going on?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(giving LORENZO the letter)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$the letter)$NEWLINE$An it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem to signify.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(he gives LORENZO the letter) If you don’t mind opening this letter, you can find out for yourself.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$the letter)

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I know the hand. In faith, ’tis a fair hand,$NEWLINE$And whiter than the paper it writ on$NEWLINE$Is the fair hand that writ.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I recognize the handwriting. It’s beautiful handwriting. And the beautiful hand that wrote this letter is whiter than the paper it’s written on.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Love news, in faith?
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I bet it’s a love letter!

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(to LORENZO) By your leave, sir.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$(to LORENZO) May I be excused, sir?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Whither goest thou?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$To invite my former boss, the Jew, to dine tonight with my new master, the Christian.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$(giving LAUNCELOT money)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$money)$NEWLINE$Hold here, take this. Tell gentle Jessica$NEWLINE$I will not fail her. Speak it privately.—$NEWLINE$Go, gentlemen,$NEWLINE$Will you prepare you for this masque tonight?$NEWLINE$I am provided of a torchbearer.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$(he gives LAUNCELOT money) Hold on, take this. Tell Jessica I won’t fail her. Tell her in private.—Go, gentlemen, get ready for the masquerade tonight. I have someone who can be my torchbearer.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$money)

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT the clown$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT exits.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Ay, marry, I’ll be gone about it straight.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$All right, I’ll go get things ready.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$And so will I.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Me too.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Meet me and Gratiano$NEWLINE$At Gratiano’s lodging some hour hence.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Meet me and Gratiano at his house in about an hour.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$'Tis good we do so.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$It’s good we’re doing this.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SALARINO and SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO and SOLANIO exit.$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Was not that letter from fair Jessica?
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Wasn’t that letter from Jessica?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I must needs tell thee all. She hath directed$NEWLINE$How I shall take her from her father’s house,$NEWLINE$What gold and jewels she is furnished with,$NEWLINE$What page’s suit she hath in readiness.$NEWLINE$If e'er the Jew her father come to heaven,$NEWLINE$It will be for his gentle daughter’s sake.$NEWLINE$And never dare Misfortune cross her foot$NEWLINE$Unless she do it under this excuse:$NEWLINE$That she is issue to a faithless Jew.$NEWLINE$Come, go with me.$NEWLINE$(gives GRATIANO the letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$the letter)$NEWLINE$Peruse this as thou goest.$NEWLINE$Fair Jessica shall be my torchbearer.
paragraphs.translated:
LORENZO$NEWLINE$I have to tell you everything. She’s told me how I can get her out of her father’s house. She’s also told me what gold and jewels she owns, and she’s described the
page’s uniform she’s keeping to wear as a disguise. If her father ever goes to heaven, it’ll be because his daughter’s so good. She’ll never be punished with bad luck—unless it’s because her father is an unbelieving Jew. Come with me. (gives GRATIANO the letter) You can look this letter over as you go. Beautiful Jessica will be my torchbearer.$NEWLINE$page’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$the letter)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SHYLOCK the Jew and his man LAUNCELOT that was the clown$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK and LAUNCELOT enter$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Well, thou shalt see, thy eyes shall be thy judge,$NEWLINE$The difference of old Shylock and Bassanio.—$NEWLINE$What, Jessica!—Thou shalt not gormandize$NEWLINE$As thou hast done with me.—What, Jessica!—$NEWLINE$And sleep and snore, and rend apparel out—$NEWLINE$Why, Jessica, I say!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Well, you’ll see it with your own eyes. You’ll see the difference between working for Shylock and working for Bassanio.—(calling for his daughter) Jessica!—You won’t eat like a pig like you used to do at my place.—Jessica!—And sleep, and snore, and wear your clothes out.—Jessica, I’m calling you!$NEWLINE$(calling for his daughter)

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Why, Jessica!
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Jessica!

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Who bids thee call? I do not bid thee call.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Who asked you to call her? I’m not asking you to call her.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Your worship was wont to tell me that I could do nothing without bidding.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$You always loved to tell me I couldn’t do anything without being told.

paragraphs.original: Enter JESSICA$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA enters.$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Call you? What is your will?
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Did you call me? Do you need something?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.$NEWLINE$There are my keys.—But wherefore should I go?$NEWLINE$I am not bid for love. They flatter me.$NEWLINE$But yet I’ll go in hate to feed upon$NEWLINE$The prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl,$NEWLINE$Look to my house. I am right loath to go.$NEWLINE$There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest,$NEWLINE$For I did dream of money bags tonight.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ve been invited to supper, Jessica. Here are my keys.—But why should I go? I wasn’t invited because they like me. They’re just flattering me. But I’ll go out of spite, to feed off the wasteful Christian.—Jessica, my girl, watch the house. I don’t feel like going. Things aren’t going my way right now. I know because I dreamed of money bags last night.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I beseech you, sir, go. My young master doth expect your reproach.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Please go, sir. My new master is expecting your approach.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$So do I his.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$And I’m expecting his reproach.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$And they have conspired together. I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six o'clock i' th' morning falling out that year on Ash Wednesday was four year in th' afternoon.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$And they’ve been plotting things together. I’m not saying you’ll get a masquerade party, but if you do, I predicted it. I knew there would be a masquerade when I got that bad omen of a bloody nose last Easter Monday, at six in the morning, four years after I got the same kind of bloody nose on Ash Wednesday, in the afternoon.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, are there masques? Hear you me, Jessica.$NEWLINE$Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum$NEWLINE$And the vile squealing of the wry-necked fife,$NEWLINE$Clamber not you up to the casements then,$NEWLINE$Nor thrust your head into the public street$NEWLINE$To gaze on Christian fools with varnished faces.$NEWLINE$But stop my house’s ears—I mean my casements—$NEWLINE$Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter$NEWLINE$My sober house. By Jacob’s staff, I swear,$NEWLINE$I have no mind of feasting forth tonight.$NEWLINE$But I will go.—Go you before me, sirrah.$NEWLINE$Say I will come.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, there’s going to be a masquerade? Listen to me, Jessica, lock my doors up, and when you hear the drum and the nasty squealing of the flute, don’t climb up to the windows. Don’t stick your head out into the public street to stare at the Christian fools with painted faces. Block up my house’s ears—I mean the windows. Don’t let the noise of shallow fools enter my serious house. I swear, I’m in no mood to go out to dinner tonight, but I’ll go anyway.—Launcelot, go tell them I’ll come.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I will go before, sir.—$NEWLINE$Mistress, look out at window, for all this.$NEWLINE$There will come a Christian by$NEWLINE$Will be worth a Jewess' eye.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$I’ll go ahead of you, sir. (to JESSICA) Mistress, be on the lookout when you’re staring out the window. A Christian’s coming who’ll be worth a Jewess’s glance.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT exits.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What says that fool of Hagar’s offspring, ha?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What did that gentile fool say to you, hmmm?

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$His words were, “Farewell, mistress.” Nothing else.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$He said “Goodbye, madam,” and nothing else.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$The patch is kind enough, but a huge feeder,$NEWLINE$Snail-slow in profit, and he sleeps by day$NEWLINE$More than the wildcat. Drones hive not with me.$NEWLINE$Therefore I part with him, and part with him$NEWLINE$To one that would have him help to waste$NEWLINE$His borrowed purse. Well, Jessica, go in.$NEWLINE$Perhaps I will return immediately.$NEWLINE$Do as I bid you. Shut doors after you.$NEWLINE$Fast bind, fast find.$NEWLINE$A proverb never stale in thrifty mind.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$The fool’s nice enough, but he’s such a huge eater, and slow as a snail when he works. He sleeps all day like a cat. Bees that don’t work can’t stay in my hive, so I’m letting him go, handing him off so he can waste money for his new boss, the man who borrowed money from me. Anyway, Jessica, go inside. I might come back soon. Do as I told you. Shut the doors after you. As the saying goes, lock things up, and you’ll get to keep them.

paragraphs.original: Exit SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Farewell, and if my fortune be not crost,$NEWLINE$I have a father, you a daughter, lost.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Goodbye. If luck’s with me, I’ll lose a father, and you’ll lose a daughter.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the masquers GRATIANO and SALARINO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$SALARINO
paragraphs.translated: RATIANO and SALARINO enter, dressed for the masquerade ball.$NEWLINE$RATIANO$NEWLINE$SALARINO

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo$NEWLINE$Desired us to make stand.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$This is the roof under which Lorenzo said to meet him.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$His hour is almost past.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$He’s late.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$And it is marvel he outdwells his hour,$NEWLINE$For lovers ever run before the clock.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Yes, and that’s surprising, because lovers are usually early.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Oh, ten times faster Venus' pigeons fly$NEWLINE$To seal love’s bonds new made than they are wont$NEWLINE$To keep obligèd faith unforfeited.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Yes, for new lovers time passes ten times faster than for couples who’ve been married forever.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$That ever holds. Who riseth from a feast$NEWLINE$With that keen appetite that he sits down?$NEWLINE$Where is the horse that doth untread again$NEWLINE$His tedious measures with the unbated fire$NEWLINE$That he did pace them first? All things that are,$NEWLINE$Are with more spirit chasèd than enjoyed.$NEWLINE$How like a younger or a prodigal$NEWLINE$The scarfèd bark puts from her native bay,$NEWLINE$Hugged and embraèd by the strumpet wind!$NEWLINE$How like the prodigal doth she return,$NEWLINE$With overweathered ribs and ragged sails$NEWLINE$Lean, rent, and beggared by the strumpet wind!
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$That’s always true. Who gets up from a meal with the same appetite he had when he sat down? Can any horse retrace his footsteps with the same energy he had when he walked them the first time? We chase everything in life more excitedly than we actually enjoy it when we get it. It’s like when a ship sails out of the harbor with all its flags waving, gently pushed by the wind. When that ship returns, her timber is all weather-beaten and her sails are ragged. That same wind makes the ship thin and poor.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Here comes Lorenzo. More of this hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Here comes Lorenzo. We’ll talk about this later.

paragraphs.original: Enter LORENZO$NEWLINE$LORENZO
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO enters.$NEWLINE$LORENZO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Sweet friends, your patience for my long abode.$NEWLINE$Not I but my affairs have made you wait.$NEWLINE$When you shall please to play the thieves for wives,$NEWLINE$I’ll watch as long for you then. Approach.$NEWLINE$Here dwells my father Jew.—Ho! Who’s within?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$My dear friends, thanks for your patience. I had business that made me late. When you have to steal your own wives some day, I’ll wait for you just as long. Come over here. My future father-in-law, the Jew, lives here.—Hey! Who’s in there?

paragraphs.original: Enter JESSICA above, disguised as a boy$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA appears above, disguised as a boy.$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Who are you? Tell me for more certainty,$NEWLINE$Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Who are you? Tell me so I can be sure, though I swear I recognize your voice.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Lorenzo, and thy love.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I’m Lorenzo, your love.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Lorenzo certain, and my love indeed—$NEWLINE$For who love I so much? And now who knows$NEWLINE$But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Lorenzo, that’s for sure, and I’m also sure you’re my love—who else do I love so much? And now who but you knows whether I’m yours?

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$As God is my witness, you know you’re mine.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Here, catch this casket. It is worth the pains.$NEWLINE$I am glad ’tis night, you do not look on me,$NEWLINE$For I am much ashamed of my exchange.$NEWLINE$But love is blind, and lovers cannot see$NEWLINE$The pretty follies that themselves commit,$NEWLINE$For if they could Cupid himself would blush$NEWLINE$To see me thus transformèd to a boy.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Here, catch this box. It’ll be worth your while. I’m glad it’s nighttime and you can’t see me. I’m ashamed of my disguise. But love is blind, and lovers can’t see the silly things they do around each other. If they could, Cupid himself would be embarassed to see me dressed up as a boy.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Come down here. You have to be my torchbearer for the masquerade.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$What, must I hold a candle to my shames?$NEWLINE$They in themselves, good sooth, are too too light.$NEWLINE$Why, ’tis an office of discovery, love.$NEWLINE$And I should be obscured.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$What, I have to hold a candle up so people can see what I’m doing? The truth is, I’m behaving like a loose woman. The torchbearer is supposed to bring light and love, but I should be hidden away in the dark.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$So are you, sweet,$NEWLINE$Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.$NEWLINE$But come at once,$NEWLINE$For the close night doth play the runaway,$NEWLINE$And we are stayed for at Bassanio’s feast.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$You’re hidden away, sweetheart, dressed up like a boy. Come on quickly. Time flies at night, and we’re late for Bassanio’s feast.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I will make fast the doors and gild myself$NEWLINE$With some more ducats, and be with you straight.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’ll lock up the doors, grab some more ducats, and be with you right away.

paragraphs.original: Exit JESSICA above$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA exits from above.$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Now, by my hood, a gentle and no Jew.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$My God, she can’t be a Jew, she’s too nice!

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Beshrew me but I love her heartily.$NEWLINE$For she is wise, if I can judge of her.$NEWLINE$And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true.$NEWLINE$And true she is, as she hath proved herself.$NEWLINE$And therefore, like herself—wise, fair and true—$NEWLINE$Shall she be placèd in my constant soul.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$God, I’m crazy about her. She’s wise, if I’m judging her right. She’s beautiful, if my eyes can see. And she’s loyal, as she has proven. And as long as she’s herself—wise, beautiful, and faithful—she’ll always have a place in my heart.

paragraphs.original: Enter JESSICA$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA enters.$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: What, art thou come?—On, gentlemen, away!$NEWLINE$Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, you’re here?—Come on, gentlemen, let’s go! Our masquerade mates are waiting for us.

paragraphs.original: Exit LORENZO with JESSICA and SALARINO$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$SALARINO
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO, JESSICA, and SALARINO exit.$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$SALARINO

paragraphs.original: Enter ANTONIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Who’s there?
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Signor Antonio?
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Signor Antonio?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Fie, fie, Gratiano! Where are all the rest?$NEWLINE$'Tis nine o'clock. Our friends all stay for you.$NEWLINE$No masque tonight. The wind is come about.$NEWLINE$Bassanio presently will go aboard.$NEWLINE$I have sent twenty out to seek for you.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Gratiano, where is everybody? It’s nine o'clock! Our friends are all waiting for you. There’s no masquerade tonight. The wind is blowing right, so Bassanio’s going onboard immediately. I’ve sent twenty people to look for you.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I am glad on ’t. I desire no more delight$NEWLINE$Than to be under sail and gone tonight.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I’m glad. I want to head out tonight.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish cornets Enter PORTIA with the Prince of MOROCCO, and both their trains$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$MOROCCO
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. PORTIA enters with the prince of MOROCCO and both their entourages.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$MOROCCO

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to servant) Go draw aside the curtains and discover$NEWLINE$(to servant)$NEWLINE$The several caskets to this noble prince.—
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to servant) Go open the curtains and show the different boxes to the prince.$NEWLINE$(to servant)

paragraphs.original: A curtain is drawn showing a gold, silver, and lead casket
paragraphs.translated: A curtain is drawn revealing showing three caskets: one gold, one silver, and one lead.$NEWLINE$A curtain is drawn revealing showing three caskets: one gold, one silver, and one lead.

paragraphs.original: (to MOROCCO) Now make your choice.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to MOROCCO) Now make your choice.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$The first, of gold, who this inscription bears:$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”$NEWLINE$The second, silver, which this promise carries:$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”$NEWLINE$This third, dull lead, with warning all as blunt:$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”$NEWLINE$How shall I know if I do choose the right?
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$The first one, the gold one, has an inscription that says, “He who chooses me will get what many men want.” The second one, the silver one, says, “He who chooses me will get what he deserves.” And this third one is made of dull lead. It has a blunt warning that says, “He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” How will I know if I chose the right one?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The one of them contains my picture, Prince.$NEWLINE$If you choose that, then I am yours withal.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$One of them contains my picture. If you choose that one, I’m yours, along with the picture.

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Some god direct my judgment! Let me see.$NEWLINE$I will survey th' inscriptions back again.$NEWLINE$What says this leaden casket?$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”$NEWLINE$Must give—for what? For lead? Hazard for lead?$NEWLINE$This casket threatens. Men that hazard all$NEWLINE$Do it in hope of fair advantages.$NEWLINE$A golden mind stoops not to shows of dross.$NEWLINE$I’ll then nor give nor hazard aught for lead.$NEWLINE$What says the silver with her virgin hue?
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$I wish some god could help me choose! Let me see. I’ll look over the inscriptions again. What does the lead box say? “He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” Must give everything—for what? For lead? Risk everything for lead? This box is too threatening. Men who risk everything hope to make profits. A golden mind doesn’t bend down to choose something worthless. So I won’t give or risk anything for lead. What does the silver one say?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”$NEWLINE$“As much as he deserves!”—pause there, Morocco,$NEWLINE$And weigh thy value with an even hand.$NEWLINE$If thou beest rated by thy estimation,$NEWLINE$Thou dost deserve enough, and yet enough$NEWLINE$May not extend so far as to the lady,$NEWLINE$And yet to be afeard of my deserving$NEWLINE$Were but a weak disabling of myself.$NEWLINE$As much as I deserve! Why, that’s the lady.$NEWLINE$I do in birth deserve her, and in fortunes,$NEWLINE$In graces, and in qualities of breeding.$NEWLINE$But more than these, in love I do deserve.$NEWLINE$What if I strayed no further, but chose here?$NEWLINE$Let’s see once more this saying graved in gold,$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”$NEWLINE$Why, that’s the lady. All the world desires her.$NEWLINE$From the four corners of the earth they come$NEWLINE$To kiss this shrine, this mortal breathing saint.$NEWLINE$The Hyrcanian deserts and the vasty wilds$NEWLINE$Of wide Arabia are as thoroughfares now$NEWLINE$For princes to come view fair Portia.$NEWLINE$The watery kingdom, whose ambitious head$NEWLINE$Spits in the face of heaven, is no bar$NEWLINE$To stop the foreign spirits, but they come$NEWLINE$As o'er a brook to see fair Portia.$NEWLINE$One of these three contains her heavenly picture.$NEWLINE$Is ’t like that lead contains her? 'Twere damnation$NEWLINE$To think so base a thought. It were too gross$NEWLINE$To rib her cerecloth in the obscure grave.$NEWLINE$Or shall I think in silver she’s immured,$NEWLINE$Being ten times undervalued to tried gold?$NEWLINE$O sinful thought! Never so rich a gem$NEWLINE$Was set in worse than gold. They have in England$NEWLINE$A coin that bears the figure of an angel$NEWLINE$Stamped in gold, but that’s insculped upon.$NEWLINE$But here an angel in a golden bed
paragraphs.translated: “He who chooses me will get as much as he deserves.” As much as he deserves—wait a minute there, Morocco, and consider your own value with a level head. If your reputation is trustworthy, you deserve a lot—though maybe not enough to include this lady. But fearing I don’t deserve her is a way of underestimating myself. As much as I deserve—I deserve Portia! By birth I deserve her. In terms of wealth, talents, and upbringing, and especially love, I deserve her. What if I went no further and chose this one? But let’s see once more what the gold one says: “He who chooses me will get what many men want.” That’s Portia! The whole world wants her. They come from the four corners of the earth to kiss this shrine and see this living, breathing saint. Princes travel across deserts and the vast wilderness of Arabia to come see the beautiful Portia. The wide ocean doesn’t prevent them from coming to see her—they travel across it as if it were a little stream. One of these three boxes contains her lovely picture. Could the lead one contain it? No, it’d be a sin to think such a low thought. Lead’s too crass to hold her. Is she enclosed in silver, which is ten times less valuable than gold? Oh, what a sinful thought! Nobody ever set a gem like her in a worse setting than gold. They have a coin in England stamped with the figure of an angel, but that’s just engraved on the surface.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Lies all within.—Deliver me the key.$NEWLINE$Here do I choose, and thrive I as I may!
paragraphs.translated: Here an angel’s lying in a golden bed.—Give me the key. I will choose this one and try my chances.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(giving MOROCCO a key)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a key)$NEWLINE$There, take it, Prince. And if my form lie there$NEWLINE$Then I am yours.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(she hands him a key) There, take it, prince. And if my picture’s in there, then I’m yours.$NEWLINE$(she hands him a key)

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO opens the golden casket$NEWLINE$MOROCCO
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO opens the gold casket.$NEWLINE$MOROCCO

paragraphs.original: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$O hell, what have we here?$NEWLINE$A carrion death, within whose empty eye$NEWLINE$There is a written scroll. I’ll read the writing.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“All that glisters is not gold—$NEWLINE$Often have you heard that told.$NEWLINE$Many a man his life hath sold$NEWLINE$But my outside to behold.$NEWLINE$Gilded tombs do worms enfold.$NEWLINE$Had you been as wise as bold,$NEWLINE$Young in limbs, in judgment old,$NEWLINE$Your answer had not been inscrolled.$NEWLINE$Fare you well. Your suit is cold—$NEWLINE$Cold, indeed, and labor lost.”$NEWLINE$Then, farewell, heat, and welcome, frost!$NEWLINE$Portia, adieu. I have too grieved a heart$NEWLINE$To take a tedious leave. Thus losers part.
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO$NEWLINE$Damn it! What’s this? It’s a skull with a scroll in its empty eye socket. I’ll read it aloud.$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“All that glitters is not gold—$NEWLINE$You’ve often heard that said.$NEWLINE$Many men have sold their souls$NEWLINE$Just to view my shiny surface.$NEWLINE$But gilded tombs contain worms.$NEWLINE$If you’d been as wise as you were bold,$NEWLINE$With an old man’s mature judgment,$NEWLINE$You wouldn’t have had to read this scroll.$NEWLINE$So goodbye—you lost your chance.”$NEWLINE$Lost my chance indeed! So goodbye hope, and hello despair. Portia, goodbye to you. My heart’s too sad for long goodbyes. Losers always leave quickly.

paragraphs.original: Exit MOROCCO with his train$NEWLINE$MOROCCO
paragraphs.translated: MOROCCO exits with his entourage.$NEWLINE$MOROCCO

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$A gentle riddance.—Draw the curtains, go.—$NEWLINE$Let all of his complexion choose me so.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Good riddance!—Close the curtains and leave.—I hope everyone who looks like him will make the same choice.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SALARINO and SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO and SOLANIO enter$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail.$NEWLINE$With him is Gratiano gone along.$NEWLINE$And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I saw Bassanio sail away, and Gratiano went with him. I’m sure Lorenzo isn’t on their ship.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$The villain Jew with outcries raised the Duke,$NEWLINE$Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$That wicked Jew got the duke to listen to his complaints. The duke went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$He came too late. The ship was under sail.$NEWLINE$But there the Duke was given to understand$NEWLINE$That in a gondola were seen together$NEWLINE$Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.$NEWLINE$Besides, Antonio certified the Duke$NEWLINE$They were not with Bassanio in his ship.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$He got there too late. The ship was already sailing. But once he got there, the duke learned that Lorenzo and his lover Jessica were together in a gondola. In any case, Antonio assured the duke they weren’t with Bassanio on his ship.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I never heard a passion so confused,$NEWLINE$So strange, outrageous, and so variable,$NEWLINE$As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.$NEWLINE$“My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter,$NEWLINE$Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!$NEWLINE$Justice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter!$NEWLINE$A sealèd bag, two sealèd bags of ducats,$NEWLINE$Of double ducats, stol'n from me by my daughter!$NEWLINE$And jewels—two stones, two rich and precious stones—$NEWLINE$Stol'n by my daughter! Justice, find the girl!$NEWLINE$She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.”
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I’ve never heard such confused emotions as what that Jew dog was shouting in the streets. “My daughter, oh my ducats, oh my daughter! Ran off with a Christian! Oh my Christian ducats! Justice, the law, my ducats, and my daughter, a sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats, of double ducats, stolen from me by my daughter, and jewels—two stones, two rich and precious stones—stolen by my daughter! Justice, find the girl! She has the stones on her, and the ducats.”

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Why, all the boys in Venice follow him,$NEWLINE$Crying, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I know, all the boys in Venice are following him, yelling, “His stones, his daughter, and his ducats!”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Let good Antonio look he keep his day,$NEWLINE$Or he shall pay for this.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I hope Antonio repays his loan on time, or he’ll suffer for this.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Marry, well remembered.$NEWLINE$I reasoned with a Frenchman yesterday,$NEWLINE$Who told me, in the narrow seas that part$NEWLINE$The French and English, there miscarried$NEWLINE$A vessel of our country richly fraught.$NEWLINE$I thought upon Antonio when he told me,$NEWLINE$And wished in silence that it were not his.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$That’s a good point. I spoke with a Frenchman yesterday who said that a Venetian ship loaded with treasure was wrecked in the English Channel. I thought about Antonio when he told me. I silently hoped it wasn’t his ship.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$You were best to tell Antonio what you hear—$NEWLINE$Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$You should tell Antonio what you hear—but don’t do it suddenly, because it might upset him.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.$NEWLINE$I saw Bassanio and Antonio part.$NEWLINE$Bassanio told him he would make some speed$NEWLINE$Of his return. He answered, “Do not so.$NEWLINE$Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio$NEWLINE$But stay the very riping of the time.$NEWLINE$And for the Jew’s bond which he hath of me,$NEWLINE$Let it not enter in your mind of love.$NEWLINE$Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts$NEWLINE$To courtship and such fair ostents of love$NEWLINE$As shall conveniently become you there.”$NEWLINE$And even there, his eye being big with tears,$NEWLINE$Turning his face, he put his hand behind him,$NEWLINE$And with affection wondrous sensible$NEWLINE$He wrung Bassanio’s hand. And so they parted.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$There’s no nicer guy in the whole world. I saw Bassanio and Antonio say goodbye. Bassanio told him he’d try to hurry back. Antonio answered “Don’t rush. Don’t do a sloppy job for my sake, Bassanio. Stay until everything is finished. As for the Jew’s contract, don’t let it be a factor in your plans. Be happy and concentrate your thoughts on love and how to win your love.” Then his eyes started tearing up. He turned his face away. Then he shook Bassanio’s hand affectionately—and they separated.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I think he only loves the world for him.$NEWLINE$I pray thee, let us go and find him out$NEWLINE$And quicken his embracèd heaviness$NEWLINE$With some delight or other.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I think he only loves life because of Bassanio. Let’s go find him and cheer him up.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Do we so.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Yes, let’s do that.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NERISSA and a servitor$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA and a servant enter.$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Quick, quick, I pray thee. Draw the curtain straight.$NEWLINE$The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath$NEWLINE$And comes to his election presently.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Hurry, hurry, close the curtain quick. The prince of Arragon has taken his oath, and he’s coming to make his choice now.

paragraphs.original: Flourish cornets Enter the Prince of ARRAGON, his train, and PORTIA$NEWLINE$ARRAGON$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. The Prince of ARRAGON, his entourage, and PORTIA enter.$NEWLINE$ARRAGON$NEWLINE$PORTIA

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince.$NEWLINE$If you choose that wherein I am contained,$NEWLINE$Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemnized.$NEWLINE$But if you fail, without more speech, my lord,$NEWLINE$You must be gone from hence immediately.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Look, here are the boxes, prince. If you choose the one that contains my picture, we’ll be married right away. But if you fail, you have to leave immediately. No pleas will be allowed.

paragraphs.original: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$I am enjoined by oath to observe three things:$NEWLINE$First, never to unfold to any one$NEWLINE$Which casket ’twas I chose; next, if I fail$NEWLINE$Of the right casket, never in my life$NEWLINE$To woo a maid in way of marriage; lastly,$NEWLINE$If I do fail in fortune of my choice,$NEWLINE$Immediately to leave you and be gone.
paragraphs.translated: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$I swore I’d do three things. First, I can never tell anyone what box I choose. Second, if I choose the wrong box, I’ll never propose marriage for the rest of my life. Third, if I pick the wrong box, I’ll leave immediately.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$To these injunctions every one doth swear$NEWLINE$That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Everyone who comes to gamble on winning me has to swear to these three rules.

paragraphs.original: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$And so have I addressed me. Fortune now$NEWLINE$To my heart’s hope! Gold, silver, and base lead.$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”$NEWLINE$You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.$NEWLINE$What says the golden chest? Ha, let me see.$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”
paragraphs.translated: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$Okay, I’m ready. I hope luck will give me what my heart hopes for! Gold, silver, and common lead. “He who chooses me must give and risk all he has.” You’d have to be more attractive for me to give or risk anything for you. What does the golden box say? Hmm, let me see:

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “What many men desire”—that “many” may be meant$NEWLINE$By the fool multitude that choose by show,$NEWLINE$Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach;$NEWLINE$Which pries not to th' interior, but like the martlet$NEWLINE$Builds in the weather on the outward wall,$NEWLINE$Even in the force and road of casualty.$NEWLINE$I will not choose what many men desire$NEWLINE$Because I will not jump with common spirits$NEWLINE$And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.$NEWLINE$Why then, to thee, thou silver treasure house.$NEWLINE$Tell me once more what title thou dost bear.$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”$NEWLINE$And well said too—for who shall go about$NEWLINE$To cozen fortune and be honorable$NEWLINE$Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume$NEWLINE$To wear an undeservèd dignity.$NEWLINE$Oh, that estates, degrees and offices$NEWLINE$Were not derived corruptly, and that clear honor$NEWLINE$Were purchased by the merit of the wearer!$NEWLINE$How many then should cover that stand bare!$NEWLINE$How many be commanded that command!$NEWLINE$How much low peasantry would then be gleaned$NEWLINE$From the true seed of honor! And how much honor$NEWLINE$Picked from the chaff and ruin of the times$NEWLINE$To be new varnished! Well, but to my choice.$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”$NEWLINE$I will assume desert.—Give me a key for this,$NEWLINE$And instantly unlock my fortunes here.
paragraphs.translated: “He who chooses me will get what many men want.” What many men want—that “many” could mean that most people are fools and choose by whatever is flashy. They don’t go beyond what their eyes see. They don’t bother to find out what’s on the inside. Just like those birds called martins who build their nests on the outside of walls, people pay too much attention to what’s on the outside. So I won’t choose what many men desire, because I won’t jump on the bandwagon and include myself with the whole crude population. So I guess it’s you, you silver treasure house. Tell me once more what you say. “He who chooses me will get what he deserves.” That’s nicely put—because who’s going to cheat luck and get more than he deserves? No one should have an honor he doesn’t deserve. Oh, wouldn’t it be great if property, rank, official positions, and other honors were earned only by merit, not by corruption? There wouldn’t be too many important men then. How many people who are humble now would be great then? How many people who give orders now would have to take orders? How many noblemen would be weeded out and would become peasants? And how many common people would suddenly shine with nobility? Well, let me get back to my choice. “He who chooses me will get what he deserves.” I’ll assume I deserve the very best.—Give me a key for this one. I’ll unlock my fate here in a second.

paragraphs.original: ARRAGON opens the silver casket$NEWLINE$ARRAGON
paragraphs.translated: ARRAGON opens the silver casket.$NEWLINE$ARRAGON

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Too long a pause for that which you find there.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You thought about it too long, considering what you found there.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$What’s here? The portrait of a blinking idiot$NEWLINE$Presenting me a schedule! I will read it.—$NEWLINE$How much unlike art thou to Portia!$NEWLINE$How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!$NEWLINE$“Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves”!$NEWLINE$Did I deserve no more than a fool’s head?$NEWLINE$Is that my prize? Are my deserts no better?
paragraphs.translated: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$What’s this? A picture of an idiot holding a scroll up for me to read! I’ll read it.—It looks so unlike Portia! This outcome isn’t what I hoped for, or what I deserve. “The one who chooses me will get what he deserves”! Didn’t I deserve anything more than a fool’s head? Is this my prize? Don’t I deserve more than this?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$To offend and judge are distinct offices$NEWLINE$And of opposèd natures.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Judging what you deserve is one thing. Offending you is something very different, so I’ll keep my mouth shut.

paragraphs.original: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$What is here?$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“The fire seven times tried this,$NEWLINE$Seven times tried that judgment is,$NEWLINE$That did never choose amiss.$NEWLINE$Some there be that shadows kiss.$NEWLINE$Such have but a shadow’s bliss.$NEWLINE$There be fools alive, iwis,$NEWLINE$Silvered o'er—and so was this.$NEWLINE$Take what wife you will to bed,$NEWLINE$I will ever be your head.$NEWLINE$So be gone. You are sped.$NEWLINE$Still more fool I shall appear”$NEWLINE$By the time I linger here.$NEWLINE$With one fool’s head I came to woo,$NEWLINE$But I go away with two.—$NEWLINE$Sweet, adieu. I’ll keep my oath$NEWLINE$Patiently to bear my wroth.”
paragraphs.translated: ARRAGON$NEWLINE$What does this say?$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“This box was tested in the fire seven times.$NEWLINE$The person who never makes a wrong choice$NEWLINE$Has wisdom that will stand the test.$NEWLINE$Some people kiss shadows.$NEWLINE$They only feel the shadow of joy.$NEWLINE$There are fools out there$NEWLINE$With silver hair and silver coins.$NEWLINE$This choice was as foolish as they are.$NEWLINE$Take whatever wife you want to bed with you,$NEWLINE$You’ll have a fool’s head forever.$NEWLINE$So go away. You’re done here.”$NEWLINE$The longer I stay, the more foolish I look. I came here with a fool’s head on my shoulders and now I’m leaving with two.—Goodbye, sweet lady. I’ll keep my oath and patiently suffer through my anger.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ARRAGON and his train$NEWLINE$ARRAGON
paragraphs.translated: He exits with his train.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Thus hath the candle singed the moth.$NEWLINE$O these deliberate fools! When they do choose,$NEWLINE$They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$These men are like moths, drawn to these boxes as if they were flames. This is how the candle burned the moth. Oh, these fools! When they choose, they only know how to lose.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$The ancient saying is no heresy.$NEWLINE$Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You know what they say. Destiny chooses when you’ll die and who you’ll marry.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come, draw the curtain, Nerissa.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come on, close the curtain, Nerissa.

paragraphs.original: Enter MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: messenger$NEWLINE$Where is my lady?
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Where’s lady Portia?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Here. What would my lord?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Here. How can I help you, sir?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, there is alighted at your gate$NEWLINE$A young Venetian, one that comes before$NEWLINE$To signify th' approaching of his lord,$NEWLINE$From whom he bringeth sensible regreets,$NEWLINE$To wit—besides commends and courteous breath—$NEWLINE$Gifts of rich value. Yet I have not seen$NEWLINE$So likely an ambassador of love.$NEWLINE$A day in April never came so sweet$NEWLINE$To show how costly summer was at hand,$NEWLINE$As this forespurrer comes before his lord.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Madam, a young Venetian man has arrived to tell us his master is about to arrive. This lord has sent gifts. Besides his nice polite greetings, his gifts are expensive. I haven’t seen such a promising candidate for your love. This servant has arrived before his master the way a sweet spring day hints about a lush summer. But there’s never been an April day as promising as this.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$No more, I pray thee. I am half afeard$NEWLINE$Thou wilt say anon he is some kin to thee,$NEWLINE$Thou spend’st such high-day wit in praising him.—$NEWLINE$Come, come, Nerissa, for I long to see$NEWLINE$Quick Cupid’s post that comes so mannerly.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Please don’t tell me any more. I’m almost afraid you’re going to tell me he’s a relative of yours, because you’re going so crazy praising him. Come on, Nerissa, I want to go see this man who’s come so courteously.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Bassanio, Lord Love, if thy will it be!
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$I hope it’s Bassanio coming to win Portia!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SOLANIO and SALARINO$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO and SALARINO enter$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Now, what news on the Rialto?
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$So, what’s the news on the Rialto?

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Why, yet it lives there unchecked that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wracked on the narrow seas. The Goodwins I think they call the place—a very dangerous flat, and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip report be an honest woman of her word.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Well, there’s a rumor that Antonio had a ship carrying expensive cargo that shipwrecked in the English Channel on the Goodwin Sands, a very dangerous sandbar. Many ships have sunk there, according to rumors.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever knapped ginger or made her neighbors believe she wept for the death of a third husband. But it is true, without any slips of prolixity or crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, that I had a title good enough to keep his name company!—
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I hope this new rumor is a lie, like the gossiping widow’s claim that she was sorry her third husband died! But it’s true—I don’t want to get all mushy and go on and on, but the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—oh, if I only had a title good enough to match his!—

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Come, the full stop.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Come on, get to the point.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Ha, what sayest thou? Why, the end is he hath lost a ship.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$What are you saying? Well, the point is, he’s lost a ship.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I would it might prove the end of his losses.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$I hope that’s all he loses.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Let me say “Amen” betimes, lest the devil cross my prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Let me say “amen” quickly, before the devil comes in and stops my prayer—because here comes the devil, disguised as a Jew.

paragraphs.original: Enter SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK enters.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How now, Shylock? What news among the merchants?
paragraphs.translated: How’s it going, Shylock? What’s the news among the merchants?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$You knew—none so well, none so well as you—of my daughter’s flight.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$You knew—no one knew, no one knew as well as you did—about my daughter’s plans to run away.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$That’s certain. I, for my part, knew the tailor that made the wings she flew withal.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$That’s true. I even knew the tailor who made the disguise she wore when she ran off.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$And Shylock, for his own part, knew the bird was fledged, and then it is the complexion of them all to leave the dam.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$And Shylock knew his daughter was ready to run away. It’s natural for children to leave their parents.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$She is damned for it.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$She’ll be damned for it.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$That’s certain—if the devil may be her judge.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$That’s true—if the devil’s judging her.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$My own flesh and blood to rebel!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$My own flesh and blood turned against me! A rebel!

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Out upon it, old carrion! Rebels it at these years?
paragraphs.translated:
SOLANIO$NEWLINE$No! Your
flesh still rebels at your age?$NEWLINE$flesh still rebels$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I say my daughter is my flesh and blood.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I mean my daughter is my flesh and blood.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$There is more difference between thy flesh and hers than between jet and ivory, more between your bloods than there is between red wine and rhenish. But tell us, do you hear whether Antonio have had any loss at sea or no?
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$You two are totally different. Your flesh is more different from hers than coal is from ivory. There’s more difference between your bloods than between red wine and white. But tell us, did you hear anything about Antonio’s loss at sea?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$There I have another bad match!—a bankrupt, a prodigal who dare scarce show his head on the Rialto, a beggar that was used to come so smug upon the mart. Let him look to his bond. He was wont to call me usurer; let him look to his bond. He was wont to lend money for a Christian courtesy; let him look to his bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$That’s another bad deal I’ve made!—a bankrupt, a spendthrift, who now has to hide his head on the Rialto, a beggar who used to look so smug in front of the other merchants. Let him think about his own debt. He liked to call me a loan shark; let him think about his debt to me. He used to lend money as a favor between Christians; but now, let him think about his own debt.

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$Why, I am sure, if he forfeit thou wilt not take his flesh.$NEWLINE$What’s that good for?
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$But you won’t take his flesh if he can’t pay. What’s that good for?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$To bait fish withal. If it will feed nothing else, it will feed my revenge. He hath disgraced me and hindered me half a million, laughed at my losses, mocked at my gains, scorned my nation, thwarted my bargains, cooled my friends, heated mine enemies—and what’s his reason? I am a Jew. Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions? Fed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian is? If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge? If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that. If a Jew wrong a Christian, what is his humility? Revenge. If a Christian wrong a Jew, what should his sufferance be by Christian example? Why, revenge. The villainy you teach me I will execute—and it shall go hard but I will better the instruction.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ll use it for fish bait. You can’t eat human flesh, but if it feeds nothing else, it’ll feed my revenge. He’s insulted me and cost me half a million ducats. He’s laughed at my losses, made fun of my earnings, humiliated my race, thwarted my deals, turned my friends against me, riled up my enemies—and why? Because I’m a Jew. Doesn’t a Jew have eyes? Doesn’t a Jew have hands, bodily organs, a human shape, five senses, feelings, and passions? Doesn’t a Jew eat the same food, get hurt with the same weapons, get sick with the same diseases, get healed by the same medicine, and warm up in summer and cool off in winter just like a Christian? If you prick us with a pin, don’t we bleed? If you tickle us, don’t we laugh? If you poison us, don’t we die? And if you treat us badly, won’t we try to get revenge? If we’re like you in everything else, we’ll resemble you in that respect. If a Jew offends a Christian, what’s the Christian’s kind and gentle reaction? Revenge. If a Christian offends a Jew, what punishment will he come up with if he follows the Christian example? Of course, the same thing—revenge! I’ll treat you as badly as you Christians taught me to—and you’ll be lucky if I don’t outdo my teachers.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MAN from ANTONIO$NEWLINE$MAN$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: One of ANTONIO’s SERVANTS enters.$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SERVANTS

paragraphs.original: MAN$NEWLINE$(to SOLANIO and SALARINO) Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house and desires to speak with you both.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$(to SOLANIO and SALARINO) My master Antonio is at his house and would like to speak to you both.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SALARINO$NEWLINE$We have been up and down to seek him.
paragraphs.translated: SALARINO$NEWLINE$We’ve been looking for him everywhere.

paragraphs.original: Enter TUBAL$NEWLINE$TUBAL
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL enters.$NEWLINE$TUBAL

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Here comes another of the tribe. A third cannot be matched unless the devil himself turn Jew.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$Here comes another Jew. You couldn’t find a third like these two unless the devil himself turned into a Jew.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SOLANIO, SALARINO, and MAN$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$MAN
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO, SALARINO, and ANTONIO’s SERVANT exit.$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$SALARINO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$How now, Tubal? What news from Genoa? Hast thou found my daughter?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Hello, Tubal. Any news from Genoa? Did you find my daughter?

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I went to many places where I heard news about her, but I couldn’t find her.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Why, there, there, there, there! A diamond gone cost me two thousand ducats in Frankfurt—the curse never fell upon our nation till now! I never felt it till now—Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels. I would my daughter were dead at my foot and the jewels in her ear! Would she were hearsed at my foot and the ducats in her coffin! No news of them? Why, so. And I know not what’s spent in the search. Why thou, loss upon loss! The thief gone with so much, and so much to find the thief—and no satisfaction, no revenge. Nor no ill luck stirring but what lights o' my shoulders, no sighs but o' my breathing, no tears but o' my shedding.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Oh, oh, oh! One of the stolen diamonds cost me two thousand ducats in Frankfurt! I never felt the curse of the Jews until now. I never felt it until now—two thousand ducats in that diamond, and other precious, precious jewels! I wish my daughter were dead at my feet wearing those jewels! I wish she were in her coffin here, with the ducats in her coffin! You couldn’t find out anything about them? Why? I don’t even know how much I’m spending to find them. Loss upon loss! The thief left with so much, and I’m spending so much to hunt down the thief—and still I’m not satisfied! I haven’t gotten my revenge. The only luck I have is bad luck. Nobody suffers but me. Nobody’s crying except me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$Yes, other men have ill luck too. Antonio, as I heard in$NEWLINE$Genoa—
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$Well, other men have bad luck too. Antonio, as I heard in Genoa—

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, what, what? Ill luck, ill luck?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, what, what? Bad luck, bad luck?

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$Hath an argosy cast away coming from Tripolis.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$He’s had a ship wrecked coming from Tripolis.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I thank God, I thank God! Is ’t true, is ’t true?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Thank God, thank God! Is it true, is it true?

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I spoke with some of the sailors who survived the wreck.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I thank thee, good Tubal. Good news, good news! Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Thank you, Tubal. Good news, good news! Ha, ha, heard in Genoa.

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, in one night fourscore ducats.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I also heard that your daughter spent eighty ducats in Genoa one night.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Thou stickest a dagger in me. I shall never see my gold again. Fourscore ducats at a sitting! Fourscore ducats!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re sticking a dagger in me! I’ll never see my gold again. Eighty ducats in one shot! Eighty ducats!

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$There came divers of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$I came to Venice with a number of Antonio’s creditors who say he won’t be able to avoid going bankrupt.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I am very glad of it. I’ll plague him. I’ll torture him. I am glad of it.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’m very glad about that. I’ll hound him. I’ll torture him. I’m very glad.

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$One of them showed me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$One creditor showed me a ring he got from your daughter in exchange for a monkey.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my turquoise. I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor. I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Damn her! You’re torturing me, Tubal. That was my turquoise ring! Leah gave it to me before we were married. I wouldn’t have given it away for a whole jungle of monkeys.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TUBAL$NEWLINE$But Antonio is certainly undone.
paragraphs.translated: TUBAL$NEWLINE$But Antonio’s certainly ruined.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s true, that’s very true. Go, Tubal, fee me an officer. Bespeak him a fortnight before.—I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will.—Go, go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue. Go, good Tubal. At our synagogue, Tubal.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$That’s true, that’s very true. Tubal, go find me a police officer to arrest Antonio. Get him ready two weeks ahead of time.—I’ll take Antonio’s heart if he can’t pay. With him out of Venice, I can make whatever bargains I want when I lend money.—Go, Tubal. Meet me at the synagogue.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
