paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO, PORTIA, GRATIANO, and NERISSA enter with all their attendants, including a SINGER.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$NERISSA$NEWLINE$SINGER

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) I pray you, tarry. Pause a day or two$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Before you hazard, for in choosing wrong$NEWLINE$I lose your company. Therefore forbear awhile.$NEWLINE$There’s something tells me—but it is not love—$NEWLINE$I would not lose you, and you know yourself$NEWLINE$Hate counsels not in such a quality.$NEWLINE$But lest you should not understand me well—$NEWLINE$And yet a maiden hath no tongue but thought—$NEWLINE$I would detain you here some month or two$NEWLINE$Before you venture for me. I could teach you$NEWLINE$How to choose right, but I am then forsworn.$NEWLINE$So will I never be. So may you miss me.$NEWLINE$But if you do, you’ll make me wish a sin,$NEWLINE$That I had been forsworn. Beshrew your eyes,$NEWLINE$They have o'erlooked me and divided me.$NEWLINE$One half of me is yours, the other half yours—$NEWLINE$Mine own, I would say. But if mine, then yours,$NEWLINE$And so all yours. Oh, these naughty times$NEWLINE$Put bars between the owners and their rights!$NEWLINE$And so, though yours, not yours. Prove it so.$NEWLINE$Let Fortune go to hell for it, not I.$NEWLINE$I speak too long, but ’tis to peize the time,$NEWLINE$To eke it and to draw it out in length,$NEWLINE$To stay you from election.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) Please wait a day or two before making your choice. If you choose wrong, I’ll lose your company. So wait a while. Something tells me—not love, but something—that I don’t want to lose you, and you know that if I hated you I wouldn’t think that. But let me put it more clearly in case you don’t understand—though I know girls aren’t supposed to express their thoughts—I’m just saying I’d like you to stay here for a month or two before you undergo the test for me. I could tell you how to choose correctly, but then I’d be disregarding the oath I took. So I’ll never tell. But you might lose me by making the wrong choice. If you do choose wrong, you’ll make me wish for something very bad. I’d wish I had ignored my oath and told you everything. God, your eyes have bewitched me. They’ve divided me in two. One half of me is yours, and the other half—my own half, I’d call it—belongs to you too. If it’s mine, then it’s yours, and so I’m all yours. But in this awful day and age people don’t even have the right to their own property! So though I’m yours, I’m not yours. If there’s no chance for me to be yours, then it’s just bad luck. I know I’m talking too much, but I do that just to make the time last longer, and to postpone your test.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Let me choose,$NEWLINE$For as I am, I live upon the rack.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Let me choose now. I feel tortured by all this talking.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Upon the rack, Bassanio? Then confess$NEWLINE$What treason there is mingled with your love.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA$NEWLINE$Tortured,
Bassanio? Then confess to your crime. Tell us about the treason you’ve mixed in with your love.$NEWLINE$Bassanio$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$None but that ugly treason of mistrust$NEWLINE$Which makes me fear th' enjoying of my love.$NEWLINE$There may as well be amity and life$NEWLINE$'Tween snow and fire, as treason and my love.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$The only treason I’m guilty of is worrying that I’m never going to get to enjoy you. Treason has nothing at all to do with my love. They’re as opposite as hot and cold.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rack$NEWLINE$Where men enforcèd do speak anything.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Hmmm, I’m not sure I believe what you’re saying. Men under torture will confess anything.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Promise me life, and I’ll confess the truth.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Promise me you’ll let me live, and I’ll confess the truth.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Well then, confess and live.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$All right then, confess and live.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$“Confess and love”$NEWLINE$Had been the very sum of my confession.$NEWLINE$O happy torment, when my torturer$NEWLINE$Doth teach me answers for deliverance!$NEWLINE$But let me to my fortune and the caskets.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$“Confess and love” is more like it. Oh, torture’s fun when my torturer tells me what I have to say to go free! But let me try my luck on the boxes.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Away, then. I am locked in one of them.$NEWLINE$If you do love me you will find me out.—$NEWLINE$Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof.$NEWLINE$Let music sound while he doth make his choice.$NEWLINE$Then if he lose he makes a swanlike end,$NEWLINE$Fading in music. That the comparison$NEWLINE$May stand more proper, my eye shall be the stream$NEWLINE$And watery deathbed for him. He may win,$NEWLINE$And what is music then? Then music is$NEWLINE$Even as the flourish when true subjects bow$NEWLINE$To a new-crownèd monarch. Such it is$NEWLINE$As are those dulcet sounds in break of day$NEWLINE$That creep into the dreaming bridegroom’s ear$NEWLINE$And summon him to marriage.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Go ahead, then. I’m locked in one of them. If you really love me, you’ll find me.—Nerissa and the rest of you, get away from him. Play some music while he chooses. Then if he loses, it’ll be his swan song, music before the end. And since swans need water to swim in, I’ll cry him a river when he loses. But on the other hand, he may win. What music should we play then? If he wins, the music should be like the majestic trumpets that blare when subjects bow to a newly crowned monarch. It’s the sweet sounds at daybreak that the dreaming bridegroom hears on his wedding morning, calling him to the church.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Now he goes$NEWLINE$With no less presence but with much more love$NEWLINE$Than young Alcides, when he did redeem$NEWLINE$The virgin tribute paid by howling Troy$NEWLINE$To the sea monster. I stand for sacrifice.$NEWLINE$The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives,$NEWLINE$With blearèd visages come forth to view$NEWLINE$The issue of th' exploit.—Go, Hercules!$NEWLINE$Live thou, I live. With much, much more dismay$NEWLINE$I view the fight than thou that makest the fray.
paragraphs.translated: Bassanio’s walking to the boxes now. He looks as dignified as Hercules did when he saved the princess Hesione from the sea monster. But he loves me more than Hercules loved the princess. I’ll play Hesione, and everyone else will be the bystanders watching with tear-streaked faces. We’ve all come out to see what will happen.—Go, Hercules! If you survive, I’ll live. I’m more anxious watching you fight than you are in the fight itself.

paragraphs.translated: A song plays while BASSANIO mulls over the boxes.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$So may the outward shows be least themselves.$NEWLINE$The world is still deceived with ornament.$NEWLINE$In law, what plea so tainted and corrupt$NEWLINE$But, being seasoned with a gracious voice,$NEWLINE$Obscures the show of evil? In religion,$NEWLINE$What damnèd error, but some sober brow$NEWLINE$Will bless it and approve it with a text,$NEWLINE$Hiding the grossness with fair ornament?$NEWLINE$There is no vice so simple but assumes$NEWLINE$Some mark of virtue on his outward parts.$NEWLINE$How many cowards whose hearts are all as false$NEWLINE$As stairs of sand wear yet upon their chins$NEWLINE$The beards of Hercules and frowning Mars,$NEWLINE$Who, inward searched, have livers white as milk,$NEWLINE$And these assume but valor’s excrement$NEWLINE$To render them redoubted. Look on beauty,$NEWLINE$And you shall see ’tis purchased by the weight,$NEWLINE$Which therein works a miracle in nature,$NEWLINE$Making them lightest that wear most of it.$NEWLINE$So are those crispèd snaky golden locks$NEWLINE$Which maketh such wanton gambols with the wind,$NEWLINE$Upon supposèd fairness, often known$NEWLINE$To be the dowry of a second head,$NEWLINE$The skull that bred them in the sepulcher.$NEWLINE$Thus ornament is but the guilèd shore$NEWLINE$To a most dangerous sea, the beauteous scarf$NEWLINE$Veiling an Indian beauty—in a word,$NEWLINE$The seeming truth which cunning times put on$NEWLINE$To entrap the wisest. Therefore then, thou gaudy gold,$NEWLINE$Hard food for Midas, I will none of thee.$NEWLINE$Nor none of thee, thou pale and common drudge$NEWLINE$'Tween man and man. But thou, thou meagre lead,$NEWLINE$Which rather threaten’st than dost promise aught,$NEWLINE$Thy paleness moves me more than eloquence,$NEWLINE$And here choose I. Joy be the consequence!
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$You can’t always judge a book by its cover. People are often tricked by false appearances. In court, someone can deliver a false plea but hide its wickedness with a pretty voice. In religion, don’t serious men defend sins with Scripture, covering up evil with a show of good. Every sin in the world manages to make itself look good somehow. How many people are cowards at heart but wear beards like Hercules or Mars, the god of war? Take another example: beauty. It can be bought by the ounce in makeup, which works miracles. Women who wear it the most are respected the least. It’s the same thing with hair. Curly golden hair moves so nicely in the wind and makes a woman beautiful. But you can buy that kind of hair as a wig, and wigs are made from dead people’s hair. Decoration’s nothing but a danger, meant to trick and trap the viewer. A lovely, cunning shore can distract a man from the perils of a stormy sea, just as a pretty scarf can hide a dangerous dark-skinned beauty. Nowadays, everyone’s fooled by appearances. So I’ll have nothing to do with that gaudy gold box—it’s like the gold that Midas couldn’t eat. And I’ll have nothing to do with the pale silver either, the metal that common coins are made of. But this humble lead one, though it looks too threatening to promise me anything good, moves me more than I can say. So this is the one I choose. I hope I’m happy with my choice!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(aside) How all the other passions fleet to air,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$As doubtful thoughts, and rash-embraced despair,$NEWLINE$And shuddering fear, and green-eyed jealousy!$NEWLINE$O love, be moderate. Allay thy ecstasy.$NEWLINE$In measure rein thy joy. Scant this excess.$NEWLINE$I feel too much thy blessing. Make it less,$NEWLINE$For fear I surfeit.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to herself) All my other emotions are vanishing into thin air, as all my doubts and desperation and fears and jealousy are all flying away! Oh, I need to calm down, make my love and my joy less intense. I’m feeling this too strongly. Please make my love less, or I’m going to overindulge, making myself sick.$NEWLINE$(to herself)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(opening the lead casket)$NEWLINE$(opening the lead casket)$NEWLINE$What find I here?$NEWLINE$Fair Portia’s counterfeit! What demigod$NEWLINE$Hath come so near creation? Move these eyes?$NEWLINE$Or whether, riding on the balls of mine,$NEWLINE$Seem they in motion? Here are severed lips,$NEWLINE$Parted with sugar breath. So sweet a bar$NEWLINE$Should sunder such sweet friends. Here in her hairs,$NEWLINE$The painter plays the spider and hath woven$NEWLINE$A golden mesh t' entrap the hearts of men$NEWLINE$Faster than gnats in cobwebs. But her eyes—$NEWLINE$How could he see to do them? Having made one,$NEWLINE$Methinks it should have power to steal both his$NEWLINE$And leave itself unfurnished. Yet look how far$NEWLINE$The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow$NEWLINE$In underprizing it, so far this shadow$NEWLINE$Doth limp behind the substance. Here’s the scroll,$NEWLINE$The continent and summary of my fortune.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“You that choose not by the view,$NEWLINE$Chance as fair and choose as true.$NEWLINE$Since this fortune falls to you,$NEWLINE$Be content and seek no new.$NEWLINE$If you be well pleased with this$NEWLINE$And hold your fortune for your bliss,$NEWLINE$Turn you where your lady is$NEWLINE$And claim her with a loving kiss.”
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(opening the lead box) What do we have here? A picture of beautiful Portia! What artist captured her likeness so well? Are these eyes moving? Or do they just seem to move as my eyes move? Her sweet breath forces her lips open, a lovely divider of lovely lips. And look at her hair, looking like a golden mesh to trap the hearts of men, like little flies in a cobweb. The painter was like a spider in creating it so delicately. But her eyes—how could he keep looking at them long enough to paint them? I would’ve expected that when he finished one of them, it would have enraptured him and kept him from painting the other. But I’m giving only faint praise of the picture, just as the picture, as good as it is, is only a faint imitation of the real woman herself. Here’s the scroll that sums up my fate:$NEWLINE$(opening the lead box)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“You who don’t judge by looks alone,$NEWLINE$Have better luck, and make the right choice.$NEWLINE$Since this prize is yours,$NEWLINE$Be happy with it, and don’t look for a new one.$NEWLINE$If you’re happy with what you’ve won$NEWLINE$And accept this prize as your blissful destiny,$NEWLINE$Then turn to where your lady is,$NEWLINE$And claim her with a loving kiss.”

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: A gentle scroll. Fair lady, by your leave,$NEWLINE$I come by note to give and to receive.$NEWLINE$Like one of two contending in a prize$NEWLINE$That thinks he hath done well in people’s eyes,$NEWLINE$Hearing applause and universal shout,$NEWLINE$Giddy in spirit, still gazing in a doubt$NEWLINE$Whether these pearls of praise be his or no—$NEWLINE$So, thrice fair lady, stand I even so,$NEWLINE$As doubtful whether what I see be true$NEWLINE$Until confirmed, signed, ratified by you.
paragraphs.translated: A nice message. My lady, with your permission, this note authorizes me to give myself to you with a kiss. But I’m in a daze, like someone who’s just won a contest and thinks that all the applause and cheering is for him, but isn’t sure yet. And so, beautiful lady, I’m standing here just like that, wondering whether all this can be true until you tell me it is.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You see me, Lord Bassanio, where I stand$NEWLINE$Such as I am. Though for myself alone$NEWLINE$I would not be ambitious in my wish$NEWLINE$To wish myself much better, yet for you$NEWLINE$I would be trebled twenty times myself—$NEWLINE$A thousand times more fair, ten thousand times more rich—$NEWLINE$That only to stand high in your account$NEWLINE$I might in virtue, beauties, livings, friends$NEWLINE$Exceed account. But the full sum of me$NEWLINE$Is sum of something which, to term in gross,$NEWLINE$Is an unlessoned girl, unschooled, unpracticèd;$NEWLINE$Happy in this—she is not yet so old$NEWLINE$But she may learn. Happier than this—$NEWLINE$She is not bred so dull but she can learn.$NEWLINE$Happiest of all is that her gentle spirit$NEWLINE$Commits itself to yours to be directed$NEWLINE$As from her lord, her governor, her king.$NEWLINE$Myself and what is mine to you and yours$NEWLINE$Is now converted. But now I was the lord$NEWLINE$Of this fair mansion, master of my servants,$NEWLINE$Queen o'er myself. And even now, but now,$NEWLINE$This house, these servants, and this same myself$NEWLINE$Are yours, my lord’s. I give them with this ring,$NEWLINE$Which when you part from, lose, or give away,$NEWLINE$Let it presage the ruin of your love
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You see me standing here, Lord Bassanio. What you see is what you get. Though I wouldn’t wish to be better for my own sake, for your sake I wish I were twenty times more than myself—a thousand times more beautiful and ten thousand times richer—just so you might value me more, so my good qualities, beauty, possessions, and friends would be more than you could calculate. What you’re getting is an innocent and inexperienced girl. I’m happy that at least I’m not too old to learn new things. I’m even happier that I’m not stupid, and I can learn. I’m happiest of all that I’m yours now, my lord, my king, and you can guide me as you wish. Everything I am and everything I have now belongs to you. Just a minute ago I was the owner of this beautiful mansion, master of these servants, and queen over myself. But as of right this second all these things are yours. With this ring I give them all to you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And be my vantage to exclaim on you.$NEWLINE$(gives BASSANIO a ring)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a ring)
paragraphs.translated: If you ever give away this ring or lose it, it means our love’s doomed, and I’ll have a right to be angry with you.$NEWLINE$(she gives BASSANIO the ring)$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$the ring)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Madam, you have bereft me of all words.$NEWLINE$Only my blood speaks to you in my veins.$NEWLINE$And there is such confusion in my powers$NEWLINE$As after some oration fairly spoke$NEWLINE$By a belovèd prince there doth appear$NEWLINE$Among the buzzing pleasèd multitude,$NEWLINE$Where every something, being blent together,$NEWLINE$Turns to a wild of nothing, save of joy,$NEWLINE$Expressed and not expressed. But when this ring$NEWLINE$Parts from this finger, then parts life from hence.$NEWLINE$O, then be bold to say Bassanio’s dead!
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Madam, you’ve left me speechless, but my feelings are responding to your words. I’m as confused as a crowd of people going wild after hearing their prince give a speech. But the day I take this ring off will be the day I die. If you see me without it, you can be confident I’m dead.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$My lord and lady, it is now our time,$NEWLINE$That have stood by and seen our wishes prosper,$NEWLINE$To cry, “Good joy, good joy, my lord and lady!”
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$My lord and lady, it’s now our turn, who have been watching as our dreams came true. Now we can shout, “Congratulations, congratulations, my lord and lady!”

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio and my gentle lady,$NEWLINE$I wish you all the joy that you can wish,$NEWLINE$For I am sure you can wish none from me.$NEWLINE$And when your honors mean to solemnize$NEWLINE$The bargain of your faith, I do beseech you$NEWLINE$Even at that time I may be married too.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio, and my dear lady, I wish you all the joy I can wish for. And when you get married, I hope I can be married at the same time.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$With all my heart, so thou canst get a wife.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Absolutely, if you can find a wife by then.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I thank your lordship, you have got me one.$NEWLINE$My eyes, my lord, can look as swift as yours.$NEWLINE$You saw the mistress, I beheld the maid.$NEWLINE$You loved, I loved. For intermission$NEWLINE$No more pertains to me, my lord, than you.$NEWLINE$Your fortune stood upon the casket there,$NEWLINE$And so did mine too, as the matter falls.$NEWLINE$For wooing here until I sweat again,$NEWLINE$And swearing till my very roof was dry$NEWLINE$With oaths of love, at last—if promise last—$NEWLINE$I got a promise of this fair one here$NEWLINE$To have her love, provided that your fortune$NEWLINE$Achieved her mistress.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I think I’ve found one already, thanks to you, my lord. I can fall in love just as quickly as you can, and I loved Nerissa as soon as I laid eyes on her. You fell in love with Portia, and I fell in love with Nerissa, because I’m not in the habit of delaying any more than you are, my lord. Your fate depended on those boxes, and it turns out that mine did too. I couldn’t help but chase her. I started making love vows to her till my mouth was dry. Then finally she said she loved me and would marry me if you two got married as well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is this true, Nerissa?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is that true, Nerissa?

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Madam, it is, so you stand pleased withal.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, madam, it is, if it’s all right with you.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$And do you mean what you’re saying, Gratiano?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Yes, faith, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Our feast shall be much honored in your marriage.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Then we’d be honored to have you join us in our wedding ceremony.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) We’ll play with them the first boy for a thousand ducats.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) Let’s bet them a thousand ducats that we will have a son first.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What, and stake down?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$You want to stake the money down now?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$No, we shall ne'er win at that sport and stake down. But who comes here? Lorenzo and his infidel? What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?
paragraphs.translated:
GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Hey, if I lay down my “
stake,” I’ll never be able to have a son. But who’s this coming? Lorenzo and his pagan girlfriend? What, and my old Venetian friend Salerio?$NEWLINE$stake$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter LORENZO, JESSICA, and SALERIO, a messenger from Venice$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$SALERIO
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO and JESSICA enter with SALERIO, a messenger from Venice.$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$SALERIO

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither,$NEWLINE$If that the youth of my new interest here$NEWLINE$Have power to bid you welcome.$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$By your leave,$NEWLINE$I bid my very friends and countrymen,$NEWLINE$Sweet Portia, welcome.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Welcome, Lorenzo and Salerio. I hope my position in this new house is firm enough to allow me the right to welcome my friends.$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) With your permission, Portia, I welcome my good friends and countrymen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$So do I, my lord.$NEWLINE$They are entirely welcome.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I do too, my lord. They’re entirely welcome.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) I thank your honor. For my part, my lord,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My purpose was not to have seen you here.$NEWLINE$But meeting with Salerio by the way,$NEWLINE$He did entreat me, past all saying nay,$NEWLINE$To come with him along.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) Thank you, sir. I didn’t intend to come see you. But I ran into Salerio on the way, and he begged me to come along with him until I couldn’t say no.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$I did, my lord.$NEWLINE$And I have reason for it. Signor Antonio$NEWLINE$Commends him to you.$NEWLINE$(gives BASSANIO letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$letter)
paragraphs.translated: SALERIO$NEWLINE$That’s true, and with good reason. This letter is for you from Signor Antonio. (he gives BASSANIO a letter)$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Ere I ope his letter,$NEWLINE$I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Before I open this letter, please tell me how my good friend is doing.

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind,$NEWLINE$Nor well, unless in mind. His letter there$NEWLINE$Will show you his estate.
paragraphs.translated: SALERIO$NEWLINE$He’s not sick, my lord, but he’s very upset, and his problems are serious. His letter will tell you how he’s doing.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO opens the letter and reads it$NEWLINE$BASSANIO
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO opens the letter and reads it.$NEWLINE$BASSANIO

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(indicating JESSICA)$NEWLINE$(indicating$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Nerissa, cheer yond stranger. Bid her welcome.—$NEWLINE$Your hand, Salerio. What’s the news from Venice?$NEWLINE$How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?$NEWLINE$I know he will be glad of our success.$NEWLINE$We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(pointing at JESSICA) Nerissa, welcome this stranger. —Salerio, welcome. Any news from Venice? How’s the great merchant Antonio doing? I know he’ll be happy to hear of our success. We’re like the ancient hero Jason, we went looking for the Golden Fleece and we won it!$NEWLINE$(pointing at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.
paragraphs.translated:
SALERIO$NEWLINE$I wish you’d won the
fleece he lost.$NEWLINE$fleece$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$There are some shrewd contents in yond same paper$NEWLINE$That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek.$NEWLINE$Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world$NEWLINE$Could turn so much the constitution$NEWLINE$Of any constant man. What, worse and worse?—$NEWLINE$With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself,$NEWLINE$And I must freely have the half of anything$NEWLINE$That this same paper brings you.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Something bad in that letter is making Bassanio turn pale. Some good friend of his must have died, because nothing else in the world could change a man so much. What, does the news only get worse?—Please, Bassanio, I’m half of you, so let me bear half the burden this letter brings you.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$O sweet Portia,$NEWLINE$Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words$NEWLINE$That ever blotted paper. Gentle lady,$NEWLINE$When I did first impart my love to you,$NEWLINE$I freely told you, all the wealth I had$NEWLINE$Ran in my veins. I was a gentleman,$NEWLINE$And then I told you true. And yet, dear lady,$NEWLINE$Rating myself at nothing, you shall see$NEWLINE$How much I was a braggart. When I told you$NEWLINE$My state was nothing, I should then have told you$NEWLINE$That I was worse than nothing, for indeed$NEWLINE$I have engaged myself to a dear friend,$NEWLINE$Engaged my friend to his mere enemy$NEWLINE$To feed my means.$NEWLINE$Here is a letter, lady,$NEWLINE$The paper as the body of my friend,$NEWLINE$And every word in it a gaping wound,$NEWLINE$Issuing life blood.—But is it true, Salerio?$NEWLINE$Have all his ventures failed? What, not one hit?$NEWLINE$From Tripolis, from Mexico and England,$NEWLINE$From Lisbon, Barbary, and India?$NEWLINE$And not one vessel ’scape the dreadful touch$NEWLINE$Of merchant-marring rocks?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Oh Portia, these are some of the worst words that ever stained a piece of paper. My darling, when I gave my love to you, I told you that all the wealth I had ran within my veins—that I have noble blood, but no money. When I said that, I told you the truth. But my dear, when I said I was worth nothing, I was actually bragging—I should’ve said that I was worse than nothing. I’ve borrowed money from a dear friend who in turn borrowed money from his mortal enemy for my sake. Here’s a letter, my dear. The paper’s like my friend’s body, and every word in it is a bleeding wound on that body.—But is it true, Salerio? Have all his business ventures failed? Not even one success? He had ships to Tripolis, Mexico, England, Lisbon, North Africa, and India, and not one of these ships avoided the rocks?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$Not one, my lord.$NEWLINE$Besides, it should appear that if he had$NEWLINE$The present money to discharge the Jew,$NEWLINE$He would not take it. Never did I know$NEWLINE$A creature that did bear the shape of man$NEWLINE$So keen and greedy to confound a man.$NEWLINE$He plies the duke at morning and at night,$NEWLINE$And doth impeach the freedom of the state$NEWLINE$If they deny him justice. Twenty merchants,$NEWLINE$The duke himself, and the magnificoes$NEWLINE$Of greatest port have all persuaded with him.$NEWLINE$But none can drive him from the envious plea$NEWLINE$Of forfeiture, of justice, and his bond.
paragraphs.translated: SALERIO$NEWLINE$Not one, my lord. Anyway, even if he had the money now, the Jew probably wouldn’t take it. I’ve never seen a creature with a human shape who was so eager to destroy a man. He’s at the duke’s morning and night, accusing the state of harming free trade if they deny him justice. Twenty merchants, the duke himself, and the highest-ranking Venetian nobles have all tried to persuade him to forget his contract, but nobody can do it. He’s determined to get the penalty specified in his contract with Antonio.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$When I was with him I have heard him swear$NEWLINE$To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen,$NEWLINE$That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh$NEWLINE$Than twenty times the value of the sum$NEWLINE$That he did owe him. And I know, my lord,$NEWLINE$If law, authority, and power deny not,$NEWLINE$It will go hard with poor Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$When I was still living with him I heard him swear to Tubal and Cush, his countrymen, that he’d rather have Antonio’s flesh than twenty times the sum Antonio owed. And I know that unless the law intervenes, it’ll be bad news for poor Antonio.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is this your good friend who’s in so much trouble?

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,$NEWLINE$The best conditioned and unwearied spirit$NEWLINE$In doing courtesies, and one in whom$NEWLINE$The ancient Roman honor more appears$NEWLINE$Than any that draws breath in Italy.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Yes, he’s my best friend, the kindest man and most courteous to others. He’s more honorable than anyone else in Italy.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What sum owes he the Jew?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$How much does he owe the Jew?

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$For me, three thousand ducats.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What, no more?$NEWLINE$Pay him six thousand and deface the bond!$NEWLINE$Double six thousand, and then treble that,$NEWLINE$Before a friend of this description$NEWLINE$Shall lose a hair through Bassanio’s fault.$NEWLINE$First go with me to church and call me wife,$NEWLINE$And then away to Venice to your friend.$NEWLINE$For never shall you lie by Portia’s side$NEWLINE$With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold$NEWLINE$To pay the petty debt twenty times over.$NEWLINE$When it is paid, bring your true friend along.$NEWLINE$My maid Nerissa and myself meantime$NEWLINE$Will live as maids and widows. Come, away!$NEWLINE$For you shall hence upon your wedding day.$NEWLINE$Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer.$NEWLINE$Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear.$NEWLINE$But let me hear the letter of your friend.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What, that’s all? Pay him six thousand and cancel the debt. I’d pay twelve thousand before I’d let a friend like that suffer in the slightest because of you. First come with me to church to get married. Then you can leave for Venice to see your friend. You have to go, because you’ll never sleep next to me peacefully without settling this. I’ll give you enough gold to pay back your debt twenty times over. When it’s paid, bring your friend back. Until you get back, Nerissa and I will live like virgins and widows. Come on, let’s go, because you’re going to leave me the same day we get married. Put on a happy face, and welcome your friends. Since it’s costing me a lot to marry you, I’ll think of you as even more precious. But let me hear the letter from your friend.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all miscarried. My creditors grow cruel. My estate is very low. My bond to the Jew is forfeit. And since in paying it, it is impossible I should live, all debts are cleared between you and I if I might but see you at my death. Notwithstanding, use your pleasure. If your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.”
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“Dear Bassanio, my ships have all been wrecked. My creditors are getting mean. My money’s almost run out. I couldn’t pay my debt to the Jew on the due date. Since I’ll certainly die when he takes his collateral out of my flesh, all debts are cleared between you and me if I can just see you again before I die. In any case, do what you want. If your affection for me doesn’t convince you to come, don’t let my letter do so.”

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$O love, dispatch all business and be gone!
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Oh, my darling, make your arrangements and go!

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Since I have your good leave to go away,$NEWLINE$I will make haste. But till I come again,$NEWLINE$No bed shall e'er be guilty of my stay,$NEWLINE$No rest be interposer ’twixt us twain.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Since you’re letting me leave, I’ll hurry. But I won’t sleep till I get back.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SHYLOCK, SOLANIO, ANTONIO, and the jailer$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK, SOLANIO, ANTONIO, and the jailer enter.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SOLANIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Jailer, look to him. Tell not me of mercy.$NEWLINE$This is the fool that lent out money gratis.$NEWLINE$Jailer, look to him.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Jailer, watch out for this one. Don’t try to convince me to feel sorry for him. This is the fool who lent out money without charging interest. Jailer, keep an eye on him.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Hear me yet, good Shylock.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Listen to me, good Shylock.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ll have my bond. Speak not against my bond.$NEWLINE$I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.$NEWLINE$Thou calledst me dog before thou hadst a cause.$NEWLINE$But since I am a dog, beware my fangs.$NEWLINE$The duke shall grant me justice.—I do wonder,$NEWLINE$Thou naughty jailer, that thou art so fond$NEWLINE$To come abroad with him at his request.
paragraphs.translated:
SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’m going to get my
bond . Don’t try to say anything against my taking my bond. I’ve sworn an oath that I will have my bond. You called me a dog before you had any reason to. But since I’m a dog, beware my fangs. The duke will give me justice.—I do wonder, jailer, how you can be so foolish as to let this prisoner out of his cell.$NEWLINE$bond$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I pray thee, hear me speak.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Please, listen to me.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ll have my bond. I will not hear thee speak.$NEWLINE$I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.$NEWLINE$I’ll not be made a soft and dull-eyed fool$NEWLINE$To shake the head, relent and sigh, and yield$NEWLINE$To Christian intercessors. Follow not.$NEWLINE$I’ll have no speaking. I will have my bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I want my bond. I won’t listen to you. I want my bond, so stop talking. I won’t be taken for a fool who sighs and gives in to Christian meddlers. Don’t follow me. I’m not talking with you. I want my bond.

paragraphs.original: Exit SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$It is the most impenetrable cur$NEWLINE$That ever kept with men.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$He’s the most stubborn dog that ever lived among humans.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Let him alone.$NEWLINE$I’ll follow him no more with bootless prayers.$NEWLINE$He seeks my life. His reason well I know.$NEWLINE$I oft delivered from his forfeitures$NEWLINE$Many that have at times made moan to me.$NEWLINE$Therefore he hates me.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Leave him alone. I won’t follow him around with useless pleas anymore. He wants me dead. I know the real reason. I’ve often given money to people who were unable to pay back their loans to him. That’s why he hates me.

paragraphs.original: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I am sure the duke$NEWLINE$Will never grant this forfeiture to hold.
paragraphs.translated: SOLANIO$NEWLINE$I’m sure the duke will never allow this contract to be enforced.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The duke cannot deny the course of law.$NEWLINE$For the commodity that strangers have$NEWLINE$With us in Venice, if it be denied,$NEWLINE$Will much impeach the justice of his state,$NEWLINE$Since that the trade and profit of the city$NEWLINE$Consisteth of all nations. Therefore go.$NEWLINE$These griefs and losses have so bated me,$NEWLINE$That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh$NEWLINE$Tomorrow to my bloody creditor.—$NEWLINE$Well, jailer, on.—Pray God Bassanio come$NEWLINE$To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$The duke can’t deny the law, because that would threaten the security of all foreign merchants in Venice, and that’s how the city makes its money. If the government disregards the law, it will be discredited. So go. I’ve lost so much weight worrying about my losses have that I’ll hardly have a pound of flesh to spare for my bloody creditor tomorrow.—Well, jailer, let’s go.—I hope to God that Bassanio comes to see me pay his debt. After that, I don’t care what happens.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA, NERISSA, LORENZO, JESSICA, and BALTHAZAR, a man of PORTIA’s$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$BALTHAZAR$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA, NERISSA, LORENZO, and JESSICA enter with BALTHAZAR, a servant of PORTIA’s.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$BALTHAZAR$NEWLINE$PORTIA

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Madam, although I speak it in your presence,$NEWLINE$You have a noble and a true conceit$NEWLINE$Of godlike amity, which appears most strongly$NEWLINE$In bearing thus the absence of your lord.$NEWLINE$But if you knew to whom you show this honor,$NEWLINE$How true a gentleman you send relief,$NEWLINE$How dear a lover of my lord your husband,$NEWLINE$I know you would be prouder of the work$NEWLINE$Than customary bounty can enforce you.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Madam, I hope you don’t mind my saying that I admire your noble respect for friendship, which you show in letting your husband go off to help his friend like this. If you only knew the man you’re helping out, and what a faithful gentleman he is and how much he loves your husband, I know you’d be even prouder of your kindness than you normally might be.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I never did repent for doing good,$NEWLINE$Nor shall not now; for in companions$NEWLINE$That do converse and waste the time together$NEWLINE$Whose souls do bear an equal yoke of love,$NEWLINE$There must be needs a like proportion$NEWLINE$Of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit,$NEWLINE$Which makes me think that this Antonio,$NEWLINE$Being the bosom lover of my lord,$NEWLINE$Must needs be like my lord. If it be so,$NEWLINE$How little is the cost I have bestowed$NEWLINE$In purchasing the semblance of my soul$NEWLINE$From out the state of hellish cruelty!$NEWLINE$This comes too near the praising of myself.$NEWLINE$Therefore no more of it. Hear other things.$NEWLINE$Lorenzo, I commit into your hands$NEWLINE$The husbandry and manage of my house$NEWLINE$Until my lord’s return.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I’ve never regretted doing good, and I don’t now. Friends who spend a lot of time together and really care equally for each other must have many traits in common. Since Antonio’s my husband’s best friend, they must be very similar men. In that case, the money I’ve sent is a small price to pay to rescue someone who resembles my Bassanio, who’s like my own soul.—Anyway, let’s change the subject, since I feel like I’m starting to flatter myself. I have a favor to ask of you. Lorenzo, please take charge of the management of my house until my husband comes back.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For mine own part,$NEWLINE$I have toward heaven breathed a secret vow$NEWLINE$To live in prayer and contemplation,$NEWLINE$Only attended by Nerissa here$NEWLINE$Until her husband and my lord’s return.$NEWLINE$There is a monastery two miles off,$NEWLINE$And there will we abide. I do desire you$NEWLINE$Not to deny this imposition,$NEWLINE$The which my love and some necessity$NEWLINE$Now lays upon you.
paragraphs.translated: I’ve sworn to God that I’ll live a life of prayer and contemplation until my husband returns. Only Nerissa will keep me company. There’s a monastery two miles away where we can stay. Please say you’ll agree, because I really need you to do this.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Madam, with all my heart.$NEWLINE$I shall obey you in all fair commands.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Madam, with all my heart. I’ll do anything you ask.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$My people do already know my mind$NEWLINE$And will acknowledge you and Jessica$NEWLINE$In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.$NEWLINE$So fare you well till we shall meet again.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I’ve already spoken to my staff about this. They’ll consider you and Jessica masters of this house in place of Lord Bassanio and myself. So goodbye until we meet again.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I hope you can relax and enjoy yourself!

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I wish your ladyship all heart’s content.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I hope you find peace and happiness, my lady.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I thank you for your wish, and am well pleased$NEWLINE$To wish it back on you. Fare you well, Jessica.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Thank you. I wish you the same. Goodbye, Jessica.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt JESSICA and LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$LORENZO
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA and LORENZO exit.$NEWLINE$JESSICA$NEWLINE$LORENZO

paragraphs.original: Now, Balthazar,$NEWLINE$As I have ever found thee honest true,$NEWLINE$So let me find thee still.$NEWLINE$(gives BALTHAZAR a letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a letter)$NEWLINE$Take this same letter,$NEWLINE$And use thou all th' endeavour of a man$NEWLINE$In speed to Padua. See thou render this$NEWLINE$Into my cousin’s hands, Doctor Bellario.
paragraphs.translated: Now, Balthazar, you’ve always been honest and faithful to me, and I trust you still are. (she gives BALTHAZAR a letter) Take this letter to Padua as fast as you can. Make sure you put it into the hands of my cousin Bellario, the Doctor of Laws.$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And look what notes and garments he doth give thee,$NEWLINE$Bring them, I pray thee, with imagined speed$NEWLINE$Unto the traject, to the common ferry$NEWLINE$Which trades to Venice. Waste no time in words,$NEWLINE$But get thee gone. I shall be there before thee.
paragraphs.translated: And as quickly as possible, take whatever letters and clothes he gives you to the public ferry that goes back and forth to Venice. Don’t waste time talking now. Just go. I’ll meet you at the ferry.

paragraphs.original: BALTHAZAR$NEWLINE$Madam, I go with all convenient speed.
paragraphs.translated: BALTHAZAR$NEWLINE$I’ll go as fast as I can, madam.

paragraphs.original: Exit BALTHAZAR$NEWLINE$BALTHAZAR
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand$NEWLINE$That you yet know not of. We’ll see our husbands$NEWLINE$Before they think of us.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Come on, Nerissa, I have many things to do that you don’t even know about yet. We’ll see our husbands before they even have a chance to miss us.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Shall they see us?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Will they see us?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$They shall, Nerissa, but in such a habit$NEWLINE$That they shall think we are accomplishèd$NEWLINE$With that we lack. I’ll hold thee any wager,$NEWLINE$When we are both accoutred like young men,$NEWLINE$I’ll prove the prettier fellow of the two,$NEWLINE$And wear my dagger with the braver grace,$NEWLINE$And speak between the change of man and boy$NEWLINE$With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps$NEWLINE$Into a manly stride, and speak of frays$NEWLINE$Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies,$NEWLINE$How honorable ladies sought my love,$NEWLINE$Which I denying, they fell sick and died—$NEWLINE$I could not do withal!—Then I’ll repent$NEWLINE$And wish for all that, that I had not killed them.$NEWLINE$And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell,$NEWLINE$That men shall swear I have discontinued school$NEWLINE$Above a twelvemonth. I have within my mind$NEWLINE$A thousand raw tricks of these bragging jacks$NEWLINE$Which I will practice.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$They will, Nerissa, but we’ll be disguised as men. I’ll bet you anything that I’ll be handsomer than you when we’re both dressed up. I’ll wear my sword more gracefully, and speak like a teenage boy, and walk with a manly stride rather than my ladylike steps. I’ll talk about fights like a bragging youth, and I’ll tell cute lies about honorable ladies who fell in love with me and got sick and died when I rejected them. They just died, what could I do! Then I’ll start feeling sorry for them, wishing I hadn’t killed them. I’ll tell twenty lies like that, so men will think I graduated from school at least a year ago. I know a thousand immature tricks like that, and I’ll use them all.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Why, shall we turn to men?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Why, are we turning to men?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Fie, what a question’s that$NEWLINE$If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!$NEWLINE$But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device$NEWLINE$When I am in my coach, which stays for us$NEWLINE$At the park gate. And therefore haste away,$NEWLINE$For we must measure twenty miles today.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What kind of question is that! If I had a dirty mind, I’d think you meant turning to men for sex. Here, I’ll tell you my whole plan in my carriage, which is waiting for us at the gate. So hurry up, because we have twenty miles to cover today.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LAUNCELOT the clown and JESSICA$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT and JESSICA enter.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Yes, truly, for look you, the sins of the father are to be laid upon the children. Therefore I promise ye I fear you. I was always plain with you, and so now I speak my agitation of the matter. Therefore be o' good cheer, for truly I think you are damned. There is but one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Yes, look, it’s true that children are punished for the sins of their fathers. That’s why I’m worried about you. I’ve always been straightforward with you, so now I’m telling you what I think. Cheer up, because I think you’re going to hell. There’s only one hope for you, and even that’s a kind of illegitimate hope.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$And what hope is that, I pray thee?
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$What hope is that, may I ask?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Marry, you may partly hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Jew’s daughter.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$You can hope your father isn’t your real father. Maybe your mother fooled around, and you aren’t the Jew’s daughter.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$That were a kind of bastard hope indeed. So the sins of my mother should be visited upon me.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$That really is an illegitimate hope. Then I’d be punished for the sins of my mother.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother. Thus when I shun Scylla your father, I fall into Charybdis your mother. Well, you are gone both ways.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$In that case I’m afraid you’re damned by both your father and your mother. When you avoid one trap, you fall into another. You’re in trouble either way.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I shall be saved by my husband. He hath made me a$NEWLINE$Christian.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$My husband will save me. He’s made me a Christian.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Truly, the more to blame he. We were Christians eno' before, e'en as many as could well live one by another. This making Christians will raise the price of hogs. If we grow all to be pork-eaters, we shall not shortly have a rasher on the coals for money.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$He was wrong to do that. There were enough Christians before—as many of them as could stand to live near each other. All these new Christians will make the price of hogs go up. If we’re all pork-eaters, we won’t be able to get our hands on a slice of bacon, even if we’ve got the money for it.

paragraphs.original: Enter LORENZO$NEWLINE$LORENZO
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO enters.$NEWLINE$LORENZO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say. Here he comes.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’ll tell my husband what you’ve said, Launcelot. Here he comes.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$You’re going to make me jealous, Launcelot, if you keep taking my wife into dark corners like this!

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo. Launcelot and I are out. He tells me flatly there is no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter, and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians you raise the price of pork.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$No, you don’t need to worry about us, Lorenzo. Launcelot and I can’t agree on anything. He says I won’t get into heaven because I’m a Jew’s daughter, and he says you’re irresponsible because by converting Jews to Christianity you’re raising the price of pork.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly. The Moor is with child by you, Launcelot.
paragraphs.translated:
LORENZO$NEWLINE$I can justify that better than you can justify sleeping with Portia’s African servant. The
Moor is pregnant with your child, Launcelot.$NEWLINE$Moor$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$It is much that the Moor should be more than reason. But if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more than I took her for.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$It’s too bad there’s more of the Moor than there ought to be. Well, even if she’s a less than honest woman, she’s still a lot more respectable than I thought at first.$NEWLINE$more

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$How every fool can play upon the word! I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots. Go in, sirrah. Bid them prepare for dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Any fool can make puns! I think the best sign of intelligence will soon be silence, and talking will only be a good thing for parrots to do. Go in and tell the servants to get ready for dinner.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$That is done, sir. They have all stomachs.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$That’s already been done, sir. They’re all ready to eat dinner.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you! Then bid them prepare dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Good Lord, what a clown you are! Tell them to make the dinner.$NEWLINE$make

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$That is done too, sir. Only “Cover!” is the word.
paragraphs.translated:
LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$That’s also been done, sir. The word you’re looking for is “
cover .”$NEWLINE$cover$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Will you cover then, sir?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Will you cover, then?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Not so, sir, neither. I know my duty.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$No, sir—I know my duty.$NEWLINE$Launcelot$NEWLINE$Launcelot$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Yet more quarreling with occasion! Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant? I pray thee, understand a plain man in his plain meaning. Go to thy fellows, bid them cover the table, serve in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$You keep finding ways to mock me! Are you planning on showing me all your wit at once? Please understand my simple message: go tell the servants to set the table and bring in the food, and we’ll come in to dinner.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$For the table, sir, it shall be served in. For the meat, sir, it shall be covered. For your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humours and conceits shall govern.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$About the table, sir, dinner will be served on it. As for the food, it will be served in covered dishes. As for your coming in to dinner, just do what you feel is right.

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT exits.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$O dear discretion, how his words are suited!$NEWLINE$The fool hath planted in his memory$NEWLINE$An army of good words, and I do know$NEWLINE$A many fools that stand in better place,$NEWLINE$Garnished like him, that for a tricksy word$NEWLINE$Defy the matter. How cheerest thou, Jessica?$NEWLINE$And now, good sweet, say thy opinion.$NEWLINE$How dost thou like the Lord Bassanio’s wife?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Oh, he’s good at bending words around! The fool has memorized a whole army full of fancy words. I know jesters in better positions, with the same talents he has. They also like to digress from the topic at hand by playing with language. Anyway, how are you, Jessica? And how do you like Lord Bassanio’s wife?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Past all expressing. It is very meet$NEWLINE$The Lord Bassanio live an upright life,$NEWLINE$For having such a blessing in his lady,$NEWLINE$He finds the joys of heaven here on earth.$NEWLINE$And if on earth he do not merit it,$NEWLINE$In reason he should never come to heaven.$NEWLINE$Why, if two gods should play some heavenly match$NEWLINE$And on the wager lay two earthly women,$NEWLINE$And Portia one, there must be something else$NEWLINE$Pawned with the other, for the poor rude world$NEWLINE$Hath not her fellow.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I like her more than I can say. Bassanio should live an upstanding life because having a wife like Portia is a blessing. It’s as if he found heaven here on earth. And if he doesn’t deserve this joy on earth, he’ll never deserve it in heaven. Imagine what would happen if two gods in heaven made a bet. If one of them used Portia as his stake, the other god would have a hard time coming up with a human woman to match her value. The poor rude world doesn’t have her equal.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Even such a husband$NEWLINE$Hast thou of me as she is for a wife.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$As good a wife as she is, that’s how good a husband I am to you.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Nay, but ask my opinion too of that!
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’ll be the judge of that!

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I will anon. First let us go to dinner.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$I’ll give you a chance to judge later. First let’s go to dinner.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Nay, let me praise you while I have a stomach.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$No, let me say some good things about you while I’m in the mood.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$No, pray thee, let it serve for table talk.$NEWLINE$Then howsome'er thou speak’st ’mong other things$NEWLINE$I shall digest it.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$No, please, save it for dinner conversation. That way, no matter what you say, I’ll digest it with everything else.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll set you forth.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$In that case I’ll serve you up like a dish of food.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the DUKE, the magnificoes, ANTONIO, BASSANIO, GRATIANO, SALERIO, and others$NEWLINE$DUKE$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$SALERIO
paragraphs.translated:
The
DUKE , the magnificoes, ANTONIO, BASSANIO, GRATIANO, SALERIO, and attendants all enter.$NEWLINE$DUKE$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$SALERIO

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$What, is Antonio here?
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Is Antonio here?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Ready, so please your grace.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, I’m here.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$I am sorry for thee. Thou art come to answer$NEWLINE$A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch$NEWLINE$Uncapable of pity, void and empty$NEWLINE$From any dram of mercy.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$I feel sorry for you. You’ve come to face a ruthless enemy, an inhuman wretch incapable of pity, without any feelings of mercy.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I have heard$NEWLINE$Your grace hath ta'en great pains to qualify$NEWLINE$His rigorous course. But since he stands obdurate$NEWLINE$And that no lawful means can carry me$NEWLINE$Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose$NEWLINE$My patience to his fury, and am armed$NEWLINE$To suffer with a quietness of spirit$NEWLINE$The very tyranny and rage of his.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$They tell me you’ve done everything you can to talk him out of what he’s doing. But since he remains stubborn, and there’s no legal way to protect me from his malice, I’ll just have to take what he’ll give me. I’m ready to suffer peacefully whatever he does to me in his cruelty and anger.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Go, one, and call the Jew into the court.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$One of you go call the Jew into court here.

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$He is ready at the door. He comes, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SALERIO$NEWLINE$He’s standing ready outside the door. Here he comes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Enter SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK enters.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Make room, and let him stand before our face.—$NEWLINE$Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too,$NEWLINE$That thou but lead’st this fashion of thy malice$NEWLINE$To the last hour of act, and then ’tis thought$NEWLINE$Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse more strange$NEWLINE$Than is thy strange apparent cruelty,$NEWLINE$And where thou now exacts the penalty—$NEWLINE$Which is a pound of this poor merchant’s flesh—$NEWLINE$Thou wilt not only loose the forfeiture$NEWLINE$But—touched with human gentleness and love,—$NEWLINE$Forgive a moiety of the principal,$NEWLINE$Glancing an eye of pity on his losses$NEWLINE$That have of late so huddled on his back$NEWLINE$Eno' to press a royal merchant down$NEWLINE$And pluck commiseration of his state$NEWLINE$From brassy bosoms and rough hearts of flint,$NEWLINE$From stubborn Turks and Tartars never trained$NEWLINE$To offices of tender courtesy.$NEWLINE$We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Make room so he can stand in front of me. Shylock, everyone thinks—and I agree—that you’re just pretending to be cruel. They think that at the last second you’re going to show mercy and pity, which will be more surprising than the bizarre cruelty that you seem to be showing now. And even though you’re here to collect the penalty—a pound of this poor merchant’s flesh—they think you’ll not only let it go, but out of humanity and love you’ll forgive some portion of the principal he owes you too. In doing so you’ll be taking pity on him for his many recent losses, which have been large enough to send even the greatest merchant out of business, and make even the most hard-hearted Turk or Tartar feel sorry for him. What do you say? We all expect a nice answer from you, Jew.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I have possessed your grace of what I purpose,$NEWLINE$And by our holy Sabbath have I sworn$NEWLINE$To have the due and forfeit of my bond.$NEWLINE$If you deny it, let the danger light$NEWLINE$Upon your charter and your city’s freedom.$NEWLINE$You’ll ask me why I rather choose to have$NEWLINE$A weight of carrion flesh than to receive$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats. I’ll not answer that$NEWLINE$But say it is my humour. Is it answered?$NEWLINE$What if my house be troubled with a rat$NEWLINE$And I be pleased to give ten thousand ducats$NEWLINE$To have it baned? What, are you answered yet?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ve told you what I intend to do, and I’ve sworn by the holy Sabbath to seek the penalty that is due according to our contract. If you refuse to allow me to do so, your city’s charter and its freedom are endangered. You’re going to ask me why I’d rather have a pound of decaying flesh than three thousand ducats. I won’t answer that. Let’s just say it’s because I feel like it. Is that enough of an answer? What if I had a rat in my house, and I felt like paying ten thousand ducats to have it exterminated? Do you have your answer yet?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Some men there are love not a gaping pig,$NEWLINE$Some that are mad if they behold a cat,$NEWLINE$And others, when the bagpipe sings i' th' nose,$NEWLINE$Cannot contain their urine. For affection,$NEWLINE$Mistress of passion, sways it to the mood$NEWLINE$Of what it likes or loathes. Now, for your answer:$NEWLINE$As there is no firm reason to be rendered$NEWLINE$Why he cannot abide a gaping pig;$NEWLINE$Why he, a harmless necessary cat;$NEWLINE$Why he, a woollen bagpipe, but of force$NEWLINE$Must yield to such inevitable shame$NEWLINE$As to offend, himself being offended—$NEWLINE$So can I give no reason, nor I will not$NEWLINE$(More than a lodged hate and a certain loathing$NEWLINE$I bear Antonio), that I follow thus$NEWLINE$A losing suit against him. Are you answered?
paragraphs.translated: Some men don’t like roast pig, others go crazy if they see a cat, and others can’t help urinating when they hear bagpipes. There’s no sense trying to explain people’s likes and dislikes. So, to answer your question. Just as there’s no clear reason why one man doesn’t want a roast pig, or why another man can’t stand a harmless and useful cat, or another can’t tolerate bagpipes, so I can’t give a reason, and I won’t give a reason (other than the simple hate and loathing I feel for Antonio) why I’m pursuing this unprofitable case against him. Does that answer your question?$NEWLINE$(

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This is no answer, thou unfeeling man,$NEWLINE$To excuse the current of thy cruelty.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$That’s no answer, you heartless man. It doesn’t excuse your cruel behavior.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I am not bound to please thee with my answers.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I don’t have to give you answers that you like.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Do all men kill the things they do not love?
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Does everyone kill what they don’t love?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Hates any man the thing he would not kill?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Does anyone hate something and not want to kill it?

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Every offense is not a hate at first.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Disliking something isn’t the same thing as hating it.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, wouldst thou have a serpent sting thee twice?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What, would you let a snake bite you twice?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I pray you, think you question with the Jew?$NEWLINE$You may as well go stand upon the beach$NEWLINE$And bid the main flood bate his usual height.$NEWLINE$You may as well use question with the wolf$NEWLINE$Why he hath made the ewe bleat for the lamb.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO) Please don’t bother arguing with the Jew. You might as well go stand on the beach and ask the ocean to get smaller. You might as well ask a wolf why he killed the lamb and made its mother cry.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: You may as well forbid the mountain pines$NEWLINE$To wag their high tops and to make no noise$NEWLINE$When they are fretten with the gusts of heaven.$NEWLINE$You may as well do anything most hard,$NEWLINE$As seek to soften that—than which what’s harder?—$NEWLINE$His Jewish heart. Therefore I do beseech you$NEWLINE$Make no more offers, use no farther means,$NEWLINE$But with all brief and plain conveniency$NEWLINE$Let me have judgment and the Jew his will.
paragraphs.translated: You might as well tell the pine trees on the mountain to stop waving their treetops when the storms blow through them. You might as well do the impossible rather than try to soften his Jewish heart. It’s the hardest thing imaginable. Therefore I’m begging you, don’t make any more offers, don’t look for other ways to stop him. Just let me receive my punishment, and let the Jew take his penalty.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK) For thy three thousand ducats here is six.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK) Instead of your three thousand ducats, here are six thousand.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$If every ducat in six thousand ducats$NEWLINE$Were in six parts, and every part a ducat,$NEWLINE$I would not draw them. I would have my bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$If you offered me six times that, I wouldn’t accept it. I would choose to take my penalty.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$How shalt thou hope for mercy, rendering none?
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$How can you ever hope for mercy for yourself, when you don’t give any now?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What judgment shall I dread, doing no wrong?$NEWLINE$You have among you many a purchased slave,$NEWLINE$Which—like your asses and your dogs and mules—$NEWLINE$You use in abject and in slavish parts$NEWLINE$Because you bought them. Shall I say to you,$NEWLINE$“Let them be free! Marry them to your heirs!$NEWLINE$Why sweat they under burdens? Let their beds$NEWLINE$Be made as soft as yours and let their palates$NEWLINE$Be seasoned with such viands”? You will answer,$NEWLINE$“The slaves are ours.” So do I answer you.$NEWLINE$The pound of flesh which I demand of him$NEWLINE$Is dearly bought. 'Tis mine and I will have it.$NEWLINE$If you deny me, fie upon your law—$NEWLINE$There is no force in the decrees of Venice.$NEWLINE$I stand for judgment. Answer, shall I have it?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Why should I be afraid of your judgment when I haven’t done anything wrong? Many of you own slaves, which—like your donkeys and dogs and mules—you use to perform awful jobs just because you bought them. Should I say to you, “Set them free! Let them marry your children! Why are you making them work so hard? Let their beds be as soft as yours, and let them eat the same food as you”? No, you’d answer, “The slaves are ours.” And that’s just how I’m answering you. The pound of flesh that I want from him was very expensive. It’s mine and I’m going to get it. If you refuse me, the laws of Venice have no validity. I await justice. So answer me. Will I get it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Upon my power I may dismiss this court,$NEWLINE$Unless Bellario, a learnèd doctor,$NEWLINE$Whom I have sent for to determine this,$NEWLINE$Come here today.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$I have the authority to dismiss this court, unless Bellario comes today. He’s a legal expert I sent for to act as judge and help settle this matter.

paragraphs.original: SALERIO$NEWLINE$My lord, here stays without$NEWLINE$A messenger with letters from the doctor,$NEWLINE$New come from Padua.
paragraphs.translated: SALERIO$NEWLINE$My lord, a messenger is waiting outside with letters from Bellario. He’s just come from Padua.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Bring us the letter. Call the messenger.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Bring us the letters. Call the messenger in.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Good cheer, Antonio! What, man, courage yet!$NEWLINE$The Jew shall have my flesh, blood, bones and all,$NEWLINE$Ere thou shalt lose for me one drop of blood.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Cheer up, Antonio! Keep up your courage, man! I’ll give the Jew my flesh, blood, bones, and everything before you lose one drop of blood for me.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I am a tainted wether of the flock,$NEWLINE$Meetest for death. The weakest kind of fruit$NEWLINE$Drops earliest to the ground, and so let me.$NEWLINE$You cannot better be employed, Bassanio,$NEWLINE$Than to live still and write mine epitaph.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m like the one sick sheep in the flock, the one who deserves to die. The weakest fruit drops to the ground first, so let me drop. Bassanio, the best thing you can do is to keep living and write an epitaph for my gravestone.

paragraphs.original: Enter NERISSA, disguised as a clerk$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA enters, disguised as a lawyer’s clerk.$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Came you from Padua, from Bellario?
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Have you come from Bellario’s office in Padua?

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$From both, my lord. Bellario greets your grace.$NEWLINE$(gives DUKE a letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a letter)
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. Bellario sends his greetings.$NEWLINE$(she gives the DUKE a letter)$NEWLINE$(she gives the$NEWLINE$a letter)

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK sharpens a knife on the bottom of his shoe$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK sharpens his knife on the sole of his shoe.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK) Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK) Why are you sharpening your knife so eagerly?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$To cut the forfeiture from that bankrupt there.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$To cut my penalty from that bankrupt man over there.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew,$NEWLINE$Thou makest thy knife keen. But no metal can—$NEWLINE$No, not the hangman’s axe—bear half the keenness$NEWLINE$Of thy sharp envy. Can no prayers pierce thee?
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$You’re sharpening that knife not on your sole but on your soul, you cruel Jew. No metal—not even the executioner’s axe—could ever be half as sharp as your hatred. Can’t any prayers reach your heart?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$No, none that you’re smart enough to make.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$O, be thou damned, inexecrable dog,$NEWLINE$And for thy life let justice be accused!$NEWLINE$Thou almost makest me waver in my faith$NEWLINE$To hold opinion with Pythagoras$NEWLINE$That souls of animals infuse themselves$NEWLINE$Into the trunks of men. Thy currish spirit$NEWLINE$Governed a wolf who, hanged for human slaughter,$NEWLINE$Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet,$NEWLINE$And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam$NEWLINE$Infused itself in thee, for thy desires$NEWLINE$Are wolvish, bloody, starved, and ravenous.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Oh, you’re going to hell, you disgusting dog. Killing you would be justice. You almost make me forget that I’m a Christian. You make me want to agree with the philosopher Pythagoras that animal souls are reincarnated in human bodies. Your vicious dog soul used to belong to a wolf that was killed for slaughtering humans. When he died, his cruel soul passed out of his body and went into yours while you were lying in your unholy mother’s womb. That’s why your desires are wolfish, bloody, and ravenous.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond,$NEWLINE$Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.$NEWLINE$Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall$NEWLINE$To cureless ruin. I stand here for law.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Unless your taunts can undo the signature on my contract, you’re just wearing out your lungs by speaking so loud. Be quiet, boy, or you’ll lose your mind. I stand here with the law on my side.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$This letter from Bellario doth commend$NEWLINE$A young and learnèd doctor to our court.$NEWLINE$Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$This letter from Bellario introduces us to a young and well-educated legal expert. Where is he?

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$He attendeth here hard by$NEWLINE$To know your answer whether you’ll admit him.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$He’s waiting nearby to find out if you’ll invite him in.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$With all my heart.—Some three or four of you$NEWLINE$Go give him courteous conduct to this place.—$NEWLINE$Meantime the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“Your grace shall understand that at the receipt of your letter I am very sick, but in the instant that your messenger came, in loving visitation was with me a young doctor of Rome. His name is Balthazar. I acquainted him with the cause in controversy between the Jew and Antonio the merchant. We turned o'er many books together. He is furnished with my opinion, which—bettered with his own learning, the greatness whereof I cannot enough commend—comes with him at my importunity to fill up your grace’s request in my stead.I beseech you, let his lack of years be no impediment to let him lack a reverend estimation, for I never knew so young a body with so old a head. I leave him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial shall better publish his commendation.”
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$With all my heart.—Three or four of you go welcome him.—In the meantime, I’ll read Bellario’s letter out loud.$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$(he reads)$NEWLINE$“I’ve received your letter but I’m very sick at the moment. As it happened, when your messenger came, a young lawyer from Rome was visiting me. His name is Balthazar. I told him about the case of the Jew and Antonio the merchant, and we consulted many books together. He knows my legal opinions about this matter, and he has his own expert opinions as well. I’m sending him in my place to answer your request for someone to act as judge in this matter. Please don’t underestimate him because he’s so young. I never knew such a young man with such a mature head. I leave him to you. When you put him to the test, you’ll see how wonderful he really is. You hear what the wise and educated Bellario writes.”

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA for Balthazar, disguised as a doctor of law$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA enters disguised as Balthazar, a lawyer.$NEWLINE$PORTIA

paragraphs.original: You hear the learned Bellario, what he writes.$NEWLINE$And here I take it is the doctor come.—$NEWLINE$Give me your hand. Come you from old Bellario?
paragraphs.translated: And this is the legal professor, I take it.—Let me shake your hand. Did old Bellario send you here?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I did, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$You are welcome. Take your place.$NEWLINE$Are you acquainted with the difference$NEWLINE$That holds this present question in the court?
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Welcome. Please have a seat. Are you familiar with the case currently before the court?
