paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I am informèd thoroughly of the cause.$NEWLINE$Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, thoroughly. Which one is the merchant? And which one is the Jew?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Antonio and Shylock, both of you come forward.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is your name Shylock?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is your name Shylock?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Shylock is my name.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Shylock is my name.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Of a strange nature is the suit you follow,$NEWLINE$Yet in such rule that the Venetian law$NEWLINE$Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) You stand within his danger, do you not?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Your case is most unusual, though the Venetian law can’t stop you from proceeding.—(to ANTONIO) He has a claim on you, correct?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Ay, so he says.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, so he says.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Do you confess the bond?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Do you acknowledge the contract?

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I do.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Yes, I do.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Then must the Jew be merciful.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Then the Jew must show you mercy.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$On what compulsion must I? Tell me that.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Why do I have to do that? Tell me.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The quality of mercy is not strained.$NEWLINE$It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven$NEWLINE$Upon the place beneath. It is twice blessed:$NEWLINE$It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.$NEWLINE$'Tis mightiest in the mightiest. It becomes$NEWLINE$The thronèd monarch better than his crown.$NEWLINE$His scepter shows the force of temporal power,$NEWLINE$The attribute to awe and majesty$NEWLINE$Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings,$NEWLINE$But mercy is above this sceptered sway.$NEWLINE$It is enthronèd in the hearts of kings.$NEWLINE$It is an attribute to God himself.$NEWLINE$And earthly power doth then show likest God’s$NEWLINE$When mercy seasons justice. Therefore, Jew,
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$No one shows mercy because he has to. It just happens, the way gentle rain drops on the ground. Mercy is a double blessing. It blesses the one who gives it and the one who receives it. It’s strongest in the strongest people. It looks better in a king than his own crown looks on him. The king’s scepter represents his earthly power, the symbol of majesty, the focus of royal authority. But mercy is higher than the scepter. It’s enthroned in the hearts of kings, a quality of God himself. Kingly power seems most like God’s power when the king mixes mercy with justice. So although justice is your plea, Jew, consider this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Though justice be thy plea, consider this—$NEWLINE$That in the course of justice none of us$NEWLINE$Should see salvation. We do pray for mercy,$NEWLINE$And that same prayer doth teach us all to render$NEWLINE$The deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much$NEWLINE$To mitigate the justice of thy plea,$NEWLINE$Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice$NEWLINE$Must needs give sentence 'gainst the merchant there.
paragraphs.translated: Justice won’t save our souls. We pray for mercy, and this same prayer teaches us to show mercy to others as well. I’ve told you this to make you give up this case. If you pursue it, this strict court of Venice will need to carry out the sentence against the merchant there.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$My deeds upon my head. I crave the law,$NEWLINE$The penalty, and forfeit of my bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I take all responsibility for my decisions. I want the law, the penalty, and the fulfillment of my contract.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Is he not able to discharge the money?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Can’t he pay back the money?

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Yes, here I tender it for him in the court—$NEWLINE$Yea, twice the sum. If that will not suffice,$NEWLINE$I will be bound to pay it ten times o'er,$NEWLINE$On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.$NEWLINE$If this will not suffice, it must appear$NEWLINE$That malice bears down truth.—$NEWLINE$(to DUKE)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And I beseech you,$NEWLINE$Wrest once the law to your authority.$NEWLINE$To do a great right, do a little wrong,$NEWLINE$And curb this cruel devil of his will.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Yes. I’m offering to pay it back right this moment—even twice the sum. If that’s not enough, I’ll sign a contract to pay ten times that much, and I’ll give you my hands, my head, and my heart as security. If that’s not enough, then you’re just evil and malicious.—(to the DUKE) I beg you, just this once, use your authority to bend the law. Do a great right by doing a little wrong. Don’t let this devil have his way.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It must not be. There is no power in Venice$NEWLINE$Can alter a decree establishèd.$NEWLINE$'Twill be recorded for a precedent,$NEWLINE$And many an error by the same example$NEWLINE$Will rush into the state. It cannot be.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That can’t happen. There’s no power in Venice that can change an established decree. The change will be recorded as a precedent, and many bad legal decisions will result. That can’t happen.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$A Daniel come to judgment, yea, a Daniel!—$NEWLINE$O wise young judge, how I do honor thee!
paragraphs.translated:
SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$A
Daniel has come to judgment, yes, a Daniel!—Oh, wise young judge, I honor you!$NEWLINE$Daniel$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I pray you, let me look upon the bond.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Please, let me review the contract.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$(giving PORTIA a document)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a document)$NEWLINE$Here ’tis, most reverend doctor, here it is.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$(he hands PORTIA a paper) Here it is, judge, here it is.$NEWLINE$(he hands$NEWLINE$a paper)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Shylock, there’s thrice thy money offered thee.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Shylock, they’re offering you three times the money you lent.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$An oath, an oath, I have an oath in heaven.$NEWLINE$Shall I lay perjury upon my soul?$NEWLINE$No, not for Venice.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$But I made an oath, an oath, an oath in heaven. Should I perjure my soul by disobeying it? No, not for all of Venice.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why, this bond is forfeit!$NEWLINE$And lawfully by this the Jew may claim$NEWLINE$A pound of flesh to be by him cut off$NEWLINE$Nearest the merchant’s heart.—Be merciful.$NEWLINE$Take thrice thy money. Bid me tear the bond.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The money wasn’t paid back! And so the Jew may lawfully claim a pound of flesh nearest the merchant’s heart, to be cut off by him.—But please have mercy. Take three times your money. Tell me to tear up this contract.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$When it is paid according to the tenor.$NEWLINE$It doth appear you are a worthy judge.$NEWLINE$You know the law. Your exposition$NEWLINE$Hath been most sound. I charge you by the law,$NEWLINE$Whereof you are a well-deserving pillar,$NEWLINE$Proceed to judgment. By my soul I swear$NEWLINE$There is no power in the tongue of man$NEWLINE$To alter me. I stay here on my bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’ll tear it up when it’s paid. You seem like a good judge. You know the law. Your explanation has made sense. I urge you to deliver your verdict. I swear that nothing anyone can say will change my mind. I’m sticking to the contract.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Most heartily I do beseech the court$NEWLINE$To give the judgment.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I beg the court to deliver the verdict.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why then, thus it is:$NEWLINE$You must prepare your bosom for his knife.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Well, then, here it is: you must prepare yourself for his knife.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$O noble judge! O excellent young man!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Oh, good judge! Oh, you excellent young man!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$For the intent and purpose of the law$NEWLINE$Hath full relation to the penalty,$NEWLINE$Which here appeareth due upon the bond.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The law fully authorizes the penalty, which you have to pay according to the contract.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$'Tis very true. O wise and upright judge!$NEWLINE$How much more elder art thou than thy looks!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Very true. Oh wise judge! You’re so much older than you look!

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) Therefore lay bare your bosom.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) So bare your chest.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Ay, his breast.$NEWLINE$So says the bond. Doth it not, noble judge?$NEWLINE$“Nearest his heart”—those are the very words.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Yes, his chest! That’s what the contract says, doesn’t it, judge? “Nearest his heart.”—Those are the very words.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It is so. Are there balance here to weigh$NEWLINE$The flesh?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes. Is there a scale here to weigh the flesh?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I have them ready.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I have it ready.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Have by some surgeon, Shylock, on your charge,$NEWLINE$To stop his wounds lest he do bleed to death.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Pay a surgeon to stand by and bind his wounds, Shylock, so he doesn’t bleed to death.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Is it so nominated in the bond?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Is that called for in the contract?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It is not so expressed, but what of that?$NEWLINE$'Twere good you do so much for charity.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Not explicitly, but so what? It wouldn’t hurt you to be charitable.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I cannot find it. 'Tis not in the bond.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I can’t find it. It’s not in the contract.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) You, merchant, have you any thing to say?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO) You, merchant, do you have anything to say?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But little. I am armed and well prepared.—$NEWLINE$Give me your hand, Bassanio. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Not much. I’m ready and waiting.—Give me your hand, Bassanio. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Grieve not that I am fall'n to this for you,$NEWLINE$For herein Fortune shows herself more kind$NEWLINE$Than is her custom. It is still her use$NEWLINE$To let the wretched man outlive his wealth,$NEWLINE$To view with hollow eye and wrinkled brow$NEWLINE$An age of poverty—from which lingering penance$NEWLINE$Of such misery doth she cut me off.$NEWLINE$Commend me to your honorable wife.$NEWLINE$Tell her the process of Antonio’s end.$NEWLINE$Say how I loved you. Speak me fair in death.$NEWLINE$And when the tale is told, bid her be judge$NEWLINE$Whether Bassanio had not once a love.$NEWLINE$Repent but you that you shall lose your friend,$NEWLINE$And he repents not that he pays your debt.$NEWLINE$For if the Jew do cut but deep enough,$NEWLINE$I’ll pay it presently with all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: Don’t be sad that this happened because of you, because Lady Luck’s been nicer to me than usual. Usually she makes the unhappy man live on after he loses his wealth, to spend his old age in poverty. But in my case she’s letting me avoid that misery. Send your honorable wife my greetings, and tell her how I died and how I loved you. Speak well of me after I’m dead, and when the tale’s done, ask her to judge whether Bassanio had a friend. Be sad only at the fact that you’ll lose your friend—your friend doesn’t regret that he paid your debt. If the Jew cuts deep enough, I’ll pay it instantly with all my heart.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Antonio, I am married to a wife$NEWLINE$Which is as dear to me as life itself.$NEWLINE$But life itself, my wife, and all the world$NEWLINE$Are not with me esteemed above thy life.$NEWLINE$I would lose all—ay, sacrifice them all$NEWLINE$Here to this devil—to deliver you.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Antonio, I married a woman as dear to me as life itself. But life itself, my wife, and the whole world aren’t more valuable to me than your life is. I’d give it all up—yes, I’d sacrifice them all to this devil here—to save you.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Your wife would give you little thanks for that$NEWLINE$If she were by to hear you make the offer.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Your wife wouldn’t like it if she were here to hear you make that offer.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I have a wife, whom I protest I love.$NEWLINE$I would she were in heaven, so she could$NEWLINE$Entreat some power to change this currish Jew.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I have a wife I love. I wish she were in heaven so she could appeal to some power to make this dog Jew change his mind.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$'Tis well you offer it behind her back.$NEWLINE$The wish would make else an unquiet house.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$It’s nice you’re offering to sacrifice her behind her back. That wish of yours could start quite an argument back at home.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$These be the Christian husbands. I have a daughter.$NEWLINE$Would any of the stock of Barabbas$NEWLINE$Had been her husband rather than a Christian!—$NEWLINE$We trifle time. I pray thee, pursue sentence.
paragraphs.translated:
SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$That’s what you get for marrying Christian husbands. I have a daughter. I wish she’d married any one of
Barabbas’s descendants instead of a Christian!—We’re wasting time. Please, deliver the sentence.$NEWLINE$Barabbas’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$A pound of that same merchant’s flesh is thine.$NEWLINE$The court awards it, and the law doth give it.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$A pound of this merchant’s flesh is yours. The court awards it and the law authorizes it.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Most rightful judge!
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What a righteous judge!

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$And you must cut this flesh from off his breast.$NEWLINE$The law allows it, and the court awards it.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$And you have to cut this flesh from his chest. The law allows it, and the court awards it.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Most learnèd judge, a sentence! Come, prepare.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$What a wise judge! Come on, get ready.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Tarry a little. There is something else.$NEWLINE$This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood.$NEWLINE$The words expressly are “a pound of flesh.”$NEWLINE$Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,$NEWLINE$But in the cutting it if thou dost shed$NEWLINE$One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods$NEWLINE$Are by the laws of Venice confiscate$NEWLINE$Unto the state of Venice.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$But wait a moment. There’s something else. This contract doesn’t give you any blood at all. The words expressly specify “a pound of flesh.” So take your penalty of a pound of flesh, but if you shed one drop of Christian blood when you cut it, the state of Venice will confiscate your land and property under Venetian law.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$O upright judge!—Mark, Jew.—O learnèd judge!
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Oh, what an upright judge!—Pay attention, Jew.—Oh, what a smart judge!

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Is that the law?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Is that the law?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Thyself shalt see the act.$NEWLINE$For as thou urgest justice, be assured$NEWLINE$Thou shalt have justice more than thou desirest.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You can see for yourself. You asked for justice, so rest assured you’ll get more justice than you bargained for.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$O learnèd judge!—Mark, Jew, a learnèd judge!
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Oh, what a wise judge!—Pay attention, Jew. A wise judge!

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I take this offer then: pay the bond thrice$NEWLINE$And let the Christian go.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$In that case I’ll take their offer. Pay me three times the amount of the loan and let the Christian go.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Here is the money.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Here is the money.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Soft!$NEWLINE$The Jew shall have all justice. Soft, no haste.$NEWLINE$He shall have nothing but the penalty.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Wait! The Jew will have justice. Wait, don’t rush! He’s not getting anything except the penalty.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$O Jew! An upright judge, a learnèd judge!
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Oh, Jew, what an upright judge this is! What a wise judge!

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.$NEWLINE$Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more$NEWLINE$But just a pound of flesh. If thou takest more$NEWLINE$Or less than a just pound, be it but so much$NEWLINE$As makes it light or heavy in the substance$NEWLINE$Or the division of the twentieth part$NEWLINE$Of one poor scruple—nay, if the scale do turn$NEWLINE$But in the estimation of a hair,$NEWLINE$Thou diest and all thy goods are confiscate.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$So get ready to cut off the flesh. Don’t shed any blood, or cut less or more than exactly a pound of flesh. If you take more or less than exactly a pound, even if it’s just the tiniest fraction of an ounce—if the scale changes by even so much as a hair, you die, and all your property will be confiscated.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew!$NEWLINE$Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A second Daniel!—A Daniel, Jew! I’ve got you now, pagan.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why doth the Jew pause? Take thy forfeiture.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Why is the Jew waiting? Take your penalty.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Give me my principal, and let me go.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Give me my money and let me go.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I have it ready for thee. Here it is.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I have it ready for you. Here it is.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He hath refused it in the open court.$NEWLINE$He shall have merely justice and his bond.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$No, he refused it publicly, in open court. He will have only justice and his penalty.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A Daniel, still say I, a second Daniel!—$NEWLINE$I thank thee, Jew, for teaching me that word.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A Daniel, I keep saying it! A second Daniel!—Thank you, Jew, for teaching me that word.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Shall I not have barely my principal?
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I won’t even get the original three thousand ducats back?

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture$NEWLINE$To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You can’t have anything but the penalty, to be taken at your peril, Jew.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Why then, the devil give him good of it!$NEWLINE$I’ll stay no longer question.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Well, then, I hope he chokes on it! I’m not staying here to argue anymore.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Tarry, Jew.$NEWLINE$The law hath yet another hold on you.$NEWLINE$It is enacted in the laws of Venice,$NEWLINE$If it be proved against an alien$NEWLINE$That by direct or indirect attempts$NEWLINE$He seek the life of any citizen,$NEWLINE$The party 'gainst the which he doth contrive$NEWLINE$Shall seize one half his goods. The other half$NEWLINE$Comes to the privy coffer of the state,$NEWLINE$And the offender’s life lies in the mercy$NEWLINE$Of the Duke only 'gainst all other voice.$NEWLINE$In which predicament I say thou stand’st,$NEWLINE$For it appears by manifest proceeding$NEWLINE$That indirectly—and directly too—$NEWLINE$Thou hast contrived against the very life$NEWLINE$Of the defendant, and thou hast incurred$NEWLINE$The danger formerly by me rehearsed.$NEWLINE$Down, therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Wait a minute, Jew. The law has another hold on you. The laws of Venice state that if a foreign resident directly or indirectly attempts to kill any citizen, the person he tried to kill will receive one half of the foreigner’s goods. The other half goes to the state. Whether the offending person lives or dies is up to the duke—there’s no one else to appeal to. In your predicament you’ve earned that punishment, because you’ve clearly contrived indirectly—and directly too—to take the life of the defendant. So get down on your knees and beg mercy from the duke.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself,$NEWLINE$And yet, thy wealth being forfeit to the state,$NEWLINE$Thou hast not left the value of a cord.$NEWLINE$Therefore thou must be hanged at the state’s charge.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Beg to be allowed to hang yourself! But if you’ve handed over all your wealth to the state, you don’t even have enough money left to buy a rope. So you’ll be hanged at the state’s expense.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit,$NEWLINE$I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.$NEWLINE$For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s.$NEWLINE$The other half comes to the general state,$NEWLINE$Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$I want you to see the difference between us, so I pardon you even before you ask for a pardon. Half of your wealth goes to Antonio. The other half goes to the state. However, if you show a proper humility, I may reduce this penalty to a fine.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Ay, for the state, not for Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Yes, the state’s half can be reduced, but not Antonio’s.

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Nay, take my life and all. Pardon not that.$NEWLINE$You take my house when you do take the prop$NEWLINE$That doth sustain my house. You take my life$NEWLINE$When you do take the means whereby I live.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$No, go ahead and take my life. Don’t pardon that. You take my house away when you take the money I need for upkeep. You take my life when you take away my means of making a living.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What mercy can you render him, Antonio?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What mercy can you show him, Antonio?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A halter gratis, nothing else, for God’s sake.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$A hangman’s rope free of charge. Nothing else, for God’s sake!

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$So please my lord the duke and all the court,$NEWLINE$To quit the fine for one half of his goods$NEWLINE$I am content, so he will let me have$NEWLINE$The other half in use to render it$NEWLINE$Upon his death unto the gentleman$NEWLINE$That lately stole his daughter.$NEWLINE$Two things provided more: that for this favor$NEWLINE$He presently become a Christian;$NEWLINE$The other, that he do record a gift$NEWLINE$Here in the court, of all he dies possessed,$NEWLINE$Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$If the duke and his court agree to set aside the fine for one half of his property, I’m happy, as long as he lets me have the other half in trust, to give it to the gentleman who recently stole his daughter. I only ask two more things. First, Shylock must immediately become a Christian. Second, he must make a will here in this court that leaves all his property to his son-in-law Lorenzo and his daughter when he dies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$He shall do this, or else I do recant$NEWLINE$The pardon that I late pronouncèd here.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$He must do this, or I’ll recant the pardon I just delivered.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Art thou contented, Jew? What dost thou say?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Are you satisfied, Jew? What do you say?

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I am content.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I’m satisfied.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Clerk, draw a deed of gift.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) Clerk, draw up a document to make his gift official.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$I pray you, give me leave to go from hence.$NEWLINE$I am not well. Send the deed after me,$NEWLINE$And I will sign it.
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$Please let me go. I’m not well. Send the deed after me and I’ll sign it.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$Get thee gone, but do it.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$Go, but sign the deed.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$In christening shalt thou have two godfathers.$NEWLINE$Had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more—$NEWLINE$To bring thee to the gallows, not to the font.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to SHYLOCK) When you’re baptized a Christian, you’ll have two godfathers. If I’d been the judge, you would’ve had ten more—twelve jurors to sentence you to death rather than baptism.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit SHYLOCK$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK
paragraphs.translated: SHYLOCK exits.$NEWLINE$SHYLOCK

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Sir, I entreat you home with me to dinner.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Sir, please come home with me to dinner.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I humbly do desire your grace of pardon.$NEWLINE$I must away this night toward Padua,$NEWLINE$And it is meet I presently set forth.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I’m very sorry, sir, but I have to go to Padua tonight. I should really leave right away.

paragraphs.original: DUKE$NEWLINE$I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.—$NEWLINE$Antonio, gratify this gentleman,$NEWLINE$For in my mind you are much bound to him.
paragraphs.translated: DUKE$NEWLINE$I’m sorry you don’t have time.—Antonio, give this gentleman a reward. In my opinion, you owe him a lot.

paragraphs.original: Exit DUKE and his train$NEWLINE$DUKE
paragraphs.translated: The DUKE and his entourage exit.$NEWLINE$DUKE

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Have by your wisdom been this day acquitted$NEWLINE$Of grievous penalties, in lieu whereof$NEWLINE$Three thousand ducats due unto the Jew$NEWLINE$We freely cope your courteous pains withal.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Sir, thanks to you my friend and I have been freed from paying some awful penalties today. Instead of giving the Jew the three thousand ducats he’s owed, we give it to you in gratitude for your kind efforts.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And stand indebted, over and above,$NEWLINE$In love and service to you evermore.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$And even then we’re still indebted to you. We owe you love and service forever.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He is well paid that is well satisfied.$NEWLINE$And I, delivering you, am satisfied,$NEWLINE$And therein do account myself well paid.$NEWLINE$My mind was never yet more mercenary.$NEWLINE$I pray you, know me when we meet again.$NEWLINE$I wish you well, and so I take my leave.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Being satisfied with a job well done is payment enough. In saving you I consider myself well paid. My thoughts were never on money. I hope you’ll recognize me when we meet again. I wish you well. Now, I’ve got to go.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further.$NEWLINE$Take some remembrance of us as a tribute,$NEWLINE$Not as a fee. Grant me two things, I pray you:$NEWLINE$Not to deny me, and to pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Sir, I really feel the need to give you something. Take some memento from us as a token of our gratitude, not as a fee. Please do two favors for me. First, don’t refuse me, and second, excuse me for insisting.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You press me far and therefore I will yield.$NEWLINE$(to ANTONIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Give me your gloves. I’ll wear them for your sake.$NEWLINE$(to BASSANIO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And for your love, I’ll take this ring from you.$NEWLINE$Do not draw back your hand. I’ll take no more,$NEWLINE$And you in love shall not deny me this.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Since you keep insisting, I’ll do as you say. (to ANTONIO) Give me your gloves. I’ll wear them for your sake. (to BASSANIO) And as a souvenir of your appreciation, I’ll take this ring from you. Don’t pull your hand back. I won’t take anything more than this, and you can’t refuse me this.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This ring, good sir—alas, it is a trifle.$NEWLINE$I will not shame myself to give you this.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$This ring, sir—oh no, it’s nothing. I’d be ashamed to give you this.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I will have nothing else but only this.$NEWLINE$And now methinks I have a mind to it.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I don’t want anything but that. Now that I think about it, I really want it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$There’s more depends on this than on the value.$NEWLINE$The dearest ring in Venice will I give you,$NEWLINE$And find it out by proclamation.$NEWLINE$Only for this, I pray you, pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$There’s more to this ring than its cash value. I’ll give you the most expensive ring in Venice, and I’ll make a public announcement to help me find it. But as for this ring, please excuse me.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.$NEWLINE$You taught me first to beg, and now methinks$NEWLINE$You teach me how a beggar should be answered.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I see you like to make big offers, sir. First you taught me how to beg, and now I think you’re teaching me how a beggar should be answered.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife.$NEWLINE$And when she put it on, she made me vow$NEWLINE$That I should neither sell nor give nor lose it.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Good sir, this ring was given to me by my wife. When she put it on my finger, she made me swear never to sell it, give it away, or lose it.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts.$NEWLINE$An if your wife be not a madwoman,$NEWLINE$And know how well I have deserved the ring,$NEWLINE$She would not hold out enemy forever$NEWLINE$For giving it to me. Well, peace be with you.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Many men use that excuse to avoid giving gifts. If your wife’s not a madwoman, and you tell her how much I deserve this ring, she won’t stay angry at you forever if you give it to me. Well, anyway, goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PORTIA and NERISSA$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA and NERISSA exit.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio, let him have the ring.$NEWLINE$Let his deservings and my love withal$NEWLINE$Be valued against your wife’s commandment.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Bassanio, let him have the ring. Consider how much he deserves it, and weigh that, along with my friendship, against your wife’s order.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(giving GRATIANO the ring)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$the ring)$NEWLINE$Go, Gratiano, run and overtake him.$NEWLINE$Give him the ring and bring him, if thou canst,$NEWLINE$Unto Antonio’s house. Away, make haste.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(he gives GRATIANO the ring) Go, Gratiano, run and catch up with him. Give him the ring, and take him to Antonio’s house if you can. Go quickly.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$the ring)

paragraphs.original: Exit GRATIANO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO exits.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO

paragraphs.original: Come, you and I will thither presently.$NEWLINE$And in the morning early will we both$NEWLINE$Fly toward Belmont. Come, Antonio.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you and I will go soon. Early in the morning we’ll both rush to Belmont. Come on, Antonio.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA and NERISSA, both disguised$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA and NERISSA enter, both still in disguise.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Inquire the Jew’s house out. Give him this deed,$NEWLINE$And let him sign it. We’ll away tonight,$NEWLINE$And be a day before our husbands home.$NEWLINE$This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Find out where the Jew’s house is. Give him this deed and have him sign it. We’ll leave tonight and be home a day before our husbands get back. Lorenzo will be happy with what we’ve done.

paragraphs.original: Enter GRATIANO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO enters.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(giving PORTIA BASSANIO’s ring)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$’s ring)$NEWLINE$Fair sir, you are well o'erta'en.$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio upon more advice$NEWLINE$Hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat$NEWLINE$Your company at dinner.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(he gives PORTIA BASSANIO’s ring) Sir, you’re lucky I caught up with you. Bassanio thought about it some more and sent this ring to you. He would like to invite you to dinner.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$’s ring)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That cannot be.$NEWLINE$His ring I do accept most thankfully.$NEWLINE$And so I pray you tell him. Furthermore,$NEWLINE$I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I can’t have dinner with him. Please tell him I accept his ring with thanks. And could you please take my servant to old Shylock’s house?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$That will I do.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I’ll do that.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Sir, I would speak with you.$NEWLINE$(aside to PORTIA)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I’ll see if I can get my husband’s ring,$NEWLINE$Which I did make him swear to keep for ever.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Sir, may I speak with you? (speaking so that only PORTIAcan hear) I’ll see if I can get my husband’s ring, which I made him swear to keep forever.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(aside to NERISSA)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thou mayst, I warrant. We shall have old swearing$NEWLINE$That they did give the rings away to men.$NEWLINE$But we’ll outface them, and outswear them too.—
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) I bet you’ll be able to. They’ll swear they gave the rings to men. But we’ll deny it and outswear them too.—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Away, make haste. Thou know’st where I will tarry.
paragraphs.translated: Go, hurry. You know where I’ll be waiting.

paragraphs.original: Exit PORTIA$NEWLINE$PORTIA
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come, good sir. Will you show me to this house?
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO) Sir, will you show me to Shylock’s house now?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter LORENZO and JESSICA$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO and JESSICA enter.$NEWLINE$LORENZO$NEWLINE$JESSICA

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$The moon shines bright. In such a night as this,$NEWLINE$When the sweet wind did gently kiss the trees$NEWLINE$And they did make no noise, in such a night$NEWLINE$Troilus methinks mounted the Trojan walls$NEWLINE$And sighed his soul toward the Grecian tents$NEWLINE$Where Cressid lay that night.
paragraphs.translated:
LORENZO$NEWLINE$The moon’s bright tonight. I think that on a night like this, when the wind blew the trees so gently that they didn’t make a sound,
Troilus climbed up onto the walls of Troy and sighed for Cressida in the Greek camp.$NEWLINE$Troilus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Did Thisbe fearfully o'ertrip the dew$NEWLINE$And saw the lion’s shadow ere himself$NEWLINE$And ran dismayed away.
paragraphs.translated:
JESSICA$NEWLINE$On a night like this,
Thisbe saw the lion’s shadow and ran away in fear.$NEWLINE$Thisbe$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Stood Dido with a willow in her hand$NEWLINE$Upon the wild sea banks, and waft her love$NEWLINE$To come again to Carthage.
paragraphs.translated:
LORENZO$NEWLINE$On a night like this,
Dido stood holding a willow branch on the seashore, begging her lover to come back to her in Carthage.$NEWLINE$Dido$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Medea gathered the enchanted herbs$NEWLINE$That did renew old Æson.
paragraphs.translated:
JESSICA$NEWLINE$On a night like this,
Medea gathered magic herbs to rejuvenate old Aeson.$NEWLINE$Medea$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Did Jessica steal from the wealthy Jew,$NEWLINE$And with an unthrift love did run from Venice$NEWLINE$As far as Belmont.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$On a night like this, Jessica ran away from the wealthy Jew and stole his money. She ran away from Venice all the way to Belmont with her spendthrift lover.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Did young Lorenzo swear he loved her well,$NEWLINE$Stealing her soul with many vows of faith,$NEWLINE$And ne'er a true one.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$On a night like this, young Lorenzo swore he loved her very much, stealing her heart with vows of love, but not one vow was true.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$In such a night$NEWLINE$Did pretty Jessica, like a little shrew,$NEWLINE$Slander her love, and he forgave it her.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$On a night like this, pretty Jessica, in a bad mood, said outrageously wrong things about her lover, and he forgave her.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I would outnight you, did nobody come.$NEWLINE$But, hark, I hear the footing of a man.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’d get the better of you in this storytelling game, but somebody’s coming. I hear his footsteps.

paragraphs.original: Enter STEPHANO, a messenger$NEWLINE$STEPHANO
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO, a messenger, enters.$NEWLINE$STEPHANO

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who comes so fast in silence of the night?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who are you, coming so fast in this quiet night?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$A friend.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$A friend.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$A friend? What friend? Your name, I pray you, friend?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$A friend? What friend? What’s your name, please, friend?

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$Stephano is my name, and I bring word$NEWLINE$My mistress will before the break of day$NEWLINE$Be here at Belmont. She doth stray about$NEWLINE$By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays$NEWLINE$For happy wedlock hours.
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$My name’s Stephano, and I’ve come to tell you my mistress will arrive here at Belmont before sunrise. She’s still at the monastery, kneeling and praying for a happy marriage.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who comes with her?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who’s coming with her?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$None but a holy hermit and her maid.$NEWLINE$I pray you, is my master yet returned?
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO$NEWLINE$No one except her maid and a holy hermit. Has my master returned yet?

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$He is not, nor we have not heard from him.—$NEWLINE$But go we in, I pray thee, Jessica,$NEWLINE$And ceremoniously let us prepare$NEWLINE$Some welcome for the mistress of the house.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$No, he hasn’t, and we haven’t heard from him.—But let’s go in, Jessica. We’ll get ready to welcome the mistress of the house back home.

paragraphs.original: Enter LAUNCELOT the clown$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT enters.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Sola, sola! Wo, ha, ho! Sola, sola!
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Hey, hey! Hey! Yoo-hoo!

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who calls?
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Who’s shouting?

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Sola! Did you see Master Lorenzo? Master Lorenzo, sola, sola!
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Hey! Have you seen Master Lorenzo! Master Lorenzo, hey! Hey!

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Leave holloaing, man. Here.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Stop hollering, man! I’m here.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Sola! Where, where?
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Hey! Where, where?

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Here.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Tell him there’s a post come from my master with his horn full of good news. My master will be here ere morning.
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$Tell him a messenger has arrived from my master with good news. My master will be here in the morning.

paragraphs.original: Exit LAUNCELOT$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT
paragraphs.translated: LAUNCELOT exits.$NEWLINE$LAUNCELOT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.$NEWLINE$And yet no matter. Why should we go in?—$NEWLINE$My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you,$NEWLINE$Within the house, your mistress is at hand.$NEWLINE$And bring your music forth into the air.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$My dear, let’s go inside and wait for them to arrive. But I guess it doesn’t matter. Why should we go in?—Stephano, tell the household staff that your mistress is about to arrive, and bring some musicians outside here.

paragraphs.original: Exit STEPHANO$NEWLINE$STEPHANO
paragraphs.translated: STEPHANO exits.$NEWLINE$STEPHANO

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How sweet the moonlight sleeps upon this bank!$NEWLINE$Here will we sit and let the sounds of music$NEWLINE$Creep in our ears. Soft stillness and the night$NEWLINE$Become the touches of sweet harmony.$NEWLINE$Sit, Jessica. Look how the floor of heaven$NEWLINE$Is thick inlaid with patens of bright gold.$NEWLINE$There’s not the smallest orb which thou behold’st$NEWLINE$But in his motion like an angel sings,$NEWLINE$Still choiring to the young-eyed cherubins.$NEWLINE$Such harmony is in immortal souls,$NEWLINE$But whilst this muddy vesture of decay$NEWLINE$Doth grossly close it in, we cannot hear it.
paragraphs.translated: How beautiful the moonlight’s shining on this bank! Let’s sit here and let the music fill our ears. Stillness and nighttime are perfect for beautiful music. Sit down, Jessica. Look at the stars, see how the floor of heaven is inlaid with small disks of bright gold. Stars and planets move in such perfect harmony that some believe you can hear music in their movement. If you believe this, even the smallest star sings like an angel in its motion. Souls have that same kind of harmony. But because we’re here on earth in our earthly bodies, we can’t hear it.

paragraphs.original: Enter musicians
paragraphs.translated: Musicians enter.

paragraphs.original: Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn!$NEWLINE$With sweetest touches pierce your mistress' ear,$NEWLINE$And draw her home with music.
paragraphs.translated: Wake up the moon goddess with a hymn! Get her attention and draw her home with music.

paragraphs.original: Play music
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I am never merry when I hear sweet music.
paragraphs.translated: JESSICA$NEWLINE$I’m never in the mood to laugh when I hear sweet music.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$The reason is your spirits are attentive.$NEWLINE$For do but note a wild and wanton herd,$NEWLINE$Or race of youthful and unhandled colts,$NEWLINE$Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,$NEWLINE$Which is the hot condition of their blood—$NEWLINE$If they but hear perchance a trumpet sound,$NEWLINE$Or any air of music touch their ears,$NEWLINE$You shall perceive them make a mutual stand,$NEWLINE$Their savage eyes turned to a modest gaze$NEWLINE$By the sweet power of music.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$That’s because your soul is paying attention to the music. Take a wild herd of animals, or young untrained colts, leaping around like crazy, roaring and neighing loudly, which they have to do because it’s in their blood—but if they happen to hear a trumpet, or any kind of music, they all stand still. Sweet music makes their wild eyes peaceful. That’s why the poet Ovid wrote that the great musician Orpheus could make

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Therefore the poet$NEWLINE$Did feign that Orpheus drew trees, stones, and floods$NEWLINE$Since naught so stockish, hard, and full of rage,$NEWLINE$But music for the time doth change his nature.$NEWLINE$The man that hath no music in himself,$NEWLINE$Nor is not moved with concord of sweet sounds,$NEWLINE$Is fit for treasons, stratagems, and spoils.$NEWLINE$The motions of his spirit are dull as night,$NEWLINE$And his affections dark as Erebus.$NEWLINE$Let no such man be trusted. Mark the music.
paragraphs.translated: trees, stones, and rivers come to him by playing music. There’s nothing in the world that can resist music. The man who can’t be moved by the harmonious melodies is fit only for treason, violence, and pillage. His soul is as dull as night and dark as the underworld. Nobody like that should be trusted. Pay attention to the music.

paragraphs.original: Enter PORTIA and NERISSA$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA and NERISSA enter.$NEWLINE$PORTIA$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That light we see is burning in my hall.$NEWLINE$How far that little candle throws his beams!$NEWLINE$So shines a good deed in a naughty world.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$That light we see is coming from my hall. Look how far that little candle sends its light! That’s the way a good deed shines in a naughty world.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$When the moon shone we did not see the candle.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$While the moon was shining we didn’t even notice the candle.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$So doth the greater glory dim the less.$NEWLINE$A substitute shines brightly as a king$NEWLINE$Until a king be by, and then his state$NEWLINE$Empties itself, as doth an inland brook$NEWLINE$Into the main of waters. Music, hark.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Well, brighter lights always dim the smaller ones. A governor shines as brightly as a king until a king is near by, and the governor suddenly looks like a nobody. Music, listen!

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$It is your music, madam, of the house.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$It’s your music, madam, from your house.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Nothing is good, I see, without respect.$NEWLINE$Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Now I see that you can’t call anything good except in right context. I think that music sounds much better at night than it does during the day.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$The night’s silence makes it sound better.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark$NEWLINE$When neither is attended, and I think$NEWLINE$The nightingale, if she should sing by day$NEWLINE$When every goose is cackling, would be thought$NEWLINE$No better a musician than the wren.$NEWLINE$How many things by season seasoned are$NEWLINE$To their right praise and true perfection!$NEWLINE$Peace! How the moon sleeps with Endymion$NEWLINE$And would not be awaked.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$The crow sings as well as the lark when no one’s listening. If the nightingale sang during the day, when every goose is honking, nobody would think it sang any better than a wren. How many things in life seem good to us because of when they happen! Quiet now! Look how the moon seems to be sleeping with its lover and can’t be awoken!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Music ceases
paragraphs.translated: Music ceases.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$That is the voice,$NEWLINE$Or I am much deceived, of Portia.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$If I’m not mistaken, that’s Portia’s voice.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He knows me as the blind man knows the cuckoo—$NEWLINE$By the bad voice.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$He recognizes me like a blind man recognizes a cuckoo—by its bad voice.

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Dear lady, welcome home.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Dear lady, welcome home.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$We have been praying for our husbands' welfare,$NEWLINE$Which speed, we hope, the better for our words.$NEWLINE$Are they returned?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$We’ve been praying for our husbands' welfare. We hope they’re better off because of our prayers. Have they come back?

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Madam, they are not yet,$NEWLINE$But there is come a messenger before$NEWLINE$To signify their coming.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$No, ma'am, they haven’t. But a messenger came ahead to tell us they were on their way.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Go in, Nerissa.$NEWLINE$Give order to my servants that they take$NEWLINE$No note at all of our being absent hence.—$NEWLINE$Nor you, Lorenzo.—Jessica, nor you.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Go inside, Nerissa. Tell my servants not to mention that we were gone. You must not, either, Lorenzo—or you, Jessica.

paragraphs.original: A tucket sounds
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Your husband is at hand. I hear his trumpet.$NEWLINE$We are no tell-tales, madam. Fear you not.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Your husband’s near. I hear his trumpet. We’re not tattle-tales, madam, don’t worry.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$This night methinks is but the daylight sick.$NEWLINE$It looks a little paler. 'Tis a day$NEWLINE$Such as the day is when the sun is hid.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I think this night is just like sick daylight. It only looks a little paler. It looks like a day when the sun is hidden.

paragraphs.original: Enter BASSANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their followers$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO and NERISSA move aside and talk BASSANIO, ANTONIO, GRATIANO, and their followers enter. GRATIANO and NERISSA move aside and talk.$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$NERISSA$NEWLINE$BASSANIO$NEWLINE$ANTONIO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$GRATIANO$NEWLINE$NERISSA

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) We should hold day with the Antipodes,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If you would walk in absence of the sun.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) If you walked outside at night, it would be daylight here at the same time as on the other side of the world.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Let me give light, but let me not be light.$NEWLINE$For a light wife doth make a heavy husband,$NEWLINE$And never be Bassanio so for me.$NEWLINE$But God sort all! You are welcome home, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
PORTIA$NEWLINE$I’ll give
light to men, but I’ll never be light or unchaste. An unfaithful wife makes a husband worry, and I’ll never let Bassanio worry if I can help it. I hope God figures it all out! Welcome home, my husband.$NEWLINE$light$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$I thank you, madam. Give welcome to my friend.$NEWLINE$This is the man, this is Antonio,$NEWLINE$To whom I am so infinitely bound.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Thank you, darling. I’d like to introduce you to my friend. This is Antonio, my dearest friend. We are closely tied.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You should in all sense be much bound to him.$NEWLINE$For as I hear he was much bound for you.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You should be tied to him, since he tied himself up so much for you.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$No more than I am well acquitted of.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$But I’ve been paid back well.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Sir, you are very welcome to our house.$NEWLINE$It must appear in other ways than words,$NEWLINE$Therefore I scant this breathing courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Sir, welcome to our house. But action speaks louder than words, so I’ll cut short these polite words.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$In faith, I gave it to the judge’s clerk.$NEWLINE$Would he were gelt that had it, for my part,$NEWLINE$Since you do take it, love, so much at heart.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) I swear by that moon over there that you’re doing me wrong! I’m telling the truth! I gave it to the judge’s clerk. I wish the guy I gave it to had been castrated, since you’re getting so upset about it.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$A quarrel, ho, already? What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What, an argument already? What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring$NEWLINE$That she did give me, whose posy was$NEWLINE$For all the world like cutler’s poetry$NEWLINE$Upon a knife, “Love me and leave me not.”
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$We’re arguing about a hoop of gold, a cheap little ring she gave me, that had a little inscription on it, nothing more than a knife-maker’s attempt at poetry. It said, “Love me and don’t leave me.”

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$What talk you of the posy or the value?$NEWLINE$You swore to me when I did give it you$NEWLINE$That you would wear it till your hour of death,$NEWLINE$And that it should lie with you in your grave.$NEWLINE$Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,$NEWLINE$You should have been respective and have kept it.$NEWLINE$Gave it a judge’s clerk! No, God’s my judge.$NEWLINE$The clerk will ne'er wear hair on ’s face that had it.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$How can you talk about the quality of the poem or the value of the ring? You swore to me when I gave it to you that you would wear it till you died, and that it would be buried with you. If you didn’t want to take care of it for my sake, you should have just because you made so many vows that you’d take care of it. And now you claim you gave it to a judge’s clerk! No, I swear to God that clerk will never grow a beard on his face.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$He will, an if he live to be a man.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$He will if he lives long enough to become a man.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Ay, if a woman live to be a man.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, if a woman grows up to be a man.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Now, by this hand, I gave it to a youth,$NEWLINE$A kind of boy, a little scrubbèd boy$NEWLINE$No higher than thyself, the judge’s clerk,$NEWLINE$A prating boy that begged it as a fee.$NEWLINE$I could not for my heart deny it him.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$I swear I gave it to a youth, a kind of boy, a little stunted boy, no taller than yourself. He was the judge’s clerk, a chatty boy who wanted it as a fee. I didn’t have the heart to say no to him.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$You were to blame, I must be plain with you,$NEWLINE$To part so slightly with your wife’s first gift,$NEWLINE$A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger$NEWLINE$And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I have to be honest with you. You were wrong to give away your wife’s first gift so thoughtlessly, a thing you swore to keep on your finger and bound faithfully to your body.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I gave my love a ring and made him swear$NEWLINE$Never to part with it. And here he stands.$NEWLINE$I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it$NEWLINE$Nor pluck it from his finger for the wealth$NEWLINE$That the world masters. Now in faith, Gratiano,$NEWLINE$You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief.$NEWLINE$An ’twere to me, I should be mad at it.
paragraphs.translated: I gave my lover a ring and made him swear never to lose it or give it away. And here he is. I’d swear he wouldn’t leave it behind, or even take it off his finger, for all the money in the world. To tell the truth, Gratiano, you’re giving your wife a valid reason to get upset. If it were me, I’d be very upset too.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(aside) Why, I were best to cut my left hand off$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$And swear I lost the ring defending it.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to himself) Maybe I should cut off my left hand and swear I lost the ring defending it.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away$NEWLINE$Unto the judge that begged it and indeed$NEWLINE$Deserved it too. And then the boy, his clerk,$NEWLINE$That took some pains in writing, he begged mine.$NEWLINE$And neither man nor master would take aught$NEWLINE$But the two rings.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Bassanio gave his ring to the judge who asked for it, and deserved it too. And then his clerk, who went to a lot of trouble with the writing, begged for mine. Neither of them would take anything but the two rings.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$What ring gave you my lord?$NEWLINE$Not that, I hope, which you received of me.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Which ring did you give away, my lord? Not the one I gave you, I hope.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$If I could add a lie unto a fault$NEWLINE$I would deny it. but you see my finger$NEWLINE$Hath not the ring upon it. It is gone.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$If I could make things better by lying, I’d deny it. But you see my finger doesn’t have the ring on it. It’s gone.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Even so void is your false heart of truth.$NEWLINE$By heaven, I will ne'er come in your bed$NEWLINE$Until I see the ring.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Just as there’s no ring on your finger, there’s no truth in your heart. I swear I’ll never get into your bed until I see the ring again!

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Nor I in yours$NEWLINE$Till I again see mine.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO) Me neither, until I see mine again!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Sweet Portia,$NEWLINE$If you did know to whom I gave the ring,$NEWLINE$If you did know for whom I gave the ring,$NEWLINE$And would conceive for what I gave the ring,$NEWLINE$And how unwillingly I left the ring$NEWLINE$When naught would be accepted but the ring,$NEWLINE$You would abate the strength of your displeasure.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$My dear Portia, if you knew who I gave the ring to, for whose sake I gave the ring to him, why I gave it to him, and how unwilling I was to leave it when he wouldn’t accept anything but the ring, you wouldn’t be so angry.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If you had known the virtue of the ring,$NEWLINE$Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,$NEWLINE$Or your own honor to contain the ring,$NEWLINE$You would not then have parted with the ring.$NEWLINE$What man is there so much unreasonable,$NEWLINE$If you had pleased to have defended it$NEWLINE$With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty$NEWLINE$To urge the thing held as a ceremony?$NEWLINE$Nerissa teaches me what to believe.$NEWLINE$I’ll die for ’t but some woman had the ring.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$If you’d known how much that ring meant, how much the woman who gave it to you is worth, or how much your honor depended on your keeping the ring, you wouldn’t have let it go. Who would be so unreasonable as to insist on taking the ring if you’d defended it with any kind of zeal? Who would have had so little self-restraint that they’d insist on getting a ring with ceremonial value? Nerissa’s got the right idea. I’ll bet my life you gave some woman the ring!

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, by my honor, madam, by my soul,$NEWLINE$No woman had it but a civil doctor,$NEWLINE$Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me$NEWLINE$And begged the ring, the which I did deny him$NEWLINE$And suffered him to go displeased away—$NEWLINE$Even he that did uphold the very life$NEWLINE$Of my dear friend. What should I say, sweet lady?$NEWLINE$I was enforced to send it after him.$NEWLINE$I was beset with shame and courtesy.$NEWLINE$My honor would not let ingratitude$NEWLINE$So much besmear it. Pardon me, good lady,$NEWLINE$For by these blessèd candles of the night,$NEWLINE$Had you been there I think you would have begged$NEWLINE$The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, I swear, madam. No woman got it from me, but an expert in civil law who refused three thousand ducats but asked instead for the ring, which I denied him. I watched him leave looking discontented, even though he had saved the life of my good friend. What could I say, my dear? I had to send it to him. I was ashamed and wanted to show my good manners. I just couldn’t dishonor myself by acting ungrateful to him. Please forgive me, good lady. If you’d been there, I think you would have begged me to give him the ring.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Let not that doctor e'er come near my house!$NEWLINE$Since he hath got the jewel that I loved,$NEWLINE$And that which you did swear to keep for me,$NEWLINE$I will become as liberal as you.$NEWLINE$I’ll not deny him anything I have,$NEWLINE$No, not my body, nor my husband’s bed.$NEWLINE$Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.$NEWLINE$Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argus.$NEWLINE$If you do not, if I be left alone,$NEWLINE$Now, by mine honor—which is yet mine own—$NEWLINE$I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Don’t let that lawyer ever come near my house! Since he has the jewel I loved, which you swore you’d keep forever, I’ll be as generous as you were to him. I won’t deny him anything of mine, including my own body and my husband’s bed. I’ll recognize him all right, I’m sure of it. So don’t spend one night away from this house. Watch me like a hawk. If you don’t, if I’m left alone, I swear I’ll have that legal expert as my bedfellow.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO) And I his clerk. Therefore be well advised$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$How you do leave me to mine own protection.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(to GRATIANO) And I’ll have his clerk as mine. So be careful when you leave me to my own devices.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Well, do you so, let not me take him then.$NEWLINE$For if I do I’ll mar the young clerk’s pen.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Well, go ahead. But don’t let me catch him, because if I do I’ll break that clerk’s pen.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I am th' unhappy subject of these quarrels.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$All these quarrels are about me.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Sir, grieve not you. You are welcome notwithstanding.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Don’t be upset. You’re welcome in our home in spite of everything that’s going on.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Portia, forgive me this enforcèd wrong,$NEWLINE$And in the hearing of these many friends$NEWLINE$I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes$NEWLINE$Wherein I see myself—
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Portia, forgive me for this mistake that I had to make. All these friends are my witnesses, so I swear to you, I swear by your beautiful eyes, in which I see myself reflected—

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Mark you but that!$NEWLINE$In both my eyes he doubly sees himself—$NEWLINE$In each eye, one. Swear by your double self,$NEWLINE$And there’s an oath of credit!
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Did you hear that! He sees himself in my two eyes, so there’s two of him. He should swear by his two-faced self, and that’s an oath I’ll believe!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$Nay, but hear me.$NEWLINE$Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear$NEWLINE$I never more will break an oath with thee.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$No, just listen to me. If you forgive my mistake, I swear I’ll never break an oath with you again.

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I once did lend my body for his wealth,$NEWLINE$Which but for him that had your husband’s ring$NEWLINE$Had quite miscarried. I dare be bound again,$NEWLINE$My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord$NEWLINE$Will never more break faith advisedly.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I lent my body once to make him rich. If it hadn’t been for the gentleman who now owns your husband’s ring, my body would’ve been lost. I’d be the guarantee again, promising my soul this time as penalty, if your husband ever breaks a vow again knowingly.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(giving ANTONIO a ring)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a ring)$NEWLINE$Then you shall be his surety. Give him this,$NEWLINE$And bid him keep it better than the other.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$(she gives ANTONIO a ring) Then you’ll be my guarantee. Give him this. And tell him to hold on to it better than the other one.$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$a ring)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(giving BASSANIO PORTIA's ring)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$s ring)$NEWLINE$Here, Lord Bassanio. Swear to keep this ring.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$(he gives BASSANIO PORTIA’s ring) Here, Bassanio, swear that you’ll keep this ring.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$’s ring)

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$My God, it’s the same one I gave the judge!

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I had it of him. Pardon me, Bassanio,$NEWLINE$For by this ring, the doctor lay with me.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$I got it from him. I’m sorry, Bassanio, but the legal expert slept with me in exchange for this ring.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(taking out a ring)$NEWLINE$(taking out a ring)$NEWLINE$And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano,$NEWLINE$For that same scrubbèd boy, the doctor’s clerk,$NEWLINE$In lieu of this, last night did lie with me.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$(she takes out a ring) And I’m sorry too, Gratiano, but that stunted lawyer’s clerk slept with me last night in exchange for this ring.$NEWLINE$(she takes out a ring)

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Why, this is like the mending of highways$NEWLINE$In summer where the ways are fair enough!$NEWLINE$What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserved it?
paragraphs.translated: gratiano$NEWLINE$This is like fixing roads in the summer when they don’t need to be fixed! What, did you cheat on us before we deserved it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Speak not so grossly.—You are all amazed.$NEWLINE$(takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$(takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$Here is a letter. Read it at your leisure.$NEWLINE$It comes from Padua, from Bellario.$NEWLINE$There you shall find that Portia was the doctor,$NEWLINE$Nerissa there her clerk. Lorenzo here$NEWLINE$Shall witness I set forth as soon as you,$NEWLINE$And even but now returned. I have not yet$NEWLINE$Entered my house.—Antonio, you are welcome.$NEWLINE$And I have better news in store for you$NEWLINE$Than you expect.$NEWLINE$(gives ANTONIO another letter)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$another letter)$NEWLINE$Unseal this letter soon.$NEWLINE$There you shall find three of your argosies$NEWLINE$Are richly come to harbor suddenly.$NEWLINE$You shall not know by what strange accident$NEWLINE$I chancèd on this letter.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$Don’t be crass.—You all look confused. (she takes out a letter) Here’s a letter. Read it at your leisure. It comes from Padua, from Bellario. You’ll find out that Portia was the lawyer, and Nerissa was her clerk. Lorenzo here will testify that I left the house right when you did, and just returned. I haven’t yet entered my house.—Antonio, welcome. I have better news than you expect in store for you. (she gives ANTONIO another letter) Open this letter. You’ll find out that three of your ships have suddenly arrived in the harbor loaded with a great deal of wealth. You’ll never guess what a strange coincidence it was that I came across this letter.$NEWLINE$(she takes out a letter)$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$another letter)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I am dumb.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$I’m speechless.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Were you the doctor and I knew you not?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) You were the doctor, and I didn’t even recognize you?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$(to NERISSA) Were you the clerk with whom my wife’s going to cheat on me?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Ay, but the clerk that never means to do it$NEWLINE$Unless he live until he be a man.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, but the clerk will never do it, unless he grows up to be a man.

paragraphs.original: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) Sweet doctor, you shall be my bedfellow.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$When I am absent then lie with my wife.
paragraphs.translated: BASSANIO$NEWLINE$(to PORTIA) My sweet lawyer, you’ll be my bedfellow. When I’m not there, you can sleep with my wife.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Sweet lady, you have given me life and living.$NEWLINE$For here I read for certain that my ships$NEWLINE$Are safely come to road.
paragraphs.translated: ANTONIO$NEWLINE$Madam, you’ve given me life and given me a living too. I’ve read in this letter that my ships have safely come to harbor.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$How now, Lorenzo?$NEWLINE$My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$How are you, Lorenzo? My clerk has some comforting news for you, too.

paragraphs.original: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Ay, and I’ll give them him without a fee.$NEWLINE$(gives LORENZO a document)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$a document)$NEWLINE$There do I give to you and Jessica,$NEWLINE$From the rich Jew, a special deed of gift,$NEWLINE$After his death of all he dies possessed of.
paragraphs.translated: NERISSA$NEWLINE$Yes, and I’ll give it to him for free. (she gives LORENZO a document) This is from the rich Jew, for you and Jessica. It’s a special testament. After he dies, you’ll inherit everything he owns.$NEWLINE$(she gives$NEWLINE$a document)

paragraphs.original: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way$NEWLINE$Of starvèd people.
paragraphs.translated: LORENZO$NEWLINE$Ladies, you’re dropping bread from the heavens to starving people.

paragraphs.original: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It is almost morning,$NEWLINE$And yet I am sure you are not satisfied$NEWLINE$Of these events at full. Let us go in,$NEWLINE$And charge us there upon interr'gatories,$NEWLINE$And we will answer all things faithfully.
paragraphs.translated: PORTIA$NEWLINE$It’s almost morning, but I’m sure you’re not fully satisfied about what happened. Let’s go inside and we’ll answer all your questions truthfully.

paragraphs.original: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$Let it be so. The first interr'gatory$NEWLINE$That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is$NEWLINE$Whether till the next night she had rather stay,$NEWLINE$Or go to bed now, being two hours to day.$NEWLINE$But were the day come, I should wish it dark,$NEWLINE$That I were couching with the doctor’s clerk.$NEWLINE$Well, while I live I’ll fear no other thing$NEWLINE$So sore as keeping safe Nerissa’s ring.
paragraphs.translated: GRATIANO$NEWLINE$All right, then. My first question for Nerissa is whether she’d rather wait till tomorrow night or go to bed now, since there are only two more hours till morning. When the day comes, I’ll wish it were nighttime, so I could sleep with the legal expert’s clerk. In any case, I won’t worry about anything for the rest of my life more than keeping Nerissa’s ring safe.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.
